PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That cuts in funding to the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra would cause irreparable damage to the culture life of Tasmania and the development of music nationally.
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with their only nationwide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with their only nationwide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Page Primary School: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Canberra respectfully shows:

The ACT Schools Authority has acted in an unfair and improper manner in rejecting without notice or justification, the Planning Criteria of its Draft Plan ``Community Schools for Canberra 1989-2000'', in which context it had invited communities to respond, and in reaching decisions that conflict completely with those criteria.

The ACT Schools Authority, by acting in this way, has set a precedent for arbitrary school reorganization throughout the whole of Canberra, in which schools can be closed at any time without prior notice or consultation, and without effective justification.

The Page Community has been denied natural justice by the decision to close its neighbourhood school, because that decision was made without warning, without consultation, and without right of appeal.
The Page Community is the only one in Canberra that has been given no opportunity to respond to a specific draft proposal for closure of its school.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate note our strong and united protest at the ACT Schools Authority's decision to close Page Primary School.

Noting that, the ACT Schools Authority identified only two options for school reorganization in the South Belconnen area, and that it has chosen to implement neither, and that the people of the ACT are shortly to be given the possibility of self government; the Senate resolve that no South Belconnen schools be closed until the ACT Schools Authority has:
(a) developed a complete and integrated plan for the educational needs of the South Belconnen area;
(b) developed and publicized educational and social criteria for maintaining, relocating, reorganizing or closing schools;
(c) assessed all schools against these criteria;
(d) presented these results for public review, with a full range of options; and
(e) allowed reasonable time for community consultation prior to decisions being taken and implemented.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the Privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory Committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest Opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 165 citizens) and Watson (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 16 citizens), Cooney (from 72 citizens) and McKiernan (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatization, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the imposition of sales tax, import duties and other financial constraints on Telecom Australia will have the effects of:
Increasing local and SDT call charges.
Increasing telephone rental charges.
Increasing delays in providing services to new, rural, most small business and domestic subscribers.
Decreasing service standards generally.
Leading to the destruction of the Australian telecommunications manufacturing industry.
Increasing the internal and external pressures for the deregulation and/or privatisation of Telecom Australia.
Leading to the abandonment of the ``service to all Australians'' principle on which Telecom Australia has always operated if deregulation and/or privatisation continues further.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government revokes its recent decisions applying extra financial burdens on Telecom Australia and takes appropriate steps to ensure that Telecom Australia has the legal, and financial ability to discharge its statutory obligations to provide universal service under its present monopoly status as the national telecommunications provider.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatization, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Gambling Casino
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVESTOCK CORPORATION ORDER

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, immediately after Question Time this day, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name for this day for disallowance of Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Order MS12/88. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances sought advice from the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation about avenues of appeal against certain decisions made under the Corporation's orders and about the legal validity of part of the orders which appeared inappropriately to subdelegate legislative power. The Committee accepted the Corporation's view that in a fluctuating international export meat market review of the discretions concerned was not appropriate. The Committee also persuaded the Corporation that part of its orders were legally uncertain and they will be redrafted. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two letters which describe the Committee's scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
Mr Peter O'Keeffe
Secretary
The Standing Standing Committee on
Regulation and Ordinances...By Fax: 062 73 1380
Dear Mr O'Keeffe
AMLC Order No MS 12/88 dated 26 February 1988
I refer to Senator Collins' letter to the Chairman of this Corporation received by facsimile today.

I confirm that the words ``or otherwise notified by the Corporation by Notice published in the Gazette'' contained in paragraph 3 (a) of the Order were intended to accommodate variations from time to time due to changes in the currency adjustment factor (CAF) and the Bunker Adjustment Factor (BAF). CAF and BAF adjustments occur at three monthly intervals to reflect changes in the exchange rate and in the price of ships bunkers respectively. It was hoped to avoid having to seek the Minister's approval and issue a new Order every time such changes occurred. I should point out that the Corporation has already undertaken to the Minister not to amend the maximum freight rates as set out in the Schedule, other than for variations to the CAF and BAF, without first obtaining the Minister's approval.

We now believe that we can achieve the desired result by deleting from the Order the words to which your Committee objects and inserting in the Schedule to the Order a formula for variation of the CAF and BAF. All persons subject to the Order will be notified each time such a variation occurs.

Our Shipping Department has been instructed to prepare the appropriate formula for incorporation into the Schedule and we would propose to shortly seek the Minister's approval to vary the Order in the manner outlined above.
Yours sincerely
IAN J. HARMAN
General Counsel
Mr R. O. Austen, a.o.
Chairman
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation
Aetna Life Tower
Hyde Park Square
SYDNEY N.S.W. 2001
Dear Mr Austen,
At meetings on 26 and 30 May 1988 the Committee considered the letter of 25 May 1988 sent on your behalf by Mr I. J. Harman, General Counsel, concerning AMLC Order No. MS 12/88.

On the question of review rights the Committee noted the force of the Corporation's comments about the need for commercial flexibility in an unpredictable international market and how this factor lies behind the unreviewable and unstructured nature of the exemption discretion contained in paragraph 4 of the Order. Having taken account of the objects set out in section 4 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Act 1977 (the Act) under which Orders are made, the Committee decided not to pursue further the question of review rights. The Committee thanks you for advising it on this matter.

The Committee remains unhappy, however, about the legality and implications of the apparent sub-delegation, by the Corporation acting in its legislative capacity, to itself when acting in its executive capacity, of what seems to be a quasi-legislative or prescriptive power to amend the Order by an executive instrument, being an instrument which will by-pass the scrutiny of Parliament. The Committee's general concern is made up of a number of themes impinging in matters both of law and of principle.

Firstly, the Committee is inclined to the view that the Corporation's power to promulgate changes of shipping rates by means of notice published in the Gazette is a legislative and not merely an administrative power. An executive notice will change the law by making a new law; it will not merely change the way an existing law is applied. For an exporter to act contrary to the new law as changed by Gazette notice is to risk losing the right to continue to export. Thus, a legislative notice issued by an executive organ can in effect amend or repeal the law. Paragraph 3 (a) would appear, therefore, to be in the nature of a ``Henry VIII clause'' and since such a device is not expressly authorised in the enabling Act paragraph 3 (a) is objectionable on this ground. (See generally Report on the Delegation of Parliamentary Authority, Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, P.P. 331/78, Chapter 4; and The Operation of the Australian Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, P.P. 317/85, para. 3.29).

Secondly, the Gazette notice as such will not be subject to any parliamentary scrutiny. It is not required to be tabled in Parliament and it does not fall within the scope of any of the existing statutory disallowance schemes. It is contrary to general parliamentary principles as well as the Committee's scrutiny principles, for a subordinate law-maker to make subordinate legislation which is not subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. (Committee's Eightieth Report, P.P. 241/86, para. 3.9; and Eighty-third Report, April 1988, para. 4.15). Since the Committee is inclined to the view that the prospective Gazette notices will be legislative in character, paragraph 3 (a) is objectionable also on this ground.

Thirdly, it is argued that the power to make Orders, conferred by subsection 16k (2) of the Act, is wide enough to confer power to make an Order empowering someone else to do, in another way, what the Act, prima facie, enables the Order itself to do, namely, set maximum rates for the sea-carriage of meat. The power to make Orders is a power to make provision-

``with respect to any matter relating to or incidental to [sea-carriage, and] without limiting the generality of [that] [to] make provision for and in relation to . . . the charges payable for [sea-carriage]''.

It is argued that since the power to make provision ``with respect to'' a specific subject matter is as wide a legislative power as can be created (per Latham C.J. in Bank of N.S.W. v Commonwealth, (1948) 76 C.L.R. 1 at 186) (quare: primary legislative, not delegated legislative power;) and since the compound proposition ``with respect to'' does not differ in effect from the corresponding phrase ``in relation to'' (per Windeyer J. in Victoria v Commonwealth (1970-71) 122 C.L.R. 353 at 399) the language of subsection 16k (2) is therefore, wide enough to authorise the delegation to an unsupervised executive organ of the legislative power to amend the Orders.

If, through the juxtaposition of these dicta, the scope of the Order-making power in subsection 16k (2) is accurately stated, it might appear to authorise the making of a single Order empowering the Corporation henceforth to do all that it is necessary to do for the purposes of section 4 of the Act regarding sea-carriage, without the need for any further Orders to be made or presented to Parliament. The Committee does not accept that a court would adopt and apply the High Court dicta referred to above to such effect. Yet the Committee is being invited to accept that, with respect to one aspect of the Corporation's activities, namely prescribing sea-carriage rates, just such a delegation to an executive organ is lawful and acceptable. The Committee considers such an approach is fraught with potential uncertainty. It would tend to represent an unacceptable precedent that could inappropriately be followed in other delegated legislation and for this reason the Committee finds paragraph 3 (a) objectionable.

Fourthly, if the expression ``for and in relation to'' is to have the same meaning as ``with respect to'' in subsection 16k (2), such an interpretation appears, on first sight, to be not only at variance with the distinction drawn between elements of these phrases in Paul v Munday (1976) 9 A.L.R. 245, at 251 and 259, but also contrary to the usual presumption that different words in a single provision will be taken to have different meanings. Such an interpretation would also tend to render otiose the expression in subsection 16k (2) ``and without limiting the generality of the foregoing'' since, at least in the matter of fixing sea-carriage charges, the specific power would be taken to be exactly coextensive with the general power. The Committee considers that such contradictions tend to make the interpretation advanced by the Corporation a possibly unreliable one and for this reason also the Committee finds paragraph 3 (a) objectionable.

Finally, if the Corporation's argument is correct, the power to set rates by gazette notice is a power which might be exercised in a qualitatively different way to the way in which the power has been exercised in the Schedule of the Orders. It would appear to be possible for gazette notices to set different rates for different kinds of sea-carriage, both for individual exporters or for particular groups of exporters. There is, therefore, potential for unfairness or merely inappropriate administration of the Corporation's regulatory controls. The Committee does not, of course, suggest that this would happen, only that, under the paragraph as it currently stands, it could happen. Since there would be no right of appeal on the merits against such theoretically discriminatory notices it is proper that as a matter of principle Parliament should at least have power to oversee rate changes. It is difficult to see how this could be achieved other than by removal of the power to issue notices and reliance on the general power to make disallowable Orders.

The Committee wishes to make it clear that it does not suggest that the legal advice the Corporation has received is, in any sense, less reliable than those views which the Committee is more inclined to accept. There is certainly in our scrutiny of the Orders no imputation whatsoever of any lack of care or good faith in the Corporation in setting about its task of regulating particular aspects of meat exportation. The Committee considers only that the legal position is not beyond doubt, that an exporter, if so minded, could at least mount a destabilising challenge to a notice at some time in the future, and that such a risk is not worth running if the legal arguments are nicely balanced. Given the fact that, where a protective notice of motion is to be withdrawn, the Committee's practice is to table in the Senate or incorporate in Hansard, all of its correspondence for the information of Senators and the community, the Committee considers that any such risk should be removed by a suitable amendment to paragraph 3 (a) of the Order.

In the final analysis, however, setting legal questions to one side, the Committee considers that in the circumstances of the current legislative scheme for the regulation of meat exports, changes to the Schedule should, as a matter of principle, be by some periodic instrument (for example, an Order) subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. (See also the approach adopted by the Committee in Thirty-ninth Report, P.P. 24/72 para. 10.)

The Committee would be grateful if the Corporation would reconsider its position on paragraph 3 (a) of the Order in the light of the foregoing points. We are concerned that the principle of parliamentary oversight be preserved without its application unduly affecting the work of the Corporation.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to be considered in conjunction with that Committee's reference on the feasibility of a national identification scheme:

(a) the taxation file numbering scheme announced by the Treasurer in the May Economic Statement, and, in particular, whether the scheme is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to eliminate fraud and abuses in the taxation and social security systems; and
(b) the possibility of that scheme developing into a de facto national identification card system with unacceptable impositions being made upon privacy and civil liberties.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) put:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate Selection Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee be established to inquire into and report upon the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 concerning the registration and amalgamation of organisations.
(2) That, in considering the provisions of the Bill, the Committee give particular consideration to:
(a) the desirability or otherwise of the restrictions on registration of organisations contained in the Bill; and
(b) whether the provisions on registration and amalgamation contained in the Bill will produce a union structure that reduces demarcation disputes and is conducive to improved industrial relations.
(3) That the Committee report to the Senate on the first sitting day in August 1988.

(4) (a) That the Committee consist of 6 Senators, 3 being Government Senators, and 3 being Senators who are not Government Senators nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(4) (b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee be determined by the Senate.
(5) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(7) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That the quorum of the Committee be 3 members.

(10) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(11) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of the Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

Because I have very limited time I deal only with the substantive part of the motion, which is for the establishment of a committee to inquire into and report upon the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 concerning the registration and amalgamation of organisations, asking that the committee give particular consideration to the desirability or otherwise of the restrictions on registration of the organisations contained in the Bill and whether the provisions on registration and amalgamation contained in the Bill will produce a union structure that reduces demarcation disputes and is conducive to improved industrial relations.

I seek this reference knowing that the Bill will not be dealt with in this session and, therefore, is not proposed to become law until next August or September or perhaps even later. In those circumstances the Senate has the opportunity, without in any way seeking to impede the passage of the legislation, to examine a very contentious area where I think there is a serious risk that the Government is taking the Australian industrial relations scene in the wrong direction. The area of the Bill to which I refer relates to the amalgamation of unions. It is quite clear that in this Bill the Government proposes to ease the passage of the proposal of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). I quote from the ACTU's recommendations in Australia Reconstructed:
That the Australian trade union movement should plan to have no more than 20 union organisations within two years.

The Government is proposing that an arbitrary limit should be placed upon the size of trade unions, that that limit should be 3,000, that a period of time should be allowed for amalgamations, but that, after a period of three years, the Commission will review the registration of all organisations with less than 3,000 members and will cancel their registration unless special circumstances exist. In other words, the Government is enthusiastically embracing in the legislation the proposition that large trade unions are to the benefit of Australia and that size, of itself, is a sufficient criterion for determining what is a suitable trade union structure.

I do not believe that one could get a more contentious proposal or one that would be more hotly debated, including by important elements of the trade union movement. Hundreds of unions are likely to be caught up in this forced amalgamation project. Certainly, on the views which have been put to me, their contention is that their forced amalgamation will lead to more industrial disputes, rather than fewer. Quite apart from the question of whether it will be conducive to having more industrial disputes or fewer, an important breach of the principle of freedom of association is involved which is a matter of great concern to the Opposition.

In the examination the Opposition has made of the desirable trade union structure for Australia, it seems to us that size is not the criterion that should determine the outcome of these matters. We can point to Germany, on the one hand, with a relatively small number of trade unions and a very good industrial record, and say, `That must prove something', but, on the other hand, we could look to Japan, with a very large number of trade unions, and say, `Perhaps that proves something'. It is not size which is important; what is important is the extent to which the trade union structure leads employers and employees to work together in a constructive and productive manner. We believe that any, even cursory, examination of the situation would suggest that size of itself is not the solution.

We examined the statistics of a recent batch of demarcation disputes, for example-demarcation disputes are cited as the main reason for wanting a smaller number of unions in the community-and found that out of 32 demarcation disputes, only one involved a union which would be caught up by these enforced amalgamation provisions. A small union was involved in only one of those 32 disputes. Small unions have approached me on this matter. For example, members of a union composed of ambulance drivers told us of their experience. They had been members of a very large union involving a great range of workers and had found themselves continuously embroiled in industrial disputes and, indeed, were being used by that larger union as a form of industrial battering ram.

Since that group of workers have been able to establish their own union they have been able to look after their own interests, and have not found it necessary to engage in industrial disputation. I cite that as but one example of the sort of situation which should be examined by this Parliament before we put into the hands of the ACTU and the Government the capacity to enforce the amalgamation of unions and to produce size for the sake of size.

Our intention in this matter is to produce the best possible industrial relations climate, which means a climate in which people will work together, rather than against each other. If one consults trade unions, academics, employer organisations, employers, individual unionists and members of the work force who are not unionists one will find in all of those areas a strong resistance to the enforced production of large unions to which workers, in turn, will be forced to belong.

We believe-as I say, on the grounds of efficiency, of reducing industrial disputation and having a more productive economy as well as on the defence of individuals' rights to associate together without being told by the Arbitration Commission or by large trade unions that they are not free to do so-that on all of those grounds there are issues that warrant careful examination. These points have been put to the Australian Democrats and the matter could not be put simply formally, Mr President, because as I understand the position, they are not prepared to support this reference. I think that is a matter for very great regret because I do not believe that it is possible for anyone in any honesty to deny that this is a most contentious issue.

I believe that if, for example, one talks to a range of unions one will get widely differing assessments as to the worth or otherwise of these proposals. I believe that here is an opportunity for the Parliament, when we return for the Budget session, to make an informed decision on what is a very complex issue. The likelihood is that instead we will have a debate of the sort which occurs after the second reading, at the committee stage, which will be much more an exercise in bringing together the anecdotal evidence and experience of individual senators which will have been brought together within the respective parties to adopt a fixed position.

I had always understood that it was the Australian Democrats' view that it was a worthwhile thing to examine these matters in committee where there is a totally different opportunity to hear, not just the views of the politicians, but also the views of the people who will be affected by this legislation. I remind the Senate that every time the Senate has taken an opportunity to avail itself of a careful committee examination of legislation, we have come forward with recommendations, usually on a unanimous or bipartisan or tripartisan basis, for changes to the legislation which it has been widely agreed will improve it. We have an opportunity here in approaching a system which is fundamental to economic recovery in Australia. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, said only late last week that one of the great remaining challenges for the Government in his view was the issue of the labour market. There is no dispute amongst any economic observers that our labour market is the critical impediment to getting the sort of productivity growth and the economic recovery which will enable Australians to resume a path of rising living standards.

It is fundamentally important to the future health of our economy and I believe, Mr President, it is also fundamentally important to the sort of society that we have in the future. The fact of the matter is that once again we see the trade union movement, and indeed the Government, opting for a course which ignores the views of individual employees in this country and ignores the wishes of a large number of trade unionists who believe that they are far better off to be involved in a trade union, which is not necessarily large but which is genuinely dedicated to the interests of the group, than having a wider agenda which in many cases will not be a pro-community agenda but a pro-union agenda.

Mr President, making speeches in this place when a decision has been made is always an exercise about which one might ask, `What is the point?'. The point about this speech is that it is important that the people of Australia know, that the employers of Australia know and the unions of Australia know that in the Opposition's case we believe there is very good reason to provide unions, employers and the public with an opportunity to tell the Parliament what the industrial relations reality out there is. It is a very good opportunity to tell the Parliament what sort of pattern of trade unions is likely to produce a more cooperative and productive trade union in this country. And this is an opportunity which should be taken now; it would not delay the Government's legislation in any time sense and therefore, Mr President, there is absolutely nothing to be lost. I commend the motion to the Senate and hope that, even at this late hour, it might obtain majority support.

Senator Harradine-In speaking to the motion that the Leader of the Opposition--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as will prevent Senator Harradine making a statement relating to the proposed select committee.

In moving that motion, I believe it totally unfair for the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, to deny me leave to make a very brief statement about a notice of motion which appeared on the Notice Paper, as I understand it, only this morning. It is about a matter which is very dear to my heart. I have had a lifetime of interest in this question of the trade union movement. Unless this motion of mine to suspend Standing Orders is adopted, I will not be able to speak on Senator Chaney's motion. I remind the Senate that I was elected as the Chairman of the Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation which was established by this Senate. It was formed to consider questions arising from the Viner proposals in the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill which, in fact, was submitted to the Parliament by the Fraser Government. It also had provisions relating to the amalgamation of unions. We received a large number of submissions from trade unions on that particular occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. As I understand the Standing Orders, Senator Harradine can speak only as to the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended in order to allow him to speak to the substantive issue. He cannot canvass the substantive issue.
—Order! I remind Senator Harradine of the point raised by Senator Evans.
—Thank you, Mr President. Unless I am granted leave --

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —On the understanding that Senator Harradine wishes to speak for no more than five minutes on the substantive question, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak for 7 1/2 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), but I do so from a different angle, certainly as to some of the last comments that Senator Chaney made about the Industrial Relations Bill as a framework for the trade union movement rather than for the people. I submit to the chamber that it is necessary to give organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act the opportunity to present their views to this chamber. After all, that is what the committee system is for-to receive submissions, to hear evidence, to distil that evidence and to make a report to Parliament. Many honourable senators have wide-ranging interests. Many of them are not familiar with the rights and responsibilities of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

SPEECH.PARA: If a select committee on the Industrial Relations Bill is established by this chamber, those organisations will be able to make submissions. They will be able to be heard. The select committee will be able to distil that evidence and present it in readable, precis form. That will be important in preserving the rights of industrial organisations. Let us face it, the Industrial Relations Bill goes to the heart of the system of registration of organisations in this country.

There are many old registered organisations which have less than 3,000 members, for example. Are we, at the stroke of the pen-without giving them the opportunity to be heard-to obliterate them? What is our commitment to the International Labour Organisation declaration on freedom of association? These workers have gathered themselves together over many years into their registered organisation, freely associated. Now, in one stroke of the pen, the amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are likely to abolish those organisations without giving the membership of those organisations the right to have their representations heard in this chamber. That is the first point.

The second point is: on what basis are amalgamations to be effected? Are they to be on an industry basis? Are they to be on a craft basis? Are they to be on an enterprise basis? Is there to be one union, for example, for the vehicle industry? Is that union to be the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia or are other unions to be maintained? I suggest that there would be a great fight on if that were to be the case, but it is a possibility under the new legislation.

I would like to hear-we heard some of this evidence from the unions when I was Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation-what the tradesmen's unions think. I would like to hear from the Electrical Trades Union of Australia (ETU), for example, as to what it thinks of the possible establishment of industry unions such as one union for the vehicle industry, or for the building industry. The Electrical Trades Union is a tradesmen's union. It has a long history. Are its members to be confined to the electricity generating and distributing industry? These are the sorts of detailed questions which are important, not only for the organisations themselves but also, I suggest, for the people as a whole.

It is all very well to say that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is pushing for a certain line. The ACTU is not a registered industrial organisation. It is not registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We are taking notice of what the ACTU says, or what the employers say, but are we taking notice of what the registered industrial organisations are saying? Are not the individual members of those organisations, are not their officials, entitled to have some say before they are obliterated, before they are amalgamated-forcibly-into some other organisation?

We are talking about coercion. We are not talking about freedom of association. We are talking about a Bill which says, `You are a member of the ETU. Your section of that organisation has to resign and go over to another union'. Is that freedom of association? Are we not transgressing the rights of individual union members to that freedom of association by ignoring the valid suggestion that they should be given the opportunity to be heard?

What does this motion say? It calls for a select committee to be established to inquire into and report upon the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill concerning the registration and amalgamation of organisations, and for the committee in considering the provisions of the Bill to give particular consideration to a number of things. I can see no problem about a committee giving consideration to those matters, I simply appeal to the Senate to consider these questions carefully, to recognise that if they defeat this opportunity for persons to be heard who are going to be vitally affected by this measure in respect of their rights to freedom of association, then this chamber is denying the right of freedom and not upholding the right of freedom of association.

Mr Deputy President, I asked for 7 1/2 minutes; 7 1/2 minutes is up. I hope that this proposition will be carried. I am sorry that it has come on so late. I did not know that it was coming on. Senator Chaney, of course, does not consult me about these matters. I am sorry to hear that the Australian Democrats, apparently, have found, in a very short time, that they are not able to uphold the right of freedom of association.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Sanders) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act for preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons by regulating the exportation of nuclear material and certain associated items from Australia.
Motion (by Senator Sanders) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill 1988 is designed for the Australian Labor Government. The Government is desperate to get foreign currency from uranium sales, but at the same time is under pressure to help prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. This Bill is a compromise between those aims, which is much more defensible and effective than the current policy.

This Bill does not reflect the policy of the Australian Democrats; we remain strongly opposed to the mining and export of uranium, full stop. Unlike the Government and the Opposition, we are opposed to nuclear power. More catastrophic nuclear accidents are inevitable, the problem of disposing of nuclear wastes has not been solved, and renewable energy sources are now economically competitive and ready to go.

Instead, this Bill implements the spirit of the Australian Labor Party's policy on uranium exports. If the Labor Party and the Hawke Government are serious about making sure that Australian uranium exports don't drive the nuclear arms race, then they must at least enact the terms of this Bill.

I emphasise the words `at least'-the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill 1988 sets out the minimum requirements of effective non-proliferation legislation. It has several weaknesses. It is not good enough, but it is better than the discredited safeguards system we now have.

The Bill is an attempt to make sure that Australian uranium and nuclear technology does not go to any country which is producing nuclear weapons-grade material-plutonium and highly-enriched uranium-or which has nuclear trade links with countries that are producing such material.
Specifically, the Bill allows either House of Parliament to exclude a country from receiving Australian uranium and nuclear technology if that country:
is not a member of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT); or
has not signed and ratified, or has withdrawn from, a bilateral safeguards agreement with Australia; or
does not accept safeguards on all its nuclear facilities; or
is planning or continuing to test or build nuclear explosive devices; or
is planning or continuing to produce or obtain weapons-grade or near weapons-grade material (reprocessed plutonium, or uranium enriched to 20% or more of the isotope U-235 or U-233); or
is planning or continuing to use or export such material; or
has not agreed not to prohibit the changing of the origin (including through origin-swaps) of shipments of nuclear material; or
does not prohibit the export of nuclear materials or technology to any country which is in violation of any of these conditions; or
does not prohibit uranium flag-swaps with any country which is in violation of any of these conditions.

If a motion to exclude a country from receiving Australian uranium is not dealt with within 15 sitting days, the country automatically becomes excluded. If a country which was once eligible to buy Australian uranium is later excluded by either House, any export contract with that country is suspended.
The approval of both Houses of Parliament is needed to remove a country from the excluded list, and before the export of nuclear material or technology to an eligible country can take place.

The reason I have left these decisions to Parliament, rather than to the relevant Minister, is that the final judges of any Ministerial decision would be the courts. I am advised that the courts would find it difficult, if not impossible to prove that any country had breached the conditions laid out in the Bill, thus rendering it toothless. Parliament is better equipped to make such decisions.

The Bill also requires that potential uranium customers must first agree to seek approval from the Australian Government for any flag swaps involving Australian uranium. It requires the Minister to report all flag-swaps annually to Parliament.

This Bill puts the uranium debate squarely before the elected Parliament of Australia. Public concern about nuclear weapons is now very high, higher than it has ever been. It is no longer good enough for decisions about Australia's nuclear non-proliferation policy to be left to ALP National Conferences and to Cabinet. It is time Parliament had a say.

Even before its introduction, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill has won substantial support. It has already received in principle endorsements from Jean Alexander (NSW), the Big Scrub Environmental Centre (Lismore, NSW), Diamond Valley People for Nuclear Disarmament, William Heath (SA), Janet and Nelson Kenny (NSW), People for Nuclear Disarmament (Victoria), Dr Peter Springell (Qld), Ian Thomas (Lecturer, Graduate School of Environmental Science, Monash University), Trees and People (Victoria), Union of Australian Women (Victoria), the Uniting Church Division of Social Justice (Victoria), the Victorian Baptist Social Justice Group: Ploughshares Taskforce, Jan de Voogd (NSW) and Michael Walsh (SA). Dr Anne-Marie Grisogono of Flinders University (SA) urged Australians to give careful consideration to the Bill in a recent ABC News Commentary.
Many other groups are considering endorsement, and I expect the list to grow now that the Bill has been introduced.

Of course, Australia already has a Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act, courtesy of the Hawke Government. But this Act only applies to the safeguarding of nuclear material and technology within Australia, where the risks of nuclear proliferation is relatively low. It is ironic that there are no laws governing the export of Australian uranium, which is actually contributing to the spread of nuclear weapons.

The reason is obvious. The internal legislation gives the impression that the Government is doing something about nuclear proliferation, while giving Cabinet a free hand over uranium exports. The Government's reversal of the ban on uranium sales to France was a classic example of how uranium policy can be changed at whim by executive decree.
There is an urgent need to enact Australia's non-proliferation commitments in law, so they cannot be weakened without Parliament's consent.

Some people are sure to argue that this Bill is trying to regulate the activities of other countries through domestic legislation. This is of course nonsense. This Bill can't force any other country to do anything. It only requires them to meet certain conditions if they want our uranium. Our current safeguards agreements are based on the same principle. This Bill simply goes further.

I should point out that the United States has had a Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act since 1978, which allows the President or Congress to cut off uranium exports to countries which violate their non-proliferation commitments. The US Act is not as tough as this one, but the principle is the same.
There are some aspects of the Bill which require further explanation.

Firstly, on the issue of origin-swapping. Documents leaked from the Euratom Supply Agency and passed to me clearly show that private companies are swapping the certificates of origin on different batches of uranium in order to circumvent embargoes on South African and Namibian uranium. Apparently the US Department of Energy has cooperated in some origin-swaps, and Euratom itself has no power to stop them. Because origin-swaps don't involve the swapping of safeguard obligations, they are purely a commercial matter-privatised flag-swapping, in other words.
In other cases, the origin of uranium is being changed to that of the last country in which it was processed. So Australian uranium enriched in France can then become French uranium.

Documents leaked from the scandal-ridden German company Nukem show that Nukem, which had a batch of South African yellowcake, exchanged the origin on that batch with the Niger origin on some yellowcake owned by Nufcor, also a German firm. Nukem's yellowcake, which had been mined in South Africa but was now labelled `Niger', was sent to the USSR for enrichment, and then to Finland to be made into fuel rods for nuclear reactors. Neither Finland nor the USSR would have accepted the uranium from Nukem with its original South African origin certificate.
Origin-swapping and origin changing has no redeeming features. Australian uranium customers must agree to ban those activities if they are to receive our uranium.

The only form of swap which is allowable under the Bill is a conventional flag-swap, where the ownership of two batches of uranium changes hands, and safeguards and origin together are swapped between the batches. This form of flag-swap can be used to reduce the transport of nuclear material, and therefore reduces the risk of accident or theft involving that material.
The form of swap which is legal under the Bill-between non-excluded countries only-is as follows. Before the exchange:
Owner X has Batch 1 with safeguards code S and origin A, while owner Y has Batch 2 with safeguards code P and origin B;
whereas after the exchange:
Owner X has Batch 2 with safeguards code S and origin A, while owner Y has Batch 1 with safeguards code P and origin B.

Even this form of swap can be abused to weaken safeguards. For example, Germany's Nukem wanted to enrich some Australian uranium to weapons-grade, but knew that the Australian Government would not allow it. So the Australian safeguards on Nukem's uranium were traded with American safeguards on some unenrichable uranium scraps, owned by the German electricity utility RWE. Our safeguards wound up on a batch of American scraps, and our uranium, with its less strict American safeguards, was sent away for enrichment to weapons-grade.

Flag-swapping allows Australian safeguards obligations to be detached from a batch of Australian uranium and shuffled off to some other convenient uranium batch so that they won't hinder the production of bomb fuel. This is why swapping is only allowed between countries which meet the conditions of this Bill. That way, no country which poses a proliferation risk can obtain Australian uranium through flag-swapping.
So what is the reasoning behind the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill?
The problem the Bill addresses is that Australian uranium goes into one big world pool of uranium, which is used for both military and civilian purposes.

The Government has acknowledged that Australian uranium is mixed in with uranium from other sources at the beginning of the nuclear fuel cycle, and thereafter becomes untraceable. The batches of `Australian' uranium which are tracked through the fuel cycle are only equivalent quantities to the batches mined in Australia. They do not contain the same atoms.

This Bill accepts this so-called equivalence principle. It accepts that Australian uranium goes into a pool. But none of the uranium in that pool will be available for use in bombs, because none of it can be used to produce bomb fuel.

Our current safeguards agreements already place restrictions on the enrichment and reprocessing of Australian origin nuclear material. But our safeguards are rendered almost useless because uranium mined in other countries doesn't carry the same restrictions. So France, Britain, and the United States are happy to accept Australian uranium which can't be turned into bomb fuel, because they have plentiful sources of uranium which can. France, for example, gets unsafeguarded uranium from Niger, Namibia-illegally-and from its own mines; easily enough to supply its bomb program.

At present, Australian uranium earmarked for electricity production liberates uranium from other sources for use in bombs. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill will help ensure that this does not happen, because none of the countries receiving our uranium will be making bombs, or even bomb-grade fuel. Australian uranium will be added to a pool of uranium which can only be used for civilian purposes.

It is often argued that Australian uranium shuts out suppliers with less strict safeguards, and thereby prevents the spread of nuclear weapons. On the contrary, our uranium offers importing countries more choices; if our safeguards are too restrictive for a particular customer, that customer can easily go elsewhere. Our uranium helps to create a buyer's market in which suppliers have little leverage over the way their uranium is used. This Bill attempts to give Australia more leverage in the medium term by creating a seller's market, as I'll explain later.

Uranium flag-swapping has helped to degrade our safeguards even further, by creating a safeguards market in which different safeguards obligations are traded to minimise their restrictive effect on nuclear activities.

The idea that civilian and military uses of uranium are completely separate is often peddled by the nuclear industry's apologists and profiteers. It has recently been peddled by Primary Industries and Energy Minister John Kerin. It is, of course, a myth.

France has at least 16, perhaps 20, nuclear facilities with a dual military/civilian function. These include enrichment and reprocessing plants, as well as nuclear reactors. One of these, the Tricastin uranium enrichment plant, has done low- and medium-level enrichment for the Pierreatte enrichment plant, which produces weapons-grade uranium for French bombs. The Government is on record as saying that Australian uranium passes through Tricastin, and claims that Tricastin is used only for civilian purposes.

The Government has misled Parliament on this last point, and knows it, but refuses to admit it publicly. The fact is that Australian uranium is likely to have gone into French bombs via Tricastin then Pierrelatte.

Having said that, this Bill does not prevent Australian uranium from being enriched at the Tricastin plant, so long as the equivalent quantity of Australian uranium which comes out does not get used in French reactors, and therefore does not increase the amount of uranium available to France for any purpose.

In the Soviet Union, where some Australian uranium is enriched, the civilian and military fuel cycles are not kept separate, so far as we know. In Britain, plutonium from the `civil' power program has been used in British nuclear weapons. Some has been sent to the United States under the US/UK Mutual Defense Agreement, and now forms part of the United States military plutonium stockpile. Britain and the US are both importers of Australian uranium.

Israel has built up to 200 nuclear weapons using `civilian' nuclear technology supplied by France. India exploded a nuclear weapon in 1974 using `peaceful' technology supplied by Canada. In doing so, India also exploded the myth of the peaceful atom.

Pakistan is ready to build bombs using technology stolen and imported from the West. South Africa has already done so, and many other countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Iran, Iraq, and Libya would dearly like to.

The Bill is also based on the belief that banning the production of weapons-grade material is an important arms control measure, which will not substantially hinder civilian nuclear power programs. As I have explained, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Exports) Bill does not allow uranium exports to any country which is making nuclear weapons-grade material.

It should be obvious that if we are going to ban outright the production of nuclear weapons at some time in the future, the best way to do this is to destroy existing nuclear weapons, and ban the production of fuel from which nuclear weapons can be made. Of all the necessary components of a bomb, the fuel is easiest to ban, because it has no important non-military uses, and because there is relatively little of it in the world at present.

A ban on the production of weapons-grade nuclear material would be similar to the proposed Chemical Weapons Convention (the CWC), which bans the production of certain chemicals which can be used in chemical weapons. It could be verified using factory inspections, similar to the procedures for verifying the CWC. If the International Atomic Energy Agency was beefed up, and was released from having to promote nuclear energy, it might be able to do the job.
Nuclear weapons-grade material is produced in two main ways; by reprocessing spent fuel rods to obtain plutonium, or by the high-enriching of uranium (to greater than 90% of the isotope U-235).

The major uses of plutonium and high-enriched uranium are military: plutonium is used to make most weapons, while high-enriched uranium is used to make some weapons and is used as a fuel in the reactors of nuclear-powered submarines.

Plutonium reprocessed from spent fuel rods is also added to uranium to fuel mixed-oxide civilian power reactors in Japan, France and some other Western European countries. But according to well-credentialled American scientists-Harold Feivcson, Professor Frank von Hippel and David Albright-writing in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists in March 1986, mixed oxide fuels are not economic, because of the low cost of uranium and the high cost of reprocessing.

In fact, the United States, Canada and Sweden have forgone reprocessing. Not only is it uneconomic, it does little to alleviate the disposal problems posed by high-level radioactive waste, contrary to earlier scientific opinion. According to the American scientists, ``the nuclear industry now generally agrees that the storage and final disposal of spent fuel are not intrinsically more difficult than disposal of the high-level wastes created by reprocessing the fuel''.

Furthermore, the quantities of plutonium produced by power reactors are too small to significantly extend the life of the world's uranium reserves. Plutonium-producing fast breeder reactors, by contrast, are designed to greatly extend the life of world uranium reserves, and were once seen as the guarantors of the world's energy future. In 1976, Andre Giraud, the French Defence Minister who was then head of the French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) predicted that 540 fast breeders would have been built by the year 2000, and 2766 by the year 2025.

These days, fast breeder programs have ground to a virtual standstill. Fast breeders are uniquely dangerous. They are literally able to explode like a nuclear bomb. Because they use and produce large quantities of the deadly plutonium, they pose a severe pollution risk. The reprocessing technologies needed to extract plutonium from the reactor core have not been developed on a commercial scale, because of environmental and economic problems. Furthermore, an energy system based on fast breeders would require the transport of vast quantities of plutonium (the `plutonium economy'), which would have to be heavily guarded, leading to an erosion in civil liberties.

France's only commercial-scale fast breeder has been shut down for a year with a sodium leak, while Germany's experimental fast breeder at Kalkar has been refused an operating licence. A handful of other fast breeders are in operation, but it is now generally agreed that fast breeders have little role to play in energy production. A three-year French study done for the 1986 World Energy Conference predicted that fast breeders would extend the life of the world's uranium reserves by only 17 years.
In short, banning the reprocessing of nuclear wastes to produce plutonium would not have a significant effect on civilian energy programs.

This also applies to the production of high-enriched uranium. High-enriched uranium has only one civilian use, which is as a fuel for some research reactors, such as the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. But the US Department of Energy wants to convert research reactors from using high-enriched uranium to using uranium enriched to 20% of the isotope U-235. Scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory have developed a high-density fuel using 20% enriched uranium as part of the DOE's Reduced Enrichment in Research and Test Reactors (RERTR) program. The RERTR program has the same purpose as this Bill-to make it much harder to divert nuclear weapons-grade material for use in bombs, by limiting the production of that material.

The importance of banning the production of bomb-grade fuel has been underscored by recent revelations. One is that, in 1986, there was a huge discrepancy between the amount of nuclear material on the International Atomic Energy Agency's books, and the amount of actual material the Agency found at nuclear plants around the world. To be precise, the IAEA failed to account for fissile material sufficient to make about 70 bombs.

This does not mean that all that material was stolen or diverted to weapons. What it does mean is that if some of that material has been stolen or diverted, then the IAEA has no way of knowing, because its book records are not nearly accurate enough.

This revelation was made by the German magazine `Der Spiegel'. I want to say a few words in defence of `Der Spiegel'. During the uranium flag-swaps controversy, Senator Cook claimed that `Der Spiegel' was a `tits and bums' magazine which had run the fake `Hitler diaries', and therefore could not be given any credence.
In fact, Senator Cook got `Der Spiegel' confused with `Stern', which did run the Hitler diaries and does have a poor reputation. `Der Spiegel', by contrast, is a reputable journal.

It seems that some plutonium has been diverted from under the IAEA's nose, according to a documentary called `The Plutonium Black Market', which was made by 20/20 Vision and screened on Britain's Channel Four in 1987. It has also screened on US cable television, and in New Zealand. ABC-TV's `Four Corners' is considering doing a story based in part on this documentary.

`The Plutonium Black Market' claims that plutonium and high-enriched uranium has been stolen from civilian plants in Europe and auctioned in Sudan. The bidders have included Israel, Libya, South Africa, Argentina, Brazil, Iraq, Iran, Syria, Pakistan, India and the PLO-a rogue's gallery of proliferation risks if ever there was one.

According to a former US Government agent who posed as a merchant in this black market, 12 kilograms of plutonium were offered for sale in Khartoum in 1980. South Africa offered $5 million per kilo for it, but was outbid by Iraq. Other quantities have been offered at other times. The Sudanese Prime Minister, Mr al Mahdj, confirmed the existence of the black market in his country, and said that Sudanese police had seized a contraband shipment of enriched uranium in August of last year. It had been found in the house of a businessman.

It seems that so-called `civilian' reprocessing plants such as Mol in Belgium, Sellafield in Britain and Cap la Hague in France are leaking plutonium like sieves, which is finding its way into the hands of would-be nuclear powers. It could also find its way into the hands of terrorists.

The political committee of the North Atlantic Assembly, which is NATO's parliament, said in a 1987 report that it `cannot rule out the possibility of serious nuclear terrorism in our lifetime'. This view was endorsed by a 1987 Pentagon report which said that terrorists could easily hijack plutonium from commercial reprocessing facilities.

The American scientists Feiveson, von Hippel and Albright recommend that the production of plutonium and high-enriched uranium be banned, and that existing stocks of those materials be placed under international control. The Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of this Parliament also recommended in 1986 that the production of weapons-grade material be banned. Such a ban is not a new proposal, and is not even a radical proposal. It is not an anti-nuclear power proposal. It is a nuclear non-proliferation measure which is at the heart of this Bill.
Finally, what would be the effect of the Bill, if it were to become law?

It would ban uranium sales to most of Australia's current uranium customers, with the exception, subject to certain agreements, of Finland and maybe Sweden. Over the space of ten to fifteen years, this is likely to cause the uranium supply market to shrink, because Australia is sitting on thirty percent of the world's reserves, which are likely to be exhausted some time next century if the nuclear power industry continues.

As alternative sources of uranium dried up, countries would be forced to make a choice: either produce nuclear bomb fuel and freeze in the dark, or forgo making bomb fuel in order to get Australian uranium for electricity production. Any sensible country would choose the latter option. The former would be politically stupid.

This Bill would give Australia significant leverage with which to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. This leverage would not be immediate. Australia would have to forgo revenue from uranium sales to excluded countries until they cleaned up their acts. But if the goal of uranium mining is preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, as the Government claims it is, then this Bill is an essential measure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, be established to examine and report upon the Government's proposals for the re-organisation of the administration of Aboriginal affairs by the formation of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), including:
(a) the terms of those proposals and the clauses of any legislation proposed for the establishment of ATSIC;
(b) the effectiveness of the process of consultation undertaken by the Government with respect to the ATSIC proposal;
(c) the proposal of the Aboriginal Development Commission for ``an alternative strategy of Aboriginal self-management'';
(d) the Government's treatment of the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Commissioners, including the dismissal of 8 of the Commissioners.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate within 6 months of the publication of legislation or draft legislation.
(3) That the Committee consist of 6 Senators, as follows:
(a) 3 to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(4) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(6) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(8) That the quorum of the Committee be 3 members.

(9) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(10) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(11) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(12) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution; and
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
I seek leave to make a statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking briefly to the motion, this matter arises from the urgency motion which was very properly presented in this place on 24 May by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Australian Democrats. That motion was very critical of the need for an urgent appraisal of matters relating to Aboriginal administration and, of course, the Government's proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The effectiveness of the Government's consultation was very seriously questioned in that urgency debate and many of the issues that were raised certainly highlighted the need for very adequate consultation with Aboriginal communities, particularly once the draft legislation or the legislation has been presented to the Parliament. It is most important that the accountability and scrutiny of any future Aboriginal administration be properly looked at and a select committee is a very appropriate way of doing that. I am pleased that the Democrats have given their support for the establishment of such a select committee which will go a long way to advancing issues relating to self-management and self-determination for Aboriginals in Australia. I commend the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Senator Tambling has pointed out, his motion follows quite logically and naturally from the urgency motion which was debated in the Senate last week. It represents a balancing between the desirability on the part of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to get the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (Atsic) or something approaching his ATSIC proposal up as quickly as possible and the need adequately to survey the precise legislation-which, as yet, nobody has seen-to allow Aboriginal groups to look at that legislation and ensure that it will properly fulfil their needs. The paragraph in the motion which relates to the timing of the report of the proposed Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs matches exactly the terms of the motion which was before the Senate last week. Therefore, the Australian Democrats have great pleasure in supporting Senator Tambling's motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
