TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion which is on the Notice Paper in my name, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Order 407b be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

Mr President, the Government has within the last half hour or so advised the Opposition that it is proposing to guillotine the balance of what the Government regards as its essential program and it has the support of the Australian Democrats in that move. I suppose that a keen student of even recent political history would regard that as an impossibility. Of course, the views of the Australian Democrats on these matters are very clear. They ran on a platform of never supporting gags and guillotines. Indeed, I think Senator Colin Mason, who is no longer with us, actually filled in a declaration before he entered the Parliament that he would not indulge in such behaviour.

In any event, notwithstanding the public expressions from the Australian Democrats that they will not support the limitation of debate, last night, and again today apparently, they committed themselves to a substantial limitation of debate on a major series of Bills. It is not for us to keep the Democrats honest. I suppose one might say that some sort of mini-Democrat Party needs to be formed, just to keep those who are here honest, to fulfil ex-Senator Chipp's desire to improve the operation of the system and, as Senator Chipp used to say, `To keep the bastards honest'. But that is a cry from the past. I do not intend to spend the limited time we have left for debate under the terms of the proposed guillotine discussing that matter.

The Opposition strongly opposes this guillotine and believes that it is neither necessary nor reasonable. There is certainly no basis for the Democrats welshing on their traditional stance on these matters. This session has involved, to an extraordinary degree, the Government introducing matters which required attention. A succession of statements, for example, have used up a great deal of parliamentary time. To those who might think that a delay has been imposed by the Opposition, I can only say that, as recently as a couple of weeks ago, there was certainly no suggestion in any of the discussions I had with Senator Evans, the Manager of Government Business, that there had been any delay.

Of the business conducted in the Senate from February to May of this year, that is, during the current session up to the time I was able to get statistics, about 54.2 per cent of the time had been spent on Government business-on legislation, ministerial statements, ministerial arrangements, Government-initiated motions, and so on-as against 56 per cent of the Budget session of last year, when it was certainly not found necessary to introduce such drastic proposals. Why is that? The Government has always had an impossible program. Those of us who have met frequently during the session with Senator Evans, who has given us forecasts of the Government's requirements, would know that at each of those meetings I have made the point that the Government has set a program which was not possible to achieve by any proper legislative means.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have taken off 15 or 20 Bills.

—The Minister makes the point that he has taken off some Bills, but let us consider the matters we are dealing with. We have referendum Bills, which came to the Senate only recently and which could not be dealt with until the Government had introduced them. Some time ago the Government was going to introduce amendments to them, but the Bills have got to the Senate and been dealt with only last week and this week. It was beyond the capacity of the Opposition to have a debate on them any earlier in the session.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government said last week, for example, in its programming, `We will finish all these Bills on Monday'. I remind the Government, which believes that we should perhaps have finished the constitutional Bills on Monday, that on Monday it told us that it had found a defect in the Bills and that it was going to have to amend the so-called fair elections Bill. So the Government has scarcely put itself in a position to complete debate, even if the Opposition had not had important points to make on the Bills which were still to be dealt with.

In these closing weeks of the sitting, the Government has introduced constitutional amendments although we had not seen the Bills prior to introduction. The Government introduced in the House of Representatives late last week a May statement, which required eight new Bills to be introduced in the Parliament and to pass through the Senate as part of this guillotine. Those Bills were seen by the Opposition for the first time when they were introduced at the time of the May statement, last Wednesday evening, and the Government forced them through the House of Representatives in less than 24 hours. That is the sort of legislative program the Government is imposing on the Senate. It is saying that these Bills, which have been before the Opposition for less than a week and which have not, therefore, even had the opportunity to go through the normal party processes of shadow Cabinet and party room discussion, are part of the essential legislation which is to be considered.

It was the considered view of the Opposition that it was necessary to pass those Bills through the Parliament in this session because many of them involve expenditure changes and, consistent with the extraordinary degree of maintenance of principle that we have adopted with respect to the Government's Budget legislation, we were proposing to ensure that those May statement Bills were passed through the Senate during the course of this week. But that means that under the Government's program the Senate is required to deal with the May statement Bills in something less than four hours. That means dealing with 10 May statement Bills in something less than four hours.

We then get a series of very brief times-an hour, an hour and a half and 30 minutes in some cases-to be allowed for a whole series of Bills, some of which are Bills of very great importance and complexity. For example, in the case of one of the Bills we are called upon to deal with in an hour and a half-the Bill relating to employment, education and training-the Opposition has 17 amendments and I am told that the Australian Democrats have 28 amendments. That is a total of 45 amendments on a Bill on which we have been allowed an hour and a half for debate.

Last night I made the point about the contempt for the legislative process, and I can only say that we could get no clearer demonstration that there is to be no proper opportunity for parliamentary scrutiny of that measure when, in the view of the Opposition, 17 amendments are required and, in the view of the Australian Democrats, 28 amendments are required; yet we are to have one and a half hours for debate. That is something like two minutes per amendment if we have no second reading debate. Quite clearly, that is an absurdity and it is reducing the procedures of this chamber to a farce.

We have the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill. I would have thought that that was a Bill that even the public servants advising this Government might have thought warranted a little serious attention. That Bill involves removing the vested, existing compensation rights of some thousands of public servants-I think some 8,000 public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine thousand.

—Nine thousand public servants are involved. It involves removing the right of access to the common law. Access to the common law is a very untidy right for employers because it means that, if an employer is negligent and, as a result of the employer's negligence, the employee is injured, the employee is limited to statutory compensation and cannot recover his true losses if those losses exceed the statutory compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has made it clear that we wish to amend that legislation to protect the existing rights of public servants. We accept that there is a need for amendments to the compensation legislation; but we do not believe that that need requires us to impose, effectively, retrospective provisions on people who have already suffered injury or disability in the course of their service for the Commonwealth. For the debate on that Bill we have one and a half hours, and that requires us to put quite significant propositions about the retention of common law rights, which I am sure the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, will agree are very contentious matters.

There are very strong arguments, some of which are raised, some would say, out of the self-interest of lawyers, and others, some would say, out of the civil liberties concerns. In fact, I think the need for a responsible community requires that we maintain some liability for negligence and so on. They are the sorts of issues which remain to be dealt with, and we have, for that Bill, one and a half hours. If one looks at the 9,000 public servants who will be directly involved by the retrospectivity, one could say that we have 0.1 of a minute for the concerns of each of them. That is a suitable measure of the concern that the Government has about this major matter.

We have some quite important tariff legislation which affects the responsibilities of the Industries Assistance Commission and the role of the Government and the IAC with respect to the Government and the variation of tariffs. We have matters touching on superannuation, research and development, and so on.

I simply want to make the point-I do not wish again to take up too much of the limited time we now have left under this motion-that we have consistently said that the Government's program was structured in a way which made it inevitable that, in this last period of sittings, there would not be an adequate opportunity to give these matters proper parliamentary consideration. That, I think, is the central concern that we have. If the Australian Democrats support this guillotine, the effect will be simply to add perhaps half a dozen of those Bills to the list of Bills which, we believe, would otherwise have been passed by Thursday evening. We believe that the cost of doing that is to destroy the prospect of giving proper scrutiny to some complex issues which will impact on the rights of many Australians.

Is all this brought about by a lack of preparedness of the Parliament to sit? This Parliament has seen a gradual worsening of the sitting pattern which has been imposed. The Government-with my approbation, I must say-moved to a sitting pattern described as `two weeks on, two weeks off'. Parliament used to sit for three weeks in a row, three days a week with one week up. That seemed to be an inefficient use of time. I must confess to being one of those who argued for years that sitting two weeks with four-day-a-week sitting patterns would be more productive and efficient. Given the hours of work in this place, which are anything from 12 to 16 or 18 hours a day, we accepted that four-day sitting weeks impose a very significant strain. Two weeks on, two weeks off was meant to provide an opportunity for non-parliamentary party activities, parliamentary committees and so on during one of the weeks off, and some access to our electorates, which, in the case of many senators and members, are a long way from this Parliament-in my case Western Australia-in the other week off.

We are now moving to a pattern of sitting three weeks on, one week off, four days a week. It is no surprise to any of us that one Government senator is away, having had heart trouble. The impact on both our health and efficiency, on the sensible working of this Parliament, on the sensible consideration of legislation and, indeed, on the civil treatment of each other, is obvious. It cannot be said that the sitting pattern is one where we have in any way sought to reduce the Government's capacity to have time in the chamber. We have consistently-usually over the objections of the Australian Democrats-agreed to additional sitting hours being added to days, and so on--

TALK.START.PARA: —In breach of the agreement.

—I say to Senator Haines that, given the circumstances of the Government's very difficult-indeed, impossible-program, we have bent over backwards to provide additional time where possible. The Australian Democrats have gone from being unyielding on the question of not giving extensions of time to saying-as they did last night-that we could sit till 3.30 in an attempt to finish one Bill, and then today saying that, notwithstanding their professed concern for proper legislative processes, what we are to do now is give the Government, on a very limited timetable, any legislation which it has classified as being needed this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The further options of sitting for extended weeks into June have certainly not been canvassed with us in any serious way by the Government. We know that the Government's conference next week is going to preclude it from sitting then, and I suspect that the shift from this Parliament House to the new Parliament House, which commences shortly thereafter, would make sittings here in June impractical. The Senate is being deprived of an opportunity properly to examine this legislation. We believe that it is an abuse of the processes of this Parliament and we call upon the Australian Democrats to stand by their professed principles, which require them to permit proper parliamentary scrutiny of these Bills and to reject this guillotine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, in order to ensure maximum time for the debate on the constitutional Bills, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the motion moved by Senator Chaney for the suspension of Standing Orders be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the comments that Senator Chaney made in speaking for the suspension motion, the only valid one was that the Government is in a mess and that it is in this mess because of its own incompetence, because of its own making, it should be prepared to cop the consequences. That was certainly a view that we took. We have, as Senator Chaney said, been sitting here this year dealing with innumerable ministerial statements and committee reports of all sorts. Legislation has been slow coming to us from the other place. By and large, we have had precious little to do except sit around and gaze at our own, or someone else's, navel, in the case of Senator Amanda Vanstone.

SPEECH.PARA: So we felt, certainly until last Thursday night, that the Opposition had a reasonable argument to put. We were certainly not prepared to facilitate any moves by the Government to improve its program by curtailing debates and ramming legislation through. The agreement was that there would be no additional sitting days; we would not come back next week; we would not come back on the week beginning 13 June; we would not sit any additional sitting hours, and there would be no gags and no guillotines. Essentially, the agreement on this side of the chamber was to let the Government stew in its own juice, and deservedly so.

All this was fine until last Thursday night when-with no consultation with anybody except, I gather, Senator Evans-the Opposition, through Senator Chaney, did a deal to sit late on Thursday. We called a division on that because Senator Chaney said we were opposed to it. It was, after all, part of the agreement that we had made. If we, on this side, believed that the Government was being less than well organised in its program, there was no need for us to help the Government out. But, last Thursday night, the Opposition decided to extend the sitting times. We called a division and all Liberal Party and National Party senators who were present supported the Government in the move for a later sitting.

I suspect from some comments that were made to me subsequent to last Thursday night that, not only did a number of Opposition backbenchers not know what that division was about, but neither did some of its junior frontbenchers. That is not particularly unusual. It seems to be a practice of the Opposition parties not to let their backbenchers know what is happening or they feed them a line that every time the Senate sits late it is because the Australian Democrats have agreed to it.

That is consistent, I suppose, with what has been going on in the last few years. Increasingly, Opposition senators support legislation that they have argued passionately against in this place. We have seen them support all sorts of measures that they said were iniquitous in their speeches. Then, when we, supporting their vocal opposition to the legislation, have either moved amendments to legislation or opposed it, the Opposition has voted with the Government. It might be a salutary lesson to some backbenchers in the Liberal and National parties to consider how many Bills have gone through this place in the last four years because they have supported them, despite speaking out against them, and not because we have supported them.

As I say, Thursday night rolled around and, despite the agreement, times had been extended. As they say, one slip of this sort can be seen as an accident, but when it happens several times it is sheer carelessness. I would have thought, it having happened the third time, that it had gone beyond simple carelessness and into the realm of hypocrisy.

On Monday night, the Opposition, apparently, went to the Government with an offer that it was certainly not going to refuse; the Opposition offered to sit an extra hour. There was no consultation. I understand that Senator Harradine was left out of the discussion. Certainly I was not aware of it until 10.31 p.m. rolled around and we were still sitting. There was no explanation about why. When it suited the Opposition parties' convenience-again assuming that they all knew about it-the Senate was expected to sit longer, despite the previous agreement that there would be no change to proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with truncating debate?

—Agreements require more than one party to adhere to them, and the point is that we went into the last weeks of this session agreeing on this side, I thought, that there was to be no accommodating of the Government in its ham-fisted attempt to get its program dealt with. That agreement was breached, first of all, last Thursday night; and, secondly, on Monday night; and, despite the fact that I objected to it, the deal had already been done. Last night, I understand, the Opposition-again, courtesy of Senator Chaney-offered to sit on for an extra hour. By that stage, as far as the Democrats were concerned and certainly as far as I was concerned, all bets, all agreements, all arrangements were off.
—What has this to do with the proper scrutiny of legislation?

—Senator Chaney asks what this has to do with the scrutiny of legislation, and I think that is an extremely good question. I was about to come to that because I really wonder what the charade we went through last night had to do with the scrutiny of legislation. We in this place are supposed to be a House of review. We can be a House of review only if we actually do look at legislation and come up with some sort of reasonable analysis of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, I would have to say, we heard from some of the Opposition backbenchers some of the most appalling nonsense that it has been my misfortune to hear. I would have thought that no-one, by any stretch of any imagination, could possibly have described last night's debate as scrutinising legislation. There was not even an attempt to canvass the issues. In the main, Liberal Party and, even more apparently, National Party contributions to last night's debate consisted of rattling a whole lot of sabres and an assortment of phantoms that tortured imaginations had conjured up, presumably by a cursory look at the legislation.

I think this has come perilously close to something that Lewis Carroll would have delighted in. It was certainly a long way past brillig last night when we got on to debating the Constitution Bills; but there was certainly no justification for the way the slithy toves on this side of the Senate gyred and gimbled their way through several hours of fairly meaningless contributions to a debate that should have been a review of the legislation. Yes, this House is supposed to be a place where legislation is reviewed. It is supposed to be a place where we scrutinise legislation. It was anything but that last night.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from the Opposition benches.
—For the benefit of those backbenchers who have just wandered in, presumably from a morning tea break, I will repeat that the agreement--
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: A couple of colleagues of mine had a meeting and we wandered in from a meeting-not from a morning tea break, as Senator Haines has said.
—Order! What is the point of order?
—That Senator Haines was making statements very offensive to the senators who had just come in.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—Apparently it is perfectly acceptable for Opposition senators to carry on about the absence from the chamber of all or any of us; but they simply cannot take it on the chin when it is dished up. However, whether they were at a morning tea break or whether they were at a meeting is irrelevant. They were not here and maybe it would be worthwhile filling them in--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I rarely raise a point of order and interrupt another senator; but I believe that we are supposed to be debating a motion to which Senator Haines's remarks are not at all relevant and we ought really to get on to the referendum Bills and enable others who have some substantive contributions to make to make them.

—The motion before the Chair is for the suspension of Standing Orders. Traditionally, debate on such motions has been wide-ranging. Because Senator Chaney was allowed to range fairly widely over the issues I have allowed Senator Haines to do the same. However, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the motion before the Chair is for the suspension of Standing Orders.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I was answering some of the points that Senator Chaney had raised, pointing out that an agreement had been made on this side of the chamber that no changes at all to sitting days, to sitting times, to the procedures of the place, be engaged in simply because the Government had got itself into a mess of its own making, and that it deserved no assistance. That was certainly the view that we took and, I thought, that the Opposition took, until last Thursday night when the Opposition moved to sit until 10.30, instead of rising at 6.30.
—The Government moved.

—Senator Chaney had to support it or it would not have got through, and support it he did. Worse, on Monday night he, apparently, went to the Government with a proposal that we sit another hour. So the initiative this time came from him-and sit another hour on Monday night we did. That process, for the benefit of the Liberal Party backbenchers who were not here, was repeated last night.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise another point of order. My point of order is the relevance of this speech. We have till 12.30 to deal with all of these referendum Bills under a guillotine that is going to be supported by Senator Haines, yet she is taking up time which should properly be used by others on a substantive measure.

—Order! The question of the guillotine has not yet been determined by the Senate. Senator Haines is speaking to a motion to suspend Standing Orders. She has more time, but I think she has been given adequate opportunity to respond to Senator Chaney. She should now deal with the question of whether Standing Orders should or should not be suspended.
—Did you or did you not promise not to support the guillotine?
—I will answer that question by asking my own. Did or did not the Opposition agree, until last Thursday night, that there would be no changes at all to the procedures in this place?
—No.
—Senator Walters should go back and have a look at some of the comments.
—Go back and have another look.

—Senator Bishop over here, whose voice can usually bring down planes, does not like it when it is directed at her, but the agreement in this place to continue normal procedures was first breached by the Opposition. The second time it was breached it was breached by the Opposition and the third time it was breached it was breached by the Opposition.

—Order! I have given Senator Haines adequate opportunity to reply to the remarks made by Senator Chaney. If she wishes to continue she should concentrate on the issue of whether or not Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Mr Deputy President, I do not like curtailing debate. Nobody in this place likes curtailing debate. But clearly, the behaviour of some Opposition senators last night and the decision by their Leader to renege on his part of the agreement has released the rest of this chamber from their part of the agreement.

Title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, we are dealing with the title of the fourth referendum Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988. That title states:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any Government.

Mr Chairman, that title is misleading, it is deceptive and it is a fraud. It is important for honourable senators and, indeed, the public to realise the importance of the long title because the long title will be the basis of the question that will be on the ballot paper received by every elector in this Commonwealth. The electors will be asked, `Do you support the Bill to', amongst other things, `extend freedom of religion?'. The people of Australia will not know that that proposition has the potential, as has been admitted by the Government in this chamber, to abolish state aid for independent schools. That proposition even has the potential, because it goes not only to legislative acts but also to administrative acts, to cause a future President of the Senate or a future Speaker of the House of Representatives to say, `We cannot start the day with the Lord's Prayer'.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a secular society.

—Ah, Senator Zakharov says `secular society'. Now we have it. We know now the reason for this proposition coming forward. She says we are a secular society. We may indeed be a pluralist society, but it is clear from the type of statement made by Senator Zakharov that the Zakharovs of this world are behind this particular push.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that Senator Zakharov will concede that because this amendment to the Constitution proposes that the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory shall not establish any religion or impose any religious observance, it not only deals with the laws of this country but also deals with executive and administrative acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are profoundly wrong.

—Senator Collins was not here last night when we canvassed the issues relating to Murphy. The Minister at the table could not give a guarantee that this measure would not at some stage enable a sectarian attack to be mounted in a State to prevent that State from giving aid by way of funds to parochial schools.
—Oh, you are a straw man. You are a threat expert. You have survived on threats for many years.

—Senator Button has made certain statements. Senator Button should know what Mr Justice Murphy said. He said that it was appropriate for the plaintiffs in the Black case to use section 116 of the Constitution to abolish state aid for independent schools. If we did have a Bench of Murphys, for example, the same thing could, of course, occur. But in this case it could occur in respect of the funds utilised by States for educational purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, I put to the Committee that in fact the long title of the Bill does not deal with the proper question. Where in the description of section 16 in the margin of the Constitution are the words `freedom of religion'? It says:
Commonwealth not to legislate in respect of religion.
Where, indeed, in this Bill does it say that this is a Bill to extend freedom of religion? It says, in the very part that we were dealing with last night, namely, clause 4:
No establishment et cetera of religion.

Last night Senator Crichton-Browne referred to the cases. He also referred to the discussions in the constitutional conventions, particularly by Higgins, to the effect that section 116 was not placed in the Constitution in order to establish a right to freedom of religion. That was not the primary purpose of it. The primary purpose of it was to prevent States from establishing a religion or legislating for the observance of a religion.

I have submitted, and it has not been denied, that this measure is capable of erecting an impenetrable wall which has the potential of discriminating against and isolating adherents to various religions. To describe that as a measure to extend freedom of religion is to mislead the public and to act in a most improper way in a matter which is one of the most important matters that we can discuss, and that is alterations to the Constitution. Once it is in the Constitution, it is set in concrete and the decisions then are not capable of being made by the elected representatives of the people, either at State or Federal level; they are made by non-elected judges.
I remind honourable senators again of what the former Chief Justice of Tasmania, Sir Stanley Burbury, said:

I would prefer the democratic control of legislation through the political sanction of the ballot box and a strong second Chamber of Parliament to handing over a substantial measure of control of legislation to a judicial tribunal of a few men-eminent in their profession and men of integrity and wisdom though they may be. Judges are but men and are as subject to subtle corruption by the exercise of great power as other men.

That is the crux of the matter. Here we are dealing with a question, the ramifications of which we do not know. The Government is not prepared to give a guarantee that what it is attempting to do here will not have the effect that I have suggested it may have.

Under those circumstances I believe that the people of Australia should reject it. Indeed, under those circumstances I would have thought it more appropriate to delete the words `to extend freedom of religion' and insert in lieu thereof `to ensure that the Commonwealth a State or a Territory shall not legislate or take administrative measures in respect of religion'. I make that suggestion to the Government. I oppose that, of course; but at least it would be a true reflection of what this Bill does and it would enable the electors of Australia to truly see what this measure does and to vote on it accurately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has had a good deal of debate in the committee stage of this legislation, but unfortunately very late at night. Therefore, the debate would substantially have escaped the attention of the Australian people. I rise to point out that we have half an hour to deal with the whole of the committee stage--
—You should have thought of that last night.

—I do not need any advice from the Acting Government Whip, who dishonoured the arrangements I made with him. In any event, there was no intention by the Government to bring these other Bills on today. This title cannot, in my view, encompass the diversity of matters which are being put before the Australian people. I have a great deal of sympathy for the point of view that Senator Harradine has expressed, but the fundamental problem is that people are being asked to vote on three totally disparate proposals. I do not believe that the defect in the legislation can be cured.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the desire to have some committee debate on the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, which makes another major constitutional change, I do not propose to prolong this committee debate further. I simply wish to express my great dissatisfaction that the sort of point made by Senator Harradine cannot be dealt with in an orderly and sensible way because of the restrictions imposed by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support, in precise terms, the views expressed by Senator Harradine. The proposed changes to the Constitution remove the words `for the making of a law'. They now refer to any Act of any parliament in Australia. That means that the right of the Senate to say prayers in the morning could be removed. Recently, at the opening of the new Parliament House-in spite of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who wanted no prayers-we managed to have prayers. We would no longer have that right on those occasions. In the States it would no longer be possible for school children to say prayers in the mornings. At no ceremonial function could we have a reference to God. It is not absurd to hypothesise that the singing of God Save the Queen could be prohibited. That is the practical, tangible effect of these proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, Title, leave out all words after `Constitution', insert `to provide that generally for parliamentary elections throughout Australia (but not the Senate and House of Representatives) the number of electors in electorates shall not vary by more than 20 per cent, to confer a Constitutional right to vote at all parliamentary elections within Australia, and to provide that each elector shall vote only once at an election'.

I move this amendment on behalf of the Opposition because, as with other Bills brought forward by the Government, we believe that the long title of the Bill is seriously flawed. The questions which are going to be put to the Australian people do not represent the reality of the constitutional change which is being sought by the Government. In this case the Government has delivered a sugary pill indeed by asking the Australian people whether they approve an alteration of the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. One would have thought that an untutored view, that is, a view based on not knowing what lay behind that question, what the substantial amendments to be made to the Constitution are, would result in a yes answer being given.

This Bill is not going to be debated in any reasonable way in the committee stage because the time for the debate is now less than 20 minutes. In the second reading debate, on all of the constitutional amendments, a number of points were made clear which demonstrate that this Bill will not provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia but would impose quite a different set of standards upon State parliaments as against the standards which are imposed on the Senate and the House of Representatives and which would not be disturbed by the passage of this referendum.

What this Bill alleges to do is to pay premier regard to the principle of one vote one value. It is dictating to the State parliaments and to the Territory legislatures. There are complications about that which we will not have time to debate this morning, which is a tragedy. The Australian Democrats are now putting up amendments, which we saw for the first time in the last half hour, which supplant amendments that were circulated by the Minister at the table yesterday, amendments which were supported by an explanatory memorandum that the Minister could not release to me because the Government thought that it needed to produce a tighter document. We are to be called upon, no doubt, to vote on a series of amendments which will have had no proper examination, by the Opposition or by anybody else. The farcical nature of the present procedures with respect to constitutional change is becoming increasingly apparent.

To return to my amendment, this Bill imposes the condition of one vote one value on legislatures other than the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Bill represents an attempt to impose, through the Constitution, restrictions and limitations on State electoral systems which do not and could not be applied to the Federal Parliament. The discrepancies, the variations, which exist in the House of Representatives go beyond the limits imposed on State parliaments. Because of the special arrangements made for Tasmania, the one vote one value principle as it will be applied to the States does not apply to the House of Representatives. But even more sharply, when one looks at the variations from one vote one value in the Senate, one finds, as I said in the second reading debate, that New South Wales is 117 per cent over quota, that is, over the average which is imposed if one took an Australia-wide average for the Senate, with Tasmania 81 per cent below quota. So we say to the State parliaments, `Your upper Houses must be within a tolerance of 10 per cent either way. You cannot have a variation of any more than 20 per cent between any electorates'. Yet in the Senate we allow a variation of a couple of hundred per cent on that basis. It is a farce.

It is claimed that this Bill will impose a uniform democratic standard upon Australia, whereas the reality is that the present Government, the Democrats and the other supporters of this Bill are quite prepared for far more substantial variations to continue to apply in the Senate-in my view, democratically-than will apply in any State or Territory. I look at the Tasmanian Legislative Council, which has been subject to criticism, and I find that the largest percentage over quota is 31 per cent, as against 117 per cent for the Senate in New South Wales. That is the sort of contrast. If we look at the complained-of upper House arrangements in Western Australia, we find variations which are approximately half the variations that we intend to continue in the case of the Senate. This is just one of the examples that have led independent observers who have been much quoted in this debate-the head of the Morgan polling organisation, Mr Paddy McGuinness, and so on-to say that these are thoroughly dishonest questions, and that is what they are.

A Tasmanian senator laughs. I ask him why it is that he can occupy a seat in this Senate with 80 per cent less than the quota that would be required if we had one vote one value in this place, yet he is prepared to attack the Tasmanian upper House which has half the variations that apply to him. What hypocrisy! The absolute hypocrisy of the honourable senator is almost unbelievable.

We have a series of amendments. The amendment which we are putting before this chamber now quite specifically draws the attention of the people of Australia to the substance of what is proposed by the Government. It is a far clearer exposition of the actual changes to the Constitution which are proposed. What we are saying is that the long title should read that it is an Act to alter the Constitution `to provide that generally for parliamentary elections throughout Australia (but not the Senate and House of Representatives)'-and that is a fact-`the number of electors in electorates shall not vary by more than 20 per cent', and then the other matters which are dealt with in the Bill are also included in our long title.

It is impossible to challenge the proposition that what we are putting forward as the long title which will go as the question to the people of Australia is a more accurate description than what is proposed by the Government in its present long title. What the present long title suggests is that the people are being asked to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia; yet what is proposed is, in fact, imposing totally differential standards according to whether one is dealing with a State or Federal parliament.

There is a real problem for this Committee and for the Senate in dealing with this Bill on the basis of the timetable which is put forward. Let me remind the Committee that last Friday Senator Amanda Vanstone, who is the Opposition spokesman on matters dealing with the Australian Capital Territory, pointed out that the Bill, in its present form, was utterly inconsistent with the Government's own proposals for an electoral system for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Possibly.

—The Minister at the table interjects `Possibly'. I would accept that, given the variations of judicial interpretation that apply, one perhaps should always put the word `possibly' in front of any comment made about proposed constitutional change. I say that very seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is enough evidence of wide variations of interpretation of our own Constitution and of the United States Constitution by the High Court and the Supreme Court, respectively, to say that it would be a very bold senator who stood in his place and gave any guarantees about what the precise meaning of any proposal was. Suffice it to say that Senator Amanda Vanstone's point was backed by the opinion of counsel advising the Senate. A Queen's Counsel gave his view that there was an inconsistency; that change was required. Whilst I defer to the point made by Senator Robert Ray about `possibly', I remind him that on Monday we were advised by his colleague the Minister charged with the conduct of these Bills, Senator Tate, that the Government proposed to introduce amendments.

Here we are facing a situation in which on Monday we returned to debate these Bills as we thought, only to find that the Government was proposing amendments to meet the point and some point additional to that raised by Senator Vanstone and in the opinion. We received in due course and the Minister circulated in a formal way under the heading of this Bill-the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988-amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as an amendment; as a draft.
—They were circulated to senators. They were not formally circulated in the chamber. We then, of course, sought advice.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a very confused debate on this proposed amendment. Senator Macklin, when he rose in this place, said that the legal advice the Democrats had was that the Bill was in proper order and did not need amendment, and therefore they would not be supporting the amendment. We took advice and our advice was that the Government's proposal was defective. So we were left in this situation: firstly, our advice is that the original Bill is defective; secondly, our advice is that the amendment given to us by the Government is also defective.

When, last night, in the course of that long and, for most of us, irksome, night, I went to the Minister-I checked through the Clerks and pursued the matter because there was reference to an explanatory memorandum-the Minister said in a very polite way, `I am sorry, I cannot give that to you because we are looking for a more tightly expressed document', or words to that effect. So we could not get the Government's explanation of what the document meant as late as last evening. Then today in the Senate we are hit with new amendments which are apparently to be put forward by the Australian Democrats and which of course we have had no opportunity to peruse in an orderly way or to seek advice on.

Given the variety of legal advice that has already been given on the original Bill and the first set of proposed amendments, I can only say that for the Democrats in those circumstances to put us in the position where we are required to vote on those amendments in 10 minutes time is an absolute disgrace. The situation is that we are being asked to make major changes on the basis now of a third set of words which have been produced, as far as we are concerned, in the last half hour or so.

On the face of it one can immediately see questions about precisely where the further amendments might fit in, whether those amendments will apply to the discrepancies which, as I have said, will be permitted to continue under the original legislation with respect to the House of Representatives and with respect to the Senate. I find it very hard to see precisely what ill or abuse of the process of electoral distribution is aimed at in the expressions which have now been put forward by the Australian Democrats.

I simply say to the Committee that to suggest that in this way we should finalise today a proposition which is going to be put to the people of Australia for vote is an absurdity. I have no doubt that if the Senate does what apparently it is to be asked to do and adopts these changes virtually sight unseen, they will be subsequently subjected to the most searching scrutiny and criticism in the public debate. But are we to say that the responsibilities of this Parliament are such that we should run the risk of passing deficient legislation on the basis that we hope it might be picked up later and if there is something wrong it will be handled because the people of Australia will reject the referendum and defeat the proposed constitutional amendments?

I do not believe there could be a more blatant or more apparently unsatisfactory situation with respect to dealing with constitutional amendments and nobody can blame that unsatisfactory situation on the fact that we have had a lengthy debate on the other Bills, because in fact that lengthy debate has extended the time available for the consideration of the defects in this legislation. If we had not had a lengthy debate, presumably this would have been put forward in some form or other now acknowledged by the Government and the Australian Democrats to be defective. That is the reality. Had we dealt with these Bills on Monday, we would have faced an amendment from the Government. Senator Macklin said it had the support of the Democrats. It would have been dealt with and it would have meant that we had, on the face of it, a deficient Bill passed through this House for submission to the people of Australia. The Government apparently abandoned its amendment in favour of that of the Democrats.

There could be no clearer demonstration of the lack of responsibility in the approach to these matters, the lack of preparation, the lack of capacity for proper parliamentary scrutiny. This is a quite disgraceful and unacceptable situation. I do not believe that it can be supported conscientiously by either Government senators or the Australian Democrats senators. We are being asked to vote blind at the third go at getting this right-right in the sense of achieving what the Government and the Australian Democrats want to achieve and which we say in any event is wrong for Australia.

I say to the Government that if there is any honesty of purpose, any sincerity of purpose at all in what it is putting forward, it will not maintain the extraordinary timetable that has been put down. We now have five minutes to consider this Bill and to vote on amendments which have not even been moved in this chamber. That is a disgrace, and I protest with the greatest possible force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, with regard to the Opposition's amendment, may I indicate that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting it. At a later stage when we have some time I intend to look at some other amendments which senators have before them. Since we are taking the Bill as a whole, I wish to refer to proposed section 29 (2) which, I believe, imposes an obligation upon the Federal Parliament that it does not impose upon the State Parliament. Since proposed section 124b actually refers to the same situation-124b places the onus on the States and also on the Commonwealth-there is no need for proposed section 29 (2). I would propose at a later stage to move an amendment to that effect. The second amendment with regard to items that I would certainly be looking at amending relates to proposed section 122a, which seeks to insert a new subsection. The reason for this particular item is to avoid the weighting exercise. This would be achieved by providing that votes may not be weighted according to different classes of electors, such as classes defined, for example, by social, economic, demographic or geographical factors.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision does not affect the counting process involved in normal preferential or proportional voting. The last item that I would propose to move is one about which there was some debate about the Government moving an amendment. I think it was a very long and cumbersome way of dealing with this particular item. I think it would be dealt with much more succinctly and rapidly and certainly would avoid the problem, if there is any, with regard to the upper Houses in New South Wales and South Australia, which are democratically elected Houses. I believe the way of doing that is simply to leave out those words `as near as practicable the same as the method of choosing senators' and insert instead into that situation that `the method to be used is a system of proportional representation'.

This original item, of course, came from my Bill but in my Bill it was not used in this type of context. In my Bill it was used with regard to a fallback situation. The Government here, however, has actually not only used the fallback but also used it with regard to any of those chambers in Australia which are actually elected as a single electorate. I believe that if we now take out that provision-which was perfectly all right if it was only a fallback situation, it is not all right if it refers to those chambers in New South Wales and South Australia-State parliaments under my provision would have far greater flexibility. Of course, it is still open to the States which do not have existing laws for the conduct of elections at large to adapt the Senate system to their own particular variations that they wish to achieve.

It is worth noting, I think, that Australia has a long and honoured history with regard to proportional representation. Indeed, our unique contribution to that particular method was to insert into it the notion of preferences. That ought to be borne in mind when we look at any method of proportional representation. The item here is not, in fact, to define that. My amendment, as is consistent with the Bill that I drafted on this and which had some criticism from the committee that looked at it, is drafted as a constitutional item; it is not drafted as a legislative item.

I believe that a drafting of those matters needs to be dealt with in quite different ways. One is a much more broad enunciation-indeed, Senator Alston last night enunciated this rather well-that, in fact, it is an exercise in the entrenchment of basic principles. Here I think the principle behind any notion of proportional representation is very clear. There is a whole variety of different methods but the essential element is that representation is done in regard to the proportion of votes that are received. That is the essential element that goes across all methods of proportional representation.

It means that if one wishes then to look at derivative principles, fairly obviously one such derivative principle is that more than one member is elected within that single electorate. They are the types of amendments which I think will fix up any lingering problems that people may have had. I am still not at all sure that we needed to go into that exercise. Lawyers often operate with an abundance of caution. I have had the opportunity of checking with a whole series of lawyers with regard to this matter. All of the advice I have received is confident that these proposals will achieve what they seek to achieve.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the time allotted for consideration of the Bill has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion and on behalf of Senator Haines, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing order 407b be suspended as would prevent the questions being put in respect of any amendments circulated by the Australian Democrats, the Opposition, or Independent Senators and that such questions be put accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to note precisely what is being proposed by the Australian Democrats in moving for the suspension of standing orders. Honourable senators need soberly to assess what is going on here. We have had circulated by the Australian Democrats amendments which are totally new to this chamber. They have not been properly examined. They are not now going to be debated. Having had constitutional proposals before us, for a period of some weeks now, those proposals having been found last Friday to be deficient, the proposals to remedy the deficiency by the Government, in turn, having been found to be deficient, the Australian Democrats are now asking the Senate, presumably with the consent and support of the Government, to vote on amendments which have not received any consideration at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people are going to be asked to vote in a referendum, which includes clauses-if this motion is carried-which have not received any proper consideration by the Parliament. They have been produced out of somebody's hat this morning. We are dealing with serious and significant issues. We are dealing with issues which will reconstitute many of the State parliaments. We are dealing with issues which will go to the operation of the democratic system in the States, although they leave untouched the operation of the system as it applies to the Commonwealth. We are suddenly being handed a sleeve option.

I do not know whether Senator Tate is responsible for this, whether the officials are responsible for this, or who is responsible for this, but the political responsibility rests with Senator Tate and the Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, and the Ministers at the table here today. Those people, having been confronted with the reality that they had produced a constitutional proposal that had technical legal difficulties for their other proposals for the Australian Capital Territory, went away and produced amendments which have now been found to be defective. They were not even able to give to the Committee an explanatory note of what they were doing because the document was not distributable. It was not of sufficient quality, apparently.

I am not in a position, on behalf of the Opposition, to pass final judgment on any amendments which are put forward without our having an opportunity to consider them. It is an absurdity that this Parliament and this Opposition are now being asked to consider proposals which may well affect the operation of democracy in the States and which, on the face of it, will certainly affect the range of electoral choices which are open to a State government when it is constituting its parliament and determining a proper system of voting. I oppose this extension of Standing Orders because it is a flagrant abuse of the parliamentary process. It is--

TALK.START.PARA: —So is a filibuster.

—Let me remind Senator McLean what we are talking about. These Bills came into the Senate for consideration last week and were not discovered to be defective until last Friday. The technical deficiency which everybody seems to agree was there, discovered by my colleague Senator Vanstone, was found after five days of the Bills being put before us in this place. We then have gone through a process where the Government has sought a solution to the deficiency and failed. This morning the Australian Democrats produced an alternative solution. The only reason that we in the Senate have had any opportunity to consider this third option is because of what Senator McLean calls a `filibuster'.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to say to Senator McLean: if it took five or six days to find two sets of defects in this legislation which is seeking to amend our Constitution, does he suggest that we should be apologising for providing the time to enable his party to form a view that changes were required? This is an absurdity. I remind Senator McLean that we did provide the time. These Bills would have been dealt with if we had not had a lengthy debate on rights. Presumably, consideration would have been completed before these further deficiencies were discovered. The legislation could have been passed in this deficient state.

I therefore say that once again we have had demonstrated the need for careful parliamentary scrutiny which will at times be lengthy. I remind the Democrats that they joined with us in an exceedingly lengthy debate on the Bill of Rights. That might have been described as a filibuster. That was a debate which went on for days and weeks. Indeed, it was spread over some three months. I simply remind the Senate and the Australian Democrats of the impact of that debate that a person who was opposed to what we were doing would describe as a filibuster. The impact was quite simple. The people of Australia started thinking about and examining that proposition. They decided that they did not want it. We did not defeat the Bill of Rights in the Senate. The Government took it off the table because of the public reaction, because of the way in which it assessed the people of Australia would vote.

Let us look at the identity card. Again, people could describe debate on this measure as a filibuster. We joined with the Australian Democrats, not once, not twice but three times, to really oppose the identity card. We did it in a way which, again, our opponents would describe as a filibuster. I remind honourable senators that we did it in the teeth of 70 per cent public support for the card. It was an unpopular thing to do politically. On that occasion I think we showed great courage and I acknowledge that we always had firm allies in the Australian Democrats in that exercise. Anyone who believed that the Bill of Rights or the identity card should be foisted on the Australian people without the chance for proper consideration would regard what we did in the Senate as wrong.

Let me contrast the history of the ID card and the Bill of Rights with what is before us today. Today we have a third proposition. The Government has failed twice to give us a proposition that it is prepared to support with respect to the so-called fair elections referendum. We are now, like a bolt out of the blue, given something by the Australian Democrats which is totally contrary to what they told us was their position on Monday. On Monday, Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, said that he thought the original Bill was satisfactory. He told us that he was acting on legal advice. Senator Macklin has effectively confirmed that position again in the Senate today. I remind the Senate of that because it simply demonstrates the enormous room for error in the field that we are dealing with today. We had a lengthy debate on the possibility that whatever care we took with the words the High Court could, in any event, make quite unpredictable findings. We have talked at great length about the disparity between the views of Mr Justice Murphy and all of his fellow judges on the present freedom of religion arrangements in the Constitution. That is not an unusual thing. Who could pick what a judge might decide because, after all, look at the disparate views on the right to trial by jury taken by Mr Justice Deane and Mr Justice Murphy. I am glad to de-Murphyise the argument, if you like, because variations in the way judges behave is not restricted to Senator Murphy who indeed, I think, showed a high degree of consistency in his judgments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consistently wrong.

—The view is put forward by Senator Stone that he was consistently wrong. But my point is that we have had endless demonstration in this debate of the fact that the meaning that might be given to a constitutional change, even if we think in this Parliament we have got it right, is pretty hard to pick. Former Senator Rae, who was in the Chamber until very recently, conceded that we could say no more than possibly this is what the court would hold it to believe.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are now seeking to extend their right to move amendments in this ambush situation. I use `ambush' not in the sense that they have necessarily set out to ambush us, but because they have, over the course of the last two days, totally changed their position on this Bill. I am sure it was done in good faith, but they have totally changed their position. Why have they changed their position? Because further and more careful inquiry has told them that their position on Monday was wrong. They will not give us the time for further and careful inquiry. They will not give the Government time for further and careful inquiry. I assume they gave the Government enough time for the Attorney-General's Department to give an opinion on what the amendments mean, but I say to the Government that the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department on Monday was quite different.

I assume that the Attorney-General's Department also had a chance to cast its eyes over the amendment that was circulated on Monday. It was then the Government's view of how this could be rectified and presumably the Attorney-General's Department was wrong, as the Attorney-General's Department was wrong with respect to the original Bill unless it is a fact that the Government took the drafting of the Bill and the advice on the Bill out of the hands of the Attorney-General's Department and relied upon Senator Tate and the Deputy Prime Minister and perhaps the previous Attorney-General, Senator Evans.

Mr Chairman, this is a circumstance where I think we could not have a more clear breach of the functions, a more clear abuse of the functions of this chamber and this Parliament than we are seeing today. I reject any suggestion that the Opposition has contributed in the tiniest way to the predicament of the Government on this. The worst that can be said of the Opposition is that we have had a longer debate than some people would like on these vital constitutional amendments. That is the one complaint that an opponent of the Opposition would make.

I remind the Senate again that it is only because we have taken, not the five days or the three days that the Government would have liked, but six days to deal with five Bills for constitutional amendment. All of six days, is that not disgraceful? The Senate actually spent six days debating five Bills for constitutional amendments including the one put forward by the Democrats with a totally radical new approach to the process of legislating in this country! How dare the House of review scrutinise those Bills for six days! Is that not a ridiculous proposition? To go back to it, I remind the Senate that without that six days of debate, we would not today be debating these amendments. We would two days ago or three days ago have seen amendments pushed through or the original Bill sustained if the Australian Democrats were of the view they were on Monday, which everybody now agrees is wrong-both were wrong.

I know it is very hard to turn straw into gold; it is very hard to turn sand into gold except through possession. It is very hard to turn party politicians from a path once they have adopted it and it is nearly impossible to turn governments from a path, however wrong-headed, and however clearly wrong in principle, once the juggernaut has commenced to roll. I know that in making this debate there is scarcely any chance at all that any honourable senator opposite is listening in a sense that he is prepared to consider the reality of what I am talking about and to respond.

I suspect that the Australian Democrats are as tightly bound, notwithstanding their claimed different approach where they would listen to the arguments on the merits and vote accordingly. I think, quite frankly, those days sadly have passed and any arguments that the Democrats had for being a genuine, middle-ground party have long since disappeared. I regret that, because I think it was at least a tolerable situation when one had people-and I think Senator Chipp in the main was off in this line-who were prepared to listen to arguments and to come to some conclusion. But the situation now is that the Democrats have come in here en masse, determined to force upon the Senate an amendment which has not received any proper consideration and which is not available for debate; which cannot be subjected to independent legal advice; which will result in a question being put to the Australian people; which we already know is going to be put dishonestly; which may also be, basically and sadly, flawed.

I can only say that we have come to a very sorry pass in the Senate and I believe that we have seen a complete prostitution of the legislative process, a complete abuse of the process of constitutional change in this country and I record my disgust at the circumstance in which the Senate finds itself today.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now put the question that the motion moved by Senator Macklin be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman--
—Are you taking a point of order, Senator Puplick? I will take a point of order but I will not give you the call for any other reason.

—I am seeking your advice as to whether in fact it is competent to move a motion to suspend Standing Orders to prevent the Senate from debating the amendments proposed to be moved by Senator Macklin to this piece of legislation.

—No, not in view of the guillotine. I must put the questions without any further debate. I would hear a point of order but no motions. The question is that the three amendments circulated by Senator Macklin be agreed to.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order and draw your attention to proposed amendment No. 3, which proposes to leave out certain words and insert other words. I ask whether the amendment being moved is a direct negative. The proposal is to delete certain words from clause 9, namely, the words `as nearly as is practicable the same as the method of choosing senators' and to insert certain other words, namely, `a system of proportional representation'. I would put it to you that the system which is currently provided for in the Bill is not a system of proportional representation and would not have the effect of imposing proportional representation on other elections, but that the amendment moved by Senator Macklin is a direct negative of that and that, that amendment is out of order.

—The definition of a direct negative is if the same result could be achieved by voting against the motion and in that case the same result could not be achieved by that method. Do you have a point of order, Senator Chaney?
—We have dealt with the gag motion but not with Senator Macklin's motions.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Circulated amendments-
Page 2, clause 5, proposed subsection 29 (2), lines 15 and 16, leave out the proposed subsection.
Page 3, clause 9, after proposed section 124a, insert the following new section:
Votes to have equal value
(a) an election held in an electoral division; or
(b) an election held in an electoral region that is one electorate;

the method of voting shall be such that, with respect to the votes of all electors in the division, or in the electorate, as the case may be, votes shall not be weighted according to different classes of electors.
`(2) In this section, ``election'' includes an election to choose senators.''.

Page 5, clause 9, proposed subsection 124d (2), lines 6 and 7, leave out ``, as nearly as practicable, the same as the method of choosing senators'', insert ``a system of proportional representation''.
