TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister confirm that, because the Government will not allow uranium enrichment in this country, Australians are losing an estimated $1 billion in revenue each year? Does he accept that its farcical three-mine policy is depriving the Aborigines from the Koongarra region of the right to gain the maximum economic benefit from their land and costing them $250m? Does he further accept that it is playing into the hands of our competitors for uranium sales, namely, South Africa, Niger, Namibia and Canada, which will pick up the growing uranium market for peaceful purposes? Finally, can he confirm that these important decisions about uranium policies are to be made by a handful of people dominated by the left of the trade union movement at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Conference in Hobart and that we are once again seeing the faceless minority determining the policy of Australia rather than those elected by the people to represent them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if that were true I think a faceless minority might be better than a brainless one, which is what we get with any Opposition conference on this issue.
—What a stupid statement. After the carry-on in your Party on that issue, that is a really pathetic statement.
—I am referring to the carry-on in the Senate.
—You let yourself down when you behave like that.
—Is that right?
—Your own views are totally at odds with those in the Party.
—Order!

—I am getting some sort of prefect-type coaching from members of the Opposition, but I appreciate it. There are three parts to the honourable senator's question. I do not believe for a moment that the decision not to allow uranium enrichment in Australia necessarily involves a loss of $1 billion in revenue or profit to the industry. I do not know what--
—Estimated.

—That is estimated. Some of the estimates which have been put around by various sections of the industry are wild in the extreme. Certainly, if we add value to any mineral resource we get additional revenue from that process. I would have no idea about estimating the amount but it certainly would be substantial. In so far as the Koongarra mine is concerned, I have some doubts about the three mines policy but I also have doubts about a policy which would involve open slather in respect of uranium mining. It is not within the area of my ministerial responsibility to be able to give any definitive view on that either way. I have doubts about both views. It may be that what the honourable senator says about the Koongarra mine and the loss of revenue to a variety of people is an important issue. But I think it is not to the point to say that it is a loss of revenue to an Aboriginal community; it is a loss of revenue to the whole country if the figures that the honourable senator has suggested are correct.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether we are playing into the hands of our competitors. I believe that Canada has succeeded very well in the uranium market as a result of less competition from Australia and other countries in recent years. I have no knowledge of the other countries to which the honourable senator refers. Finally, I was asked whether the decision of the ALP Conference will be made by a handful of people, the handful to which the honourable senator referred being a group of left wing trade unionists. It has always been my personal view that one of the problems of the ALP National Conference-and like any body of that kind, it has problems-is that there are insufficient union representatives at it. Certainly, on this issue, I think there would be no handful of trade unionists, Left, Right or Centre, determining this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Non-elected.
—There are no people who vote or participate in the deliberations of an ALP Conference who are not elected. They are all elected delegates.
—They are not elected by the people.

—It is exactly the same with the Liberal Party Conference. John Elliott tells Liberal parliamentarians what to do from time to time; he is not elected by the Australian people. He has been telling John Howard when to jump for months now. Mr Elliott is not elected, so what are honourable senators opposite talking about?
—Why not face up to the reality of the question?
—I am facing up to the reality. It is a precise analogy.
—You know the constitutional differences between the parties.

—I know that John Elliott tells Liberal parliamentarians what to do. That is the point: he is not elected. He is not elected even by the shareholders of Carlton and United, incidentally. So I do not think any decision will be made by anybody other than the 99 delegates who participate at the Conference.

—Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate what actions are being taken to ensure that additional international air services are provided to Brisbane to cater for visitors to World Expo 88?
—That one has been around for a while and I will need a few moments to find it. I will come back to it at the end with some detailed figures.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Did the Minister note the Treasurer's comments on the recent Channel 9 Sunday program regarding the new superannuation taxes? Did the Treasurer say that the changes announced last Wednesday represented a `snapshot' of the financial circumstances of superannuation funds at that time? Did he also imply that beneficiaries would not lose one cent so long as fund managers shifted all funds into tax sheltered investments which attract tax credits from the dividend imputation system? Does this inevitably mean that, if all fund managers shift to tax exempt investments, this would logically lead to reduced Government revenues? Did the Government include in its net revenue estimate of the changes, supposed to be $925m, any reduction in tax revenues as a result of a shift by fund managers to investments which attract tax imputation credits? If so, what was that amount?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of the question is wrong. That is, the presumption that, as superannuation funds move into buying equities that pay franked dividends, they will in that way, of course, be shifting their present lending to reducing the level of lending or property investment that they have and that that will be transferred to other sectors of the economy and tax paid on it is wrong. In regard to what the Treasurer said, I do not have a transcript of it, but I am willing to accept what Senator Messner has said. Incidentally, I did see the Sunday program and I think that Senator Messner, with tolerable accuracy, has summarised what the Treasurer said on the program a few days ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The term `snapshot', which I think was in fact used, is an appropriate term. The Opposition, of course, cannot conceive that other people will change their behaviour because the underlying realities have changed. Of course, now that the underlying realities have changed, fund managers will change their investment policies. That snapshot that was there last week will not be the snapshot that will exist six months hence or 12 months hence.

I know that it is extremely difficult for those in the Opposition to grasp the fact since their ideas never pay any account to what goes on in the real world and all the changes that have taken place in the real world. Their ideas, unchangeable, immutable, are like the ideas of the Bourbons; it is hard for them to understand that behaviour will change. They are not like John Keynes, who, when asked what he would do if he were presented with evidence that showed decisively that his beliefs or theories were wrong, said, `I would change my mind. What would you do?'. That is what we do, that is what fund managers do; it is not what the Opposition does. Apparently Senator Messner is still asserting, falsely, that there will be a loss of revenue to the Government as the superannuation funds change their investment policies, their relative holdings of equities and their debt or rental property. I will quote from a Treasury minute that was prepared on this subject, amongst others. It is, of course, correct. It says:

Any reductions in taxation revenue from superannuation funds arising from such portfolio shifts could be expected to be made up from those investors who acquire assets disposed of by the funds. As the return from those assets would generally be taxable in the hands of such investors, often at a higher rate, there would be no overall net loss to revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian which stated that in the May statement tax concessions for approved research and development had been reduced from 150 per cent to 100 per cent? Is the article correct? If not, can the Minister clarify the current position on the concession as it was announced last Wednesday? Further, if the article is not correct, is the Minister concerned that this type of article could create confusion and therefore have a detrimental effect on research and development in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that article, and as far as I am concerned it is a case where ignorance is not bliss. Journalists who know something about this subject would have known what was announced in the May statement in fact represents an extension and not a curtailment of research and development concessions. The newspaper to which Senator McMullan referred is not alone. The 150 per cent tax concession for research and development was introduced with a life of five years. The Government never introduced this with the intention that it should go beyond 30 June 1991. In the May statement the fact that it would continue to 30 June 1991 was reaffirmed. In addition to that, it was announced that post-1991 the taxation treatment of research and development would involve a 100 per cent concession; it would be treated as a normal business expense. That decision has been made and announced because people who make investments in research and development want to know what the tax treatment will be in several years to come and beyond 1991. That is the tax treatment side. There is no inhibition on the Government, as a result of any decisions made, treating research and development expenditure in different ways in terms of Budget outlays or so on, or having more targeted schemes, than the 150 per cent tax concession after 30 June 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: The other error which has appeared in newspapers relates to the management investment company scheme. That also was a scheme introduced last year with a sunset clause, again to run for a life of five years. Last year, following a report from the Bureau of Industry Economics on the management investment company scheme, it was announced that the scheme would continue to 30 June 1989. In the May statement it was announced that the scheme would now continue to 30 June 1991-again an extension of the scheme rather than a curtailment. I might say about all these things that it is no good putting them in place and saying that they will be there forever. It is essential that some environment of continuity be provided. I must say that both schemes were introduced when Australia had an appalling record on research and development. It was the lowest in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries during the life of the Fraser Government. It went beyond the Fraser Government; during that decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was also very low under the Whitlam Government.

—Yes, I said that, Senator-during that decade, which went beyond the period of that Government. The incentive was put there in order to try to redress the balance of that, and it really has had some success. I think a lot more can be done in the private sector in terms of research and development. Whether that incentive helps towards that in the remaining years remains to be seen. I believe it will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I shall speak slowly. I refer to the recent exploration agreement signed between Queensland Mines Ltd and the Northern Land Council which will allow Queensland Mines to exploit the second ore body at Nabarlek. I also refer to statements by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that the Government would consider a second ore body at Nabarlek to be a new mine. I understand that Queensland Mines has an option until August to extend its existing uranium contracts with France for an additional two years. In the light of the above and of the Government's present position of not allowing any new contracts to France, I ask the Minister: Firstly, has the Government consented to the new exploration agreement? Secondly, does the Government still consider that a second ore body at Nabarlek would be a new mine? Thirdly, does the Government consider that an extension of Queensland Mines' contracts with France, which would allow supply from the new ore body, to be new contracts or existing contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall have to answer this question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The first thing to say is that I do not know that it can be said that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has said that he would consider a second ore body as a new mine at Nabarlek. I think that inherent in the preface to the honourable senator's question was an assumption that that would be the case. The whole issue of mining at Nabarlek, in its present location where there is a mine or in some other location in the general Nabarlek area, is a matter that the Minister has before him presently and will decide on shortly. So I do not know whether the presumption is an accurate one.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me go to the first question, which was: Has the Government consented to the new exploration agreement? I have some difficulty with that question because it seems to me there is again confusion in terms of what are the jurisdictions of the Commonwealth and what are the jurisdictions of the Northern Territory Government. My understanding is that the Northern Territory Government is considering, or it may have recently made an announcement-and if it has, it would have done so very recently-whether it will conclude an exploration agreement with Queensland Mines. But my understanding is also that in terms of the Nabarlek area there is a mining lease, which is designated mining lease 94, and that is the site where mining takes place. There is also an exploration lease, designated exploration lease 2508. It seems to me that there is a presumption in the question that an exploration lease equates with a mining lease, and I do not think that that is a presumption that can be made either.

That is all I can say about the first question at this stage. I intend to clarify that as soon as I possibly can, because obviously there is some information there that is different from the presumption the honourable senator has made, and I want to be certain that the answer I have given him is 100 per cent right.

In terms of the second question-`Does the Government still consider that a second ore body at Nabarlek would be a new mine?'-as I have said before, that is a matter that the Minister has in front of him and will answer in due course.

The answer to the third question, about contracts, is dependent on the answer to the second question and therefore must be hypothetical at this stage, given that the Minister has not answered the proposition the honourable senator entertains in his second question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister, Mr Kerin, make a decision before the Australian Labor Party National Conference?
—The Minister will make a decision at the appropriate time.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to his address yesterday to the Australian Institute of Criminology seminar on police resources and effectiveness. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the increased accountability he has called for from police will increase police effectiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —An address I was to give yesterday to the Australian Institute of Criminology seminar on police resources and effectiveness was delivered, but it was delivered on my behalf because of my duties in the chamber. The address dealt with the accountability of police forces for the use of their resources, which are voted to them by Parliament. I believe that a critical juncture has been reached in relation to Federal law enforcement in that regard. The Government has provided law enforcement agencies with many legislative weapons and new and innovative schemes to combat organised crime and, of course, has provided considerable financial resources. We are now in the process of assessing the overall performance of our agencies and how they should properly develop in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: The law enforcement policy review which the Attorney-General and I initiated at the beginning of the year is examining a number of matters which are crucial to this assessment: for example, whether the total law enforcement effort is being co-ordinated as well as it can be to achieve clear goals; whether the present roles of agencies will continue to be appropriate into the next decades; and the proper relationship between the Commonwealth and the States in law enforcement. Many of those matters have already been touched on in the reports of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority that have been tabled recently in this chamber. That Committee has reported on both the National Crime Authority and its relationship with State law enforcement agencies and the question of witness protection, where once again coordination and cooperation between various jurisdictions is a key element.

It is very important-I know Senator Hill shares this view-that law enforcement agencies have a line of accountability to the people through the Minister. It is important that police agencies, in particular the Australian Federal Police (AFP), be brought more clearly into a policy relationship with the Minister, which I believe would enhance their role. If the Minister is to get far-sighted advice from police, we need to have a more sophisticated dialogue with police, involving increased ministerial input into corporate planning, objectives and capabilities and rigorous scrutiny of police performance than has been the case in the past. I believe that the community is prepared to make considerable resources available to its law enforcement agencies but wants to know that it is getting value for its dollar. I believe that this closer scrutiny by the Minister concerned of the expenditure of moneys by law enforcement agencies will help the community in that regard.

Police organisations and law enforcement agencies in general need to be tested further as to the use to which they put resources within general limits of policy set by the Government. Honourable senators will know that a general charter has been given to the Federal Police. However, it is important that we come to a clear understanding that the moneys and resources devoted to achieving the objectives of that charter are deployed to the best degree. I am greatly encouraged by the attitude to these issues of the AFP Commissioner, Mr McAulay. The Commissioner and his senior officers recognise that a number of past assumptions need to be questioned and tested. It is in the long term interests of the force to do so. The quality of the AFP's participation in the law enforcement policy review establishes a very good model for the sort of effective consultation to which I am looking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the recently commenced Queensland satellite television station that is offering rural Queensland a much awaited and excellent commercial channel. Is the Minister aware of an application lodged by the Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Media Association with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal advocating an increase of Aboriginal programming from 80 hours a year to 600 hours a year and including a request to vary the present conditions of the Queensland satellite television licence which would prohibit NQTV from holding more than 50 per cent of the licence? In view of the fact that NQTV broadcasters have committed $2.8m of investors' funds already and that the Queensland Government has appropriated $2.5m a year of taxpayers' money to subsidise the service, will the Minister, on behalf of the Government, make a submission to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal rejecting the ambit claim of the Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Media Association?

—I am aware of the application in question. I have discussed it with the senior management of the station involved. On the face of it, the claim by the group referred to can, to put it most charitably, be described as an ambit one. Beyond that I do not think it is appropriate for the Government to be making submissions on these matters to the Tribunal. The Tribunal is an independent authority that is acutely conscious of the statutory criteria that it is obliged to apply in terms of viability and the capacity of a station to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. Under those circumstances, I have taken the view that the Tribunal should be left to deal with the competing merits of the claim in question without any involvement by the Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. I refer to the fact that one in five young people in Australia cannot get work and that in the area of work for which the Minister now has responsibility-namely, the Public Service-the percentage of the work force represented by young people has declined dramatically, from around 22 per cent in 1966 to around 5 per cent now. In the last year for which I have been able to get figures there has been a further actual drop in the number of full time young employee in the Public Service. Bearing in mind the repeated questions that I have asked in the Senate about this matter and the stated commitment of the Government to give priority to young people, can the Minister advise what action the Government is now taking, first to reveal to the Senate the true picture of youth employment in the Public Service and, secondly, to ensure that youth get their fair share of Public Service jobs?

—I certainly bear in mind the number of times Senator Harradine has asked this question. I also bear in mind the number of times I have answered it. It may be that the figures to which Senator Harradine referred today are slightly different from the ones he used in his questions of six months ago, 12 months ago, 18 months ago and so on. I will seek to obtain an answer about the figures and the Government's response to them. I imagine that the response will not have changed much in the sense that, as Senator Harradine will recall I have said on other occasions, the nature of the Public Service functions, training arrangements and so on has changed significantly, which has affected the percentage of young people recruited into the Public Service. But I will get the figures for Senator Harradine and give him an answer as soon as possible.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that the new superannuation taxation provisions will encourage fund managers to move into equity stocks providing fully franked dividends, thereby giving an unhealthy price rise to blue chip stocks at the expense of the more productive investments, including Commonwealth bonds? Will he also confirm that self-employed persons who have geared up a private superannuation arrangement in the last few years will not be worse off under the new arrangements if they seek to retire within the next 12 to 18 months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I remember all the parts of the question. In regard to those funds which are light on for equities which pay franked dividends and have a high dividend payout policy, there will be-and this is deliberate-an incentive for superannuation funds to move into them. I do not think that necessarily means moving into blue chip. The most attractive type of equity for such funds to move into is equity in a company which has a policy of either paying out dividends-high dividend payouts-or, alternatively franked bonus shares, which could also be used by the superannuation fund in order to adjust its tax liability.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot think of any reason in the changes-I will seek confirmation of this point-that would disadvantage self-employed people's superannuation arrangements having regard to their position prior to last week. I can think of two changes made last week which will advantage such people: firstly, the increase from $1,500 to $3,000 in the amount that they may pay into a fund on their own behalf; and, secondly, if a lump sum scheme is involved, even after the adjustment for the lower rate, there would be the threshold for the exempt area. What was the 15 per cent or 16 1/4 per cent rate has been lifted from $55,000 to $60,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports this week that the Government of Mozambique requires food aid this year on a greater per capita basis than that needed in Ethiopia. Has the Australian Government been approached to help provide part of the 914,000 tonnes of cereal grains and other foods reportedly required? If so, what has been the response of the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been reports in a number of papers this week continuing to draw attention to the emergency in Mozambique. Mozambique and Ethiopia are the largest recipients of Australian emergency assistance to African states. Economic and social conditions in Mozambique have led to severe food and other shortages and large scale displacement of people. It is estimated that 3.3 million people require emergency assistance. Mozambique's estimated 1988-89 food import requirement of approximately 900,000 tonnes will have to be met by donor food aid.

ANSWER.PARA: On 31 March this year the United Nations Secretary-General launched a further appeal for humanitarian assistance to Mozambique, totalling $US380m. There has been a strong response by the international community, with over $US270m pledged to date. Australia provided $7.3m in aid to Mozambique in 1986-87, and in 1987-88 has committed approximately $11.4m, including assistance to Mozambican refugees in Malawi and Mozambican returnees. The break-up is as follows-$7m in emergency aid, of which $4.76m is in food aid, $1m is to the World Food Program, the United Nations Children's Fund and International Committee of the Red Cross relief operations, $500,000 is to a special appeal of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for assistance to Mozambican returnees and refugees in Malawi, as I mentioned a moment ago, $500,000 is to Austcare for the distribution of clothing to Mozambican refugees in Malawi, and $0.24m is provided through Australian non-government organisation projects. In addition, $4.4m is provided in rehabilitation and developmental aid. It is the case that further emergency assistance will be considered in 1988-89. Mozambique will also receive approximately a further $12.5m in development aid, including food aid, under the current Australian three-year program for southern Africa of $100m in toto, which extends to 1990-91.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Without canvassing the merits or otherwise of the Labor proposal to impose an extra tax on many who receive tertiary education, when did the Government post material to 400,000 tertiary students, advising of the details of this matter? What was the material that was sent to them? Will the Minister make that material available to honourable senators? What did it cost to produce? What did it cost to post the material? How does the Government justify spending probably more than a quarter of a million dollars on this lobbying exercise at present?

—I cannot answer any of those questions. I did not know anything had been posted out, but I assume now that it has been. I was asked what was in it and whether it will be made available. If it has been posted out to 400,000 people I should not think there would be any problem in making the material available to the Senate. I will refer the other questions to Mr Dawkins.

—I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Given that the boobook owl of Norfolk Island is now represented by a sole surviving female, can the Minister inform us of the success of dalliance, if any, between this owl and two male New Zealand boobooks brought to the island last spring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Black for giving me an opportunity to keep the Senate informed on this matter. I know that honourable senators have taken a real interest in it. Senator Puplick raised this question with me a couple of weeks ago and asked that, as soon as possible, I give a progress report. Unlike most of the things I say in the Senate, today's report will not be about a result of much substance. We are talking about delays and monitoring once again. We had hoped that after a whirlwind courtship there would have been a traditional happy event. The female, whose name is Miamiti, which is a Pitcairn Island word meaning sweetheart or lover, has not lived up to her name. The night of Tuesday, 24 May, was a big night on Norfolk Island. The highlight of the year was a boobook owl listening night. After listening, people heard two boobooks calling. We cannot be sure whether that meant much because it was still two months off breeding season. A check of the nesting box revealed a single feather.
—You were arousing them.

—This may not be Bill's Big Banana, but it is important. The male, who is called Fletcher after Fletcher Christian, the Bounty mutineer who sired a prolific line on Pitcairn Island, survived a courtship with another boobook. In New Zealand they call them moreporks. As Fletcher survived a courtship with a female who had eaten her previous mate and lived to breed prolifically with her, we hold out great hopes for the future. I hope we can report successfully on the boobook owl in September. I know that Senator Puplick will be anxious that I complete that report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. Is it a fact, as reported in the Press, that Mr Hugh Hudson has handed to the Minister his report on coastal surveillance? Is it a fact that Mr Hudson has recommended that aerial surveillance of northern Australia be reduced? Is it a fact that Mr Hudson has further recommended that the coordination of coastal surveillance be given to the Australian Customs Service in lieu of the Australian Federal Police? In view of widespread concern as to the effectiveness of Australian coastal surveillance, which concern would not be lessened by such recommendations, will the Minister table the report? Would the Minister not agree, given the fact that the Department of Defence extends considerable air and sea support and carries over 60 per cent of coastal surveillance costs, that there is not a good case for this coordination function to be given to the Department of Defence?

—The answer to Senator Hill's first question is yes. The answers to questions 2, 3 and 4 is: wait until the Cabinet makes a decision and we will let him know. The answer to question 5 is no. The answer to question 6 is: refer to answers to questions 2, 3 and 4.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to the report on economic issues and work-related child-care prepared by the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University (ANU) and its evidence that the current child-care funding can have a net cost to the Budget far less than the gross cost of $222m in 1987-88? Is it possible that the Government's children's services program (CSP) could actually save taxpayers more than it costs? Do these figures support the Government's initiatives in its child-care programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to those questions are yes, yes and yes. In anticipation that I may have been asked this question I have a brief from the relevant Minister, and I shall proceed to enlarge on these answers. On Monday the Minister for Community Services and Health released a report prepared by the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the ANU. The report was entitled, `Government Spending on Work Related Child Care-Some Economic Issues'. It effectively endorses the general direction of the Government's child-care policy. Preliminary results from the study commissioned by the Federal Government have shown that Commonwealth funding for child-care costs considerably less in real terms than it first appears and could indeed save taxpayers more than it costs. This financial year $190m will be spent on the provision of care for nought to four-year-old children of families where a sole parent or both parents are in the work force. In fact, the study concludes that the benefits of Government expenditure in child-care are obtained for a considerably lesser amount in real terms.

ANSWER.PARA: Work force participation of parents whose children use government-funded services produces extra taxation revenue, savings in dependent spouse rebate and savings on income support payments to families. This fiscal benefit to government could be as high as $296m-$106m more than the $190m to be spent on work-related child-care in 1987-88. The actual amount of fiscal return and therefore the actual cost of CSP depends on the number of net additional jobs created in the work force as a result of child-care provision. It should be noted that in the last five years women have filled 570,000 new jobs. Less than 10 per cent of these jobs would have had to be created and filled as a result of child-care funding for the program to have no net cost to the Government. More than this, child-care funding facilitates the ability of employers to find workers in areas where women are concentrated and employment growth is strong; a consistent approach to the formation and maintenance of skills in the Australian work force, ensuring that Australia has the skills necessary for long term economic and employment growth; and-Senator Crowley will be interested to know-success in helping sole parent families and others dependent on income support to enter the work force and thus remove children from poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I remind the Minister of the details I provided to him of an audit report on the Wangkatjurngka Aboriginal community during debate in committee on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which indicated misappropriations of goods and services from that community by the project officer, Mr Peter Ross. What action has been taken in respect of this matter and against Mr Ross in particular? Is it a fact that Mr Ross is presently employed as a project officer at Christmas Creek and, accordingly, in receipt of taxpayers' money? Was concern expressed to the Department at Mr Ross's subsequent appointment at Christmas Creek?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Crichton-Browne raising the matter of several audit reports in relation to Aboriginal communities in Western Australia, including the Wangkatjurngka Aboriginal community. I apologise to that community for not being able immediately to correctly pronounce its name. I was given short notice of the possible question by Senator Crichton-Browne. I have received some information from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to which I will refer. The audit report referred to by Senator Crichton-Browne in that committee stage debate was for the 1985-86 financial year. I do not think that that was absolutely clear at the time of the debate-he may have made it clear but it certainly was not clear in the question. The community was requested to introduce controls to ensure that proper financial procedures were in place as a result of that very critical report. It is important to note that the audit report for 1986-87 made no reference to poor purchasing procedures. I think that was the essence of the complaint in the first report.

ANSWER.PARA: The person referred to by Senator Crichton-Browne, Mr Ross, was advised, at the time of the review coming out of the audit concerns, to strictly adhere to proper purchasing procedures in any future purchases. I am advised by the Minister that no action was taken against Mr Ross at that time as it was doubtful that he had acted with intent to defraud the community. It is understood, I am advised, that the purchases referred to were not made using Commonwealth funds. So they are the matters that arose out of the audit report.

I am further asked: Is it a fact that Mr Ross is presently employed as a project officer at Christmas Creek and accordingly received taxpayers' money by way of salary? The answer to that is no. Mr Ross is no longer employed at Christmas Creek. His employment was terminated by the community in mid-1987; that is almost a year ago. The third question was: Was concern expressed to the Department at Mr Ross's subsequent appointment to Christmas Creek? Obviously it is unclear exactly how to answer that, given the fact that question No. 2 has been answered as it has. But it is important to emphasise that Mr Ross was not appointed subsequent to the audit report of 1985-86, but was in fact an employee at the time of the report. As stated earlier, his employment was subsequently terminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The audit report was unqualified in its observations that goods and services had been taken by Mr Ross for his own personal benefit and gain and paid for by the community, not the least being 34 cartons of beer. He used aircraft without accounting for their use. The report also said that food was misappropriated. I ask: What action has been taken with respect to those goods, which ultimately are paid for by the taxpayers, because the community survives and exists on taxpayers' funds?

—I can only repeat that the brief I have been provided with by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs states that it is understood that the purchases referred to were not made using Commonwealth funds. I do not have anything further to add, but I may be able to seek further information in relation to the matter. If the Minister is able to provide it, I am sure that he will make it available to Senator Crichton-Browne. But I think it needs to be emphasised, as it was in the committee stage debate, that it is important that in any community, including Aboriginal communities which are operating on the basis of appropriations of money, votes of money, by this Parliament-taxpayers' money-steps are taken to ensure that proper management practices are in place. This not only protects the taxpayer, but I think, as was made clear in that debate, also has the very positive social effect of protecting the reputation of the community in the country town that might be associated with it, because quite often these bad management practices can lead to a lot of ill will in those communities.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of the practice by some overseas telex directory suppliers of sending what appear to be invoices for unsolicited entries in their publications to Australian businesses? What is the Government doing to protect Australian businesses from this practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov raises a question which not only was raised here before but which, in the intervening period since it was raised, has had a number of interesting developments. The problem she refers to is one where demands for payment for a service which has never been ordered and never been met, especially to small business, have been made by companies, particularly those companies operating overseas and often in relation to telex directory assistance. In the last couple of months since the issue was raised in the Senate, there have been a couple of developments. For a start, the companies and the countries from which this blowing operation has been operating have expanded from countries such as Switzerland, Germany and Liechtenstein to now include the United Kingdom as well as Singapore. In the past, most people who have been approached have been in small businesses. I now know that Senator Cook and I have been approached-Senator Tate has also said that he has been approached-by companies sending bogus accounts. In my case I was sent an account for my subscription to Work and Patrol Boat World-which I had never known about-and in Senator Cook's case, he was sent an account for a world telex edition from London. The hidden factor in that, of course, is that not only was he sent an account but also he was told that if he does not stop renewal in 12 months time he will keep on getting accounts.

ANSWER.PARA: Even though this sort of operation is covered by the Trade Practices Act, as I have mentioned before, the companies that operate these sorts of scams conduct all their operations and have all their assets overseas. Whereas we may be able to prosecute them theoretically, we have no real recourse, in terms of the action that we can take, to stop them from continuing their operations. However, we have approached the matter both diplomatically, externally, and domestically through an advertising campaign run by the Trade Practices Commission entitled `Don't be bitten by a blower'. That campaign is directed very much to small business and, from all accounts, has been quite effective. We have had some success in our diplomatic campaign. We have approached the matter through Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development channels but, more recently, the Swiss Government has approached us and it is looking at Trade Practices Act provision in Australia to see whether it can amend its legislation to ensure that protection can be made available in that country.

It is a problem which is growing. From the number of members of parliament who have been approached in this matter, I think it is just as well that we are as aware of it in this place as small businesses in the wider Australian community are.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXATION: SUPERANNUATION FUNDS AND APPROVED DEPOSIT FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it not a fact that the introduction of a 15 per cent tax on net earnings of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds will have a catastrophic effect on small fund holders because of, first, the removal of the tax-free status of the pre-1983 content of superannuation funds, secondly, the removal of the tax-free threshold of superannuation payouts indirectly, and, thirdly, because many risk-conscious funds will not be able to switch from interest investments to equity investments?

—I do not know why they could not. If they are so totally risk averse, I suppose, they would not do anything other than buy Commonwealth Government bonds. I was asked whether it was a fact that all those things were going to happen. No, it is not a fact.

—Will the Minister for Justice inform the Senate of what measures any of the States have instigated to prevent further deaths of Aboriginals in custody? Is the Minister satisfied with current progress in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The various jurisdictions around Australia, including the Commonwealth, have been involved in considerable consultation with interested groups-including Aboriginal groups, obviously-in relation to a proposal put forward by the Australian Police Ministers Council, known as a draft summary of practices and procedures, in order to try to combat the undoubted tragic incidence of deaths in custody, particularly those deaths amongst Aboriginals. At previous meetings the Council had put forward this summary for the purpose of engaging in consultation, which will continue. But it was pleasing to note that at the Council meeting only last week in Brisbane, the Council was able to look at its draft of measures to combat the incidence of Aboriginal deaths in custody and it found that, in many ways, its earliest thoughts took account of the sorts of matters which have commended themselves to bodies such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which itself has put out a document in that regard, and the recommendations of the Aboriginal police workshop, which I opened, held at the Australian Police Staff College in Manly in December 1987. The draft guidelines for the prevention of Aboriginal deaths in custody, issued by the Muirhead Royal Commission, are also broadly consistent with the guidelines that the Australian Police Ministers Council has commended to the various jurisdictions around Australia and I know that consultation is taking place in relation to those guidelines.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators would know, it is not simply a matter of trying to deal with the problem of an Aboriginal in custody perhaps being vulnerable to the possibility of death. What is required is a system of diversionary procedures, or facilities, so that Aboriginals are not detained or remanded in custody for intoxication or other minor offences unless the offender is violent or the offences are likely to continue. In conjunction with the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Police Ministers Council is taking the view that in relation to those offences where violence is not likely to be a feature, it would be wise to find some diversionary method rather than putting Aboriginals in detention, and, if detention is required, certainly bail or surety procedures should be instituted as soon as possible.

It is also very important, obviously, that if an Aboriginal, or indeed any person, is in detention and shows any sign of mental or physical distress, a medical examination should take place at the earliest practicable opportunity. We believe that these matters, quite apart from the questions of the nature of the cell and the detention to which the Aboriginal is subject, are very important. I believe that the draft summary of practices and procedures, put out by the Australian Police Ministers Council and confirmed by it last week, will provide a very sound basis for further consultations with Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Now that it has been decided by the Government that the War Crimes Amendment Bill be stood over until at least the Budget session, I ask: How much has been spent on the war crimes investigations in anticipation of the Bill being passed? In view of the cost and the very damaging and disruptive effects these investigations are having among the more than 500,000 post-war migrants from Germany and eastern Europe, will the Minister restrain any further investigative activity until this Parliament has decided whether it wants the Bill and, if so, in what form?

—Obviously, the war crimes legislation cannot be passed in this session of the Parliament but it will be considered for passage at the time of the Budget session. The war crimes investigation being undertaken at the moment by Mr Greenwood and the special unit that has been set up for that purpose had its estimates reviewed by the Senate Estimates committee a matter of three or four weeks ago. I do not have the figures at my fingertips at the moment but I am sure that they are readily available and I will ensure that they are made available to Senator Hamer as soon as possible. The work of the special investigations unit, under Mr Greenwood, is intended to continue in order to be ready should the Parliament decide to pass the war crimes legislation. There will not be a cessation, a cutting off or a termination of its activity over the winter months as we await the Budget session.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is it correct that the Queensland State Government is the only government which has not endorsed the proposals outlined in the Commonwealth Schools Commission report entitled A National Policy for the Education of Girls in Australian Schools? If so, what reason has been given for the Queensland Government's failure to endorse the report? Has this meant that, once again, Queensland is falling behind in the implementation of effective policy for improving the education of girls in Queensland schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is true that Queensland is the only State not to endorse the national policy for the education of girls in Australian schools, which of course was endorsed by the Australian Education Council in September last year. I remind honourable senators that the endorsement is shared by the National Council of Independent Schools and the National Catholic Education Commission. Of course, it has been welcomed by all teachers unions. Queensland does not recognise the national policy, although there is a report that indicates that it will implement such elements of it as fit with its philosophy. Knowing the philosophy of the Queensland Government in relation to education issues, I would not have any great confidence in relation to the implementation of any aspect of the policy. I quote an extract from the Queensland Teachers Union Journal, which stated:

ANSWER.PARA: In reality the Education Department in Queensland is the only one which has not actively implemented strategies to ensure the provision of non-sexist education.
I think Senator Walsh will be interested in this:

In fact, the only Departmental project which developed resource material for use in schools was the Commonwealth funded `On Cue' project. Some $70,000 was expended on the project which developed a set of excellent resource booklets.

I understand, however, that the Queensland Education Department has refused to distribute the booklet to schools. That indicates that not only is the Queensland Government not prepared to cooperate with the Commonwealth in relation to its policies for the education of girls, but also it is prepared to go to the lengths of expending money provided by the Commonwealth and then to have those booklets just sitting on shelves, which I am sure everyone would agree is quite disgraceful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time Senator Burns asked me a question about additional international air services to Brisbane to cater for visitors to World Expo 88. I am now in a position to answer that question with some up to date information. The provision of additional airline capacity to cater for the expected high demand into Brisbane during Expo is being facilitated through the approval of supplementary scheduled services and passenger charter flights. International passenger charter policy guidelines announced by me last October are well suited to facilitate the operation of charter flights for special events such as Expo.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government gave prompt approval for Royal Brunei Airlines to operate three charters to Brisbane in May. We will give swift consideration to any other applications which are designed specifically to promote Expo. A number of schedule carriers such as British Airways, Air New Zealand and Air Caledonie will increase services to Brisbane to cater for tourists wishing to visit Expo. Qantas Airways Ltd alone will provide almost 3,500 extra seats per week to Brisbane in operating a total of 30 weekly flights from New Zealand, Japan and Singapore, as well as regular services from Manila, Port Moresby and Fiji.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 May Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question about the Government's intentions concerning the commemoration of the sixtieth anniversary of Charles Kingsford Smith's trans-Pacific flight. I would like to add to the very brief reply I gave on that occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators no doubt will be aware, on the evening of 8 June 1928 the Southern Cross landed at Ballina following a flight of 83 hours and 11 minutes from California involving two stops, at Hawaii and Fiji. On board the aircraft were Charles Kingsford Smith as pilot, Charles Ulm as co-pilot and two United States organisers, Jim Warner and Harry Lyons, as navigator and radio operator respectively. The next morning the aircraft flew on to Brisbane's Eagle Farm. On 10 June it flew to Sydney's Mascot Airport.

I am pleased to be able to advise Senator Bjelke-Petersen and other interested honourable senators that the Federal Government will assist in commemorating this historic flight. My colleague Peter Morris will be flying aboard a replica of the Southern Cross on Thursday morning, 9 June, from Ballina to Brisbane Airport. It is planned that the landing will take place at the precise anniversary time of 10.13 a.m. and that the replica aircraft will taxi to the point nearest the building housing and displaying the real Southern Cross. The Southern Cross Trust, builders and operators of the replica Southern Cross aircraft are receiving assistance from the Department of the Arts and Territories and my Department to recreate the arrival element of the trans-Pacific flight. Moreover, the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, plans to meet the aircraft on arrival at Mascot on Friday, 10 June.

All Australians value the memory of the significant contribution that Charles Kingsford Smith, Charles Ulm and their colleagues made to world aviation. I believe that the recreation of the latter stages of that historic trans-Pacific flight on its sixtieth anniversary is a fitting way of commemorating the flight in question. I hope that it will receive the support of Senator Bjelke-Petersen and all Australians.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION ORDER

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the ninth report for 1988 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988, the Audit Amendment Bill 1988, the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill 1988 and the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 9, dated 1 June 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate a short statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Committee has not commented in this week's Alert Digest on a number of Bills which may conveniently be described as the `corporations package' introduced into the Parliament last week by the Attorney-General. These Bills are lengthy, complex and far-reaching in their intended effect. The Committee has asked its legal adviser and the Committee Secretary to study the Bills during the winter break. The Committee will report on the Bills in the budget session.

The Committee's Ninth Report for 1988, which I have just tabled, is the last report for the present sittings, and is the final report that the Committee will table for the consideration of the Senate in the provisional Parliament House. The present Committee, several of who are new members of the Committee, has striven over the last year to continue the record of careful, considered examination and comment on legislation which was the outstanding hallmark of the Committee under the chairmanship of my predecessors; the late Senator Alan Missen, the present Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, and Senator Rosemary Crowley.

As Honourable Senators are aware, the Committee examines every Bill introduced into the Parliament to ensure that provisions of proposed laws of the Commonwealth which may improperly affect or prejudice the individual rights of citizens, or seek to reduce the primary law-making role of Parliament, are drawn to Senators' attention.

The Committee goes to some length to ensure, via its Alert Digests that, within a very short time frame, based on sound legal advice, comment is available to Senators to enable informed consideration of the import and effect of Bills before the Parliament.

The Committee ensures that, following tabling of each week's Alert Digest, its comments are immediately communicated to responsible Ministers. It is disappointing to the Committee that the time taken by Ministers to respond to the Committee's comments has progressively increased over the last year. In the case of the majority of comments made so far in this year's Alert Digests, the Committee has yet to receive a reply from Ministers. The Committee is concerned at this development, as Committee members strongly believe that informed comment on legislation before the Parliament has been, and will continue to be, assisted and enhanced not only by the Committee's reports, but also by the willingness and readiness of Ministers to co-operate with the Committee by responding fully, and promptly, the Committee's comment.

As a Committee we acknowledge that several Ministers have acted to amend a number of Bills this year, following comment on specific provisions by the Committee. I am pleased to note that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, and the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, have recently moved to amend clauses of Bills which have been the subject of comments by the Committee.

As the chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and as a former chairman of the Standing Committee for Regulations and Ordinances, I am proud of the constructive and genuinely bipartisan approach of the Senate's Legislative Scrutiny Committees. Careful avoidance of questions of policy or the relative merit of legislation that is examined by it, and an emphasis on technical scrutiny of particular clauses of Bills strongly underpins the Committee's concern that legislation is consistent, fair and above all gives primacy both to the rights and liberties of the individual, and to the law-making role of the Parliament.

I will not take up the time of the Senate further with a number of current areas of concern to the Committee and areas of legislative practice which it believes should be drawn to Senators' attention. The Committee will deal with these issues in detail in its 1987-88 Annual Report. I finally thank my fellow Committee members for their application (and occasional forbearance) over the last year and pay special tribute to all honourable senators, past and present, who have served as members of the Committee in this House.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I suggest that it might suit the convenience of the Senate if there were to be a cognate debate on the May economic statement package of Bills, that is to say, Orders of the Day Nos 6 to 13, the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill 1988, the Migration Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1988, the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-roll Tax) Amendment Bill 1988, the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill 1988, the National Health Amendment Bill 1988, the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988, the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988, as in effect was provided for in the guillotine motion.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) has just indicated, we are debating 10 Bills-the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill 1988 and cognate Bills, including a package of three departure tax Bills. Of course, we are doing so in the context of the economic statement brought down in the House of Representatives last Wednesday night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We are debating these Bills under guillotine-the guillotine motion approved and, indeed, made possible only by approval of the Australian Democrats. This will require us to complete the debate on these 10 Bills and the associated remarks on the economic statement itself by 7 o'clock this evening. Therefore, I want to begin my remarks on the Bills by making some comments about procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: We should note that this economic statement was brought into the House of Representatives last Wednesday night, 25 May. The Government has been aware of the need for this statement, or some statement of this kind, for at least seven months, that is, shortly after the crash on the stock markets and the immediately following crash on the foreign exchange markets of last October. The Government has been aware that it would need to repair its failing and flawed economic policy by some such statement of this kind. It has delayed seven months in doing so. It had deliberately chosen-I emphasise the words `deliberately chosen'-to do so on the second last sitting night of the House of Representatives, with the Senate also having only a week further to go in its sittings and with a vast amount of legislation already on its timetable. Of course, there was no real opportunity-I repeat, no real opportunity-for the Treasurer's economic statement or these 10 Bills to be debated in the House of Representatives. That results directly from the Government's deliberate decision to delay their introduction until, I think, 30 hours before the House of Representatives rose for the winter recess.

The reply in the other place by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) took place on the Thursday evening, the night following the statement by the Treasurer. Following the reply of the Leader of the Opposition at 8 o'clock that evening the 10 Bills were guillotined through the House of Representatives in the space of the following five hours. The House adjourned at 1.33 a.m. on Friday, 27 May. I cannot find words sufficiently forceful to describe my cynicism over the whole process of `government'-I put the word `government' in quotation marks-as operated by this present Government. I note in passing that that is also what this Government did in the week before, with its four referendum proposal Bills. It rammed them, too, through the House of Representatives. These are Bills to change the Constitution of this country, not just pieces of statute legislation. They are Bills designed to change the Constitution of this country, and if approved by the electorate they will do so. Those Bills were rammed through the House of Representatives in the space of a single day's debate.

What, incidentally, did we in this place subsequently find? The Senate, prior to today at least, considers Bills thoroughly. My colleague Senator Vanstone found late last week a major flaw in one of those Bills, a Bill relating to so-called fair elections, which would have had unintended consequences. We should call Government members `the Cabinet for unintended consequences'. The Government then proposed to amend that Bill but found subsequently that there were flaws in its own amendment. It found this sometime between Monday of this week and today. This morning we witnessed that Bill also being guillotined through the Senate with the full support, indeed the essential connivance, of the Australian Democrats on the basis of amendments moved not by the Government of this country but by the Democrats.

I return to the economic statement of last week, which is in two parts. The first part, the macro-economic one, deals with such issues as budgetary policy and the like. The other, the micro-economic part, deals with so-called structural adjustment aspects. I have a number of rather critical things to say about the Treasurer's statement but I will begin by saying that there is nevertheless much in it which I welcome. For example, I welcome the Treasurer's indication that in the coming financial year, 1988-89, he proposes to budget for a surplus which he has described as being in excess of $3,000m. I note in passing, however, that that will not be a supreme test for the Treasurer since at present, as he knows perfectly well, he is looking at a prospective Budget surplus in the next financial year of the order of $4,000m. I welcome the fact that prospective Budget outlays for 1988-89 do provide for a cut, on the Treasurer's estimates, of 1 1/2 per cent in real terms. But, as I will demonstrate later, that is not because of any cuts in the Commonwealth's own spending programs. I welcome without reservation the major cut in the corporate tax rate from 49 per cent at present to 39 per cent for the financial year 1988-89. I also welcome a number of other more detailed aspects of the statement, which I do not have time this afternoon to enumerate.

Subject to that preamble my overall reaction to the statement is one of disappointment, at best, and much more than mere disappointment in certain major respects. In particular, the expenditure cuts which will bring about the Treasurer's estimated 1 1/2 per cent reduction in real Commonwealth budgetary outlays in 1988-89 are virtually wholly attributable to cuts that the Commonwealth has now imposed on the funds which it makes available to the States and to a minor degree to the local authorities in that year. There is an almost total absence of equivalent cuts in the Commonwealth's own spending programs, and I think that lies at the heart of the failure of the Treasurer's statement last Wednesday night.

Of the total spending cuts of $982m in 1988-89, which are listed in last Wednesday's statement, no less than $920m is accounted for by cuts in the general revenue grants to the States, cuts in the equivalent general revenue grants to local authorities and cuts in Commonwealth funding to the States for roads. In net terms Commonwealth Ministers have barely touched, to the extent of only $62m net, their own spending programs. As we all know, the inevitable result of this limp-wristed approach by Commonwealth Ministers to their own empires, their own spending bureaucracies, has been that there will not be any cuts in personal income tax for Australians for another 13 months, at least until July 1989-if then.

Since last Wednesday the Treasurer and Senator Walsh have been arguing that it would be wrong to cut taxes and thereby, as they argue, stimulate domestic demand and imports and therefore worsen the already extremely poor state of our balance of payments. So it would be wrong if that were all we were talking about. The Treasurer, by advancing such arguments and suggesting that is all we are talking about is, however, quite deliberately distorting the debate. Clearly it is not all we are talking about. On the contrary. We propose that the Government should start cutting its own spending and thereby provide itself with scope to cut taxes now while at the same time leaving its prospective surplus unchanged. As a matter of fact, that process of cutting Government spending and making an equivalent cut, and no more than an equivalent cut, in personal income taxes would produce on balance and in the first instance a slightly depressing effect upon total demand. That is exactly what the Treasurer has said in several public statements since that time-he thinks is now appropriate. While we wait another 13 months or perhaps more for our tax cuts, the usual forces of fiscal drag, as the economists call it, or bracket creep, as it is called as it becomes more a part of the everyday lexicon, inexorably push many Australians into higher tax brackets. For example a rise in wage and salary incomes of let us say 7 per cent in the next financial year, which seems at least likely, would through this income tax multiplier effect lead to a rise of around 12 per cent in pay as you earn tax receipts.

The Treasurer has also told us that the size of the 1989-90 tax cuts will be determined by the size of the wage increases that occur next financial year, 1988-89. In other words the bigger the wage increases, the smaller the tax cuts. The truth is that the wage push by the trade unions is already up and running. Indeed the Government is already locked into supporting at least-I emphasise the words `at least'-an increase in money wages equal to inflation in the year ahead.

The Government is also making some highly over blown claims in relation to inflation. It is claiming that in 1988-89 the consumer price index (CPI) will rise by only 5 per cent, taking the year as a whole, and by only 4 1/2 per cent between the June quarter of this year and the June quarter of 1989. Frankly I regard that as a pipe dream. The fact is that the CPI has risen by 6.9 per cent, almost 7 per cent, in the 12 months to the March quarter of this year. The only question is whether, when the June quarter CPI figures are released towards the end of July, the 12-month figure to the end of the June quarter will go up or down. It is as finely balanced as that.

But let us be very optimistic and assume that the CPI does go down slightly so that the inflation rate for the year to the June quarter is, let us say, 6.5 per cent. What is going to reduce it further over the following 12 months by a further 2 percentage points to the Treasurer's 4.5 per cent theory? Is it the rise in interest rates that we have recently experienced, particularly since the economic statement was brought down? Will that reduce the CPI? Of course it will not. Will it be the rise in the various taxes and charges which the State governments are all going to be introducing in the next month or three as they in turn respond to the very sharp cut which the Commonwealth Government has imposed upon the funds available to them for their Budgets in 1988-89? I should not think so. I would not have thought that would help to reduce the rate of inflation in this country during the next 12 months.

Will it be the reduction in tariffs which the Government has announced, and about which Senator Bolkus was uttering such utterly ridiculous remarks, or boasts I think they would be better called, last weekend, which he was forced to withdraw on Monday? Not at all. Will it be the rise in the exchange rate? It is certainly true that a further rise in the exchange rate would help to slow down the rate of increase in prices in this country. But is that what the Government is relying on? I can only say that if so, it had better start telling our exporters.

In short, the figures for prospective inflation in the Treasurer's document are all simply dreamtime stuff. The truth is that we are facing inflation next financial year of at least 7 per cent, that is to say, about where we are now. We will be lucky to hold it at that level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Careful. You know your record on predictions.
—My record on predictions, I am bound to say, is a great deal better than the honourable senator's in predicting the exchange rate.
—I concede that.

—I am glad the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, concedes that. It is generous and honest of him to do so. What will the Treasurer do by way of providing tax cuts? Of course, he will not say.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the other side of the package, the package for which at least in part the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is himself responsible. Here also there are several points to be welcomed, in particular of course, the abolition of the 2 per cent revenue duty on imports with an expected cost to the Budget next year of $240m. That has been a dubious impost, and I welcome its removal without reservation. But I can only say that this side of the package also can only be described as very disappointing, both in respect of what it contains and, even more importantly, in respect of what it does not contain. First of all, the reduction in protection comes not only at least two years too late. After all, our dollar started its downward plunge in February 1985, over two years ago, but even now the proposed reduction in tariff protection will take four full years to be finally achieved. It is extraordinary that even so the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Mr Simon Crean, has been publicly protesting about this timid move by the Government to level the playing field on which our exporters have for so long been running uphill.

Take another area, the area of public enterprise efficiency. This statement, which I suppose some months ago we had all hoped and expected would deliver a good deal-that was, after all, what the Government, through its spokesmen and its leaks to the media had been promising us-in the end has delivered so little in this area that it undoubtedly constitutes one of its most disappointing aspects. There will be no exposure of public enterprises such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and so on to the pressures for enhanced efficiency which need to be imparted to them by rendering them truly accountable to real shareholders.

One result of this failure on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Ministers such as Senator Evans and Senator Walsh to win the argument on privatisation, which they have been having both with their own parliamentary colleagues in the Caucus and with the trade union bosses more particularly, is that bodies such as those I have mentioned will continue to be starved of capital and they will gradually grow less competitive and less able to deliver their services efficiently to Australians who consume those services.

But the real vacuum in last Wednesday's statement on this structural adjustment side of course lies in its total silence on anything to do with the deregulation of our most important market, namely, the market for labour. It is the greatest single market in this country, and indeed in most countries, and there is not a word about it. Most objective observers I believe would agree that today the single most important reform required for this economy, if we are to have a future in the 1990s and beyond, is to render our labour markets more flexible, more responsive to market pressures and more capable as a result of delivering jobs rather than unemployment. As I say, on this topic the statement is silent. It is silent because, among other things, and most particularly, the Government's associates in the trade union movement have refused point blank to countenance any progress in this area. As a matter of fact the Industrial Relations Bill, which was recently rammed through the House of Representatives and which is presently lying on the table here in the Senate, would have the effect of strengthening even further the already excessive power of the bosses of our major trade unions, a point to which Senator Harradine was drawing attention I think only this morning.

Let me turn quickly to deal with a few points in more detail in the short time remaining to me. One of the most important aspects of last Wednesday's speech by the Treasurer was his statement that in the area of superannuation arrangements the changes now proposed:
will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money-now lying in superannuation funds-without diminishing any personal end-benefit by one cent.

In justification of that, on the face of it, apparently very large claim, the Treasurer tabled a 51-page document entitled Reform of the Taxation of Superannuation. One can only say that as time has gone on since last Wednesday night, more and more experts in this admittedly extremely complex field have been seriously questioning this characteristically exaggerated claim by the Treasurer. Others will no doubt speak on this matter and I therefore do not propose to do so any more on the specifics, but I do draw attention to a more general point in this area. It is a point which is best brought out by my referring to some passages on page 2 of the printed copy of the Treasurer's statement to which I have just referred. I will not read it in extenso but two or three sentences are worth quoting. He said:
Similarly, it is not the Government's view that the tax concessions for superannuation are justified only if they result in reductions in age pension payments.
Subsequently, he said:
This consideration is also relevant to the question of whether superannuation should only be taken in the form of an income stream . . . rather than as a lump sum.

In those and other associated passages in the document I believe that we have seen a volte-face by the Government in relation to the extremely important question of the relationship of our arrangements for taxing superannuation schemes and our retirement incomes policy. The rationale for providing the quite generous taxation concessions for superannuation has always been, to my knowledge, that it is an incentive and an encouragement to private citizens of this country to provide, by way of superannuation arrangements, for their own retirement income and thereby, as a consequence, wholly or at least partly removing themselves from the need to go onto the public rolls of the age pension and so on. As I have said, in those and other associated passages I believe that we have seen a remarkable volte-face by this Government from that previously generally received doctrine in this area. I do not have time to pursue that point. However, it is a very important and indeed fascinating matter.

Finally, in the taxation law area, I will say something about the revision of depreciation allowances as announced by the Treasurer last Wednesday night. Without elaboration, one can say simply that the Treasurer has rendered those taxation arrangements much less `generous' than they were previously. The Treasurer has justified that-if the word is appropriate-by pointing to the fact that he has also cut the company tax rate, with almost immediate effect, from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. One can at least see the argument there, even though I still have some doubts as to whether this, of all times in our history, when private investment is as weak as it is, is the time to provide a further cloud of uncertainty over the whole investment climate and, in effect, to provide less incentive than there was before for companies to undertake the increased business investment which is desperately required.
