I note in passing that private business investment fell, in seasonally adjusted real terms, by 3 per cent in the March quarter of this year. I draw attention to the fact that while that may be an argument for companies it is no argument for partnerships or sole employers, all of whom may be conducting businesses which also undertake investments, who also have had access to the depreciation allowances under the tax law but do not necessarily have companies. Those people have not been similarly advantaged. Having in mind the speakers list and the fact that we are under a guillotine, I conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on almost more Bills than one can count-some 10 Bills are before us-I will be the only speaker on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It is worth pondering the fact that we have got into a pattern of having two Budgets a year. As Senator Stone said, this package of Bills arises from the economic statement of last week. We should realise that one of the major reasons we are blessed with this exercise of two Budgets a year is that the Government is clearly exploiting the absurd practice that the Opposition has established while in opposition of not opposing Budget measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the Government is in the happy position of being able to take any measure that it likes, in particular, any measure that it thinks the Opposition would oppose in normal circumstances, put it in as part of one or other of its Budget statements, either in May or in August, and be assured of its passage. For instance, one can think of a measure in last year's Budget package to impose a $250 administration charge on students. At that time only the Australian Democrats opposed the legislation. However, since then there have been letters in newspapers around the country and questions in this House from Opposition members opposing the fee. (Quorum formed)

Having made those preliminary comments, I will address specific Bills and then make more general comments about the mini-Budget. I note that the Opposition intends to move a second reading amendment in relation to the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill 1988. In this respect I am advised by my colleague Senator Sanders, who has expressed concerns similar to those expressed by the Opposition in its amendment, specifically the lack of funding in the legislation for the Civil Aviation Authority. Therefore, the Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment.

The Democrats have a particular interest in the Migration Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1988 and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1988. My colleague Senator Jenkins has put a great deal of time into this issue over past months. I remind the Senate that in September 1987 the then Minister, Mr Young, put out a Press release announcing a service fee of $5 to be applied to passengers over the age of 12 years who required immigration clearance on arrival in Australia. The fee was to be collected by airline operators and the Government was to collect it in bulk from them. At that time Senator Jenkins put a lot of effort into pointing out the shortcomings of the proposal. When the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 was debated in the Senate in November 1987, Senator Jenkins put up a strong protest and pointed out that the fee was ill-conceived, impractical and would not work. At that time the Opposition failed to support the Democrats in opposing the measure.

Both the Government and the Opposition opposed Senator Jenkins's amendment, which would have delayed the imposition of this so-called service fee until 1 March. Our advice was that, if it were to be implemented, the airlines at least needed more time to put in place the necessary structures to collect the fee and then disburse it to the Government. The fee came into operation on 1 January 1988 and, as Senator Jenkins and the airlines had predicted, there was immediate chaos at airports. The airlines were unhappy and passengers were irritated. It certainly did nothing to enhance Australia's reputation with the travelling public around the world. At that time Senator Jenkins made the comment that the travelling public would resent the unexpected imposition of yet another cost and the airlines would be expected to make up the shortfall in money collected from unwilling return travellers or one-way immigrants.

Even the passage of this legislation does not really solve the problems. Problems will arise. An article in the Canberra Times today points out that there will be immense confusion because the fee is paid on the outward journey rather than on the return journey to which it actually applies. The article states:

Since it was introduced on January 1 . . . hundreds of thousands of airline passengers have refused to pay. They have been able to get away with it because, according to the Board of Airline Representatives of Australia, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs refused to instruct its officers to check that travellers had paid the fee and to cancel the stamp.

As we understand it, some frequent travellers have been able to make multiple use of a single stamp. As the Democrats predicted through Senator Jenkins, the fee has been a debacle. We will therefore support the passage of this group of related Bills.

The next Bill in the package is the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-roll Tax) Amendment Bill 1988, which implements that part of the May statement-and arising from the Premiers' Conference deliberations-which provides that Telecom Australia and Australia Post will be subject to payroll tax at the hands of the State governments. It must be recognised that, while we hear a great deal, in this place in particular, about the burden these Commonwealth authorities are on the public-as if they were some kind of enormous negative in the economy-we do not take sufficient account of the contribution that they make to the economy.

I refer specifically to Telecom. Telecom makes a substantial contribution to Government revenues. In fact, it can be said, as the Telecom unions have pointed out, that the telephone network is part of a taxing medium. This legislation makes that even more so. At present 20c out of every telephone user's dollar goes to the Government. When this Government came to power in 1983 the figure was 13c in the dollar. This financial year Telecom will pay the Government $1.2 billion. When all these new charges are in place under the new capital structure which has recently been announced, the Government's take could easily exceed $1.8 billion. So, in the whole debate about whether our Commonwealth authorities are beneficial and whether the general public, as the owner of those enterprises, ought to offload them, issues such as these should definitely be taken into account. (Quorum formed)

I now turn my attention to two of the Bills which relate directly to primary industry. I refer first to the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill 1988. This Bill enables the Government to recover from industry the administrative costs incurred in collecting and disbursing funds raised through the various agricultural industry levies. The levies and charges relate to the operation of various authorities and industry research programs. While extra charges-in this case totalling over $1m in a full year-represent an additional impost on primary industry, the Democrats believe that this method of cost recovery is consistent with the current economic trend towards eliminating subsidies and tariffs which is being promoted not only by the Government and the Opposition parties but also by Australia's rural leadership. Stressing that we understand the difficulties of the imposition of additional costs, we have discussed this with the industry. We understand that it is something of a problem but in light of the general economic thrust, particularly of rural leadership, the Democrats will not oppose this legislation.

The Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill 1988 is another primary industry related Bill emanating from the May economic statement. This Bill will terminate subsidies for phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers from 1 July 1988. We have been advised by the National Farmers Federation that that organisation indicated to the Government its support for the termination of this subsidy with the Government's agreement to do several things: to improve anti-dumping legislation as it applies to fertilisers, to consider the removal of tariffs on agricultural machinery and spare parts and to reintroduce tax-related income equalisation deposits (IEDs). The Australian Democrats are very pleased with the Government's decision to reintroduce tax-related income equalisation deposits, although we would have preferred the reintroduction to take place much earlier than the Government's proposed date of 1 July 1989, as would the National Farmers Federation, representing Australia's farmers. We strongly suggest to the government that it introduce its IED legislation earlier in the autumn session-it would be nice to have any legislation introduced early in the next autumn session so that we did not have to go through the present ridiculous exercise, as we always have to do-to ensure its passage in time for implementation by 1 July 1989, in recognition that the loss of the fertiliser subsidy is a significant one for primary industry.

All along we have supported the reintroduction of a genuine tax-related IED scheme. My colleague Senator Macklin, in a speech in April 1986, when he held the primary industry portfolio for the Australian Democrats, expressed his understanding of a need for a genuine IED scheme so that-and I quote:

firstly, the income equalisation deposits are deductible from taxation income in the year of deposit; secondly, interest rates are linked to a two year bond rate; thirdly, interest was payable on the investment component of the deposit where the investment component is equal to the balance of the deposit if tax was payable in the year of deposit; and, fourthly, safeguards were imposed to avoid IEDs as a tax avoidance measure.

In that speech Senator Macklin also stressed that IEDs were destroyed by the Liberal and National parties voting with the Government, which had introduced that destructive legislation as a Budget measure, knowing that the Opposition would not act, in spite of its protestations. We make the point that we are pleased to see that negotiations have proceeded and that a suitable form of tax-related IEDs will be reintroduced. Again, we stress that the Government should ensure that that legislation is before us early in the next session.

In regard to the removal of tariffs on machinery and spare parts, the Government has expressed an inclination in that direction. The farm organisations are promoting the need for a by-law stating that such tariffs should be removed in cases where actual manufacture does not take place in this country. As far as the anti-dumping laws are concerned, it looks as though that requirement will reasonably be met in other legislation. On that basis, the Australian Democrats will not oppose this legislation. Although it is a difficult time, particularly for the wheat industry, given recent developments in the United States, the farm organisations are taking a reasonable approach on this question.

I turn to the National Health Amendment Bill 1988 and the question of pharmaceutical benefits. This portfolio is covered by my colleague Senator Coulter. I am advised by him that the Democrats want to make the point that in recent years the Government has progressively restricted the range of drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. We have expressed concern about that process. Moreover, the more expensive drugs have been progressively shifted into the special uses category. As a consequence of those two things happening at the same time, many drugs that are ostensibly covered under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme can be purchased as over-the-counter drugs more cheaply than with a national health scheme prescription. This progressive removal of real pharmaceutical benefits is more significant than the increase in the NHS drug price from $10 to $11 per prescription. It merely means that more of those drugs which are listed as NHS drugs will be cheaper as over-the-counter drugs. That is our main comment with regard to that Bill.

I turn to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988 which implements, as a new part of the Act, a new base figure from which subsequent financial assistance provided to local government is to be calculated. I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill, on the advice of local government organisations, which are receiving quite considerable blows from one direction or another with regard to their funding. We believe that it is fair to move for the retention of the present formula during the transitional period. It is very difficult, given that other parts of the formula are changing, to deny local government consistent funding in real terms until 1991. The amendment which we will move is required constitutionally to be a request to the House of Representatives to have included in this Bill amendments which will maintain existing levels of funding in real terms until 1992. This will reduce the risk of local government authorities having their financial positions destabilised during the phasing-in period for the adoption of the per capita distribution arrangements which are taking place at the same time.

I note that in 1986 we supported the original legislation but were concerned as to how the funds would be paid to the States. At that time we would have preferred payments to be made in the form of a lump sum, which was the case before that time. However, from 1 July 1987, as a result of the 1987 May statement, annual assistance to local government has been paid to the States in quarterly instalments. This was done to enable the Commonwealth to better match its outlays and receipts, resulting in savings to the Government of about $27m per annum in public debt interest payments because of a reduced within-the-year financing task.

It has been pointed out to the Democrats that, if we do not take this step of making a request to the House of Representatives, many councils in several States-we have already been advised from New South Wales, Tasmania and Victoria-would have their funding very substantially cut. We are advised that this will be so in the case of 14 per cent of all councils in New South Wales and that 20 of the 46 member councils of the Municipal Association of Tasmania will face severe adjustment difficulties, as will a very high proportion of local councils in Victoria. We will move an amendment to try to retain some stability in funding for local government.

I will make a couple of general points about the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988 and the moves which are being made by the Government. The cost to revenue of this measure-$460m in 1988-89 and up to $900m in 1992-93-needs to be considered. We are concerned at the lack of provision for retraining and relocation assistance for those who will, without doubt, lose their jobs. After the mini-Budget was brought down, Senator Button was on the record as estimating that the tariff cuts could cost 15,000 jobs over the next four years. We have to face the fact that this move will encourage imports during a time of balance of payments problems. The Government must look at these issues.

We have noted the claim by Senator Bolkus in recent days about how much consumers would save as a result of the tariff cuts. The Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Retailers Association have contested this claim. The ARA said that prices for clothing, textiles and shoes would rise. There is some encouragement, perhaps, in Senator Bolkus's commitment to put the Prices Surveillance Authority on its toes. Nevertheless, it can scarcely be said with great confidence-particularly in regard to the lack of provision for retraining and relocation assistance-that the short term measure will be of great benefit to the Australian community.

With regard to the mini-Budget in general-and further legislation, of course, will be before us in the months ahead-the Democrats have made several statements during the week since it was brought down. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been boasting about his $3 billion-plus surplus. The Democrats say that that surplus has been achieved at the expense of the unemployed, migrants, the poor, pensioners and students, who have suffered expenditure cuts over the past two years and whose circumstances are not improved by the provisions of this mini-Budget. It does not contain the back-up for the Government's claims of a strong social justice orientation.

The company tax rate has been reduced to 39c in the dollar, while at present the average amount of tax that is paid by companies is only 28 per cent. While one distinguished company in this nation could not even stagger up to 1c in the dollar in tax in the last financial year, it is almost obscene, the Democrats say, that at the same time the Government is planning to introduce a tuition tax for higher education students. It has failed to raise the lower tax threshold. While it has raised the rebate for pensioners-or will raise it by legislation further down the track, and we welcome that-a pensioner or beneficiaries can still earn only $10 a week over and above their pension before they are taxed, and low income families are falling into the tax bracket at a very early stage. At the same time, companies are not even meeting the new low level of tax. It is bad enough that the imposition of a gold tax has been delayed three years, but when we consider that half the shares in gold companies here are held by foreign interests and therefore half of the tax-free profits are leaving the country, it does not seem to be a very good economic decision.

We are very concerned about the reduction in the home and community care program and the first home owners scheme. Having the responsibility for the social security area for the Australian Democrats, I express specific concern about the large savings which in this mini-Budget are anticipated from restricted eligibility and administrative crackdowns which we believe will not be able to be achieved without resort to unduly draconian and arbitrary measures. We say this on the basis of experience. This type of crackdown has been under way for the best part of 12 to 18 months. The stories that come to me, as the social security representative for the Democrats, and to others in this place are horrific. Sole parent women are landing themselves in gaol because the poverty traps-the tax threshold remaining where it is, and low levels of permissible incomes-are forcing them into a black economy. Every now and then they are not able to evade the web which surrounds them.

While no-one would want benefits to go to those who are not eligible, it is disturbing that the Department of Social Security now has powers of what I call `search and destroy' which outdo those that are available to the crime busters in this country and to the Australian Taxation Office. Those powers are exercised over the poorest in our community. It is a major concern. It is essential for the Government to ensure that it consults fully and constructively the community sector and those people who speak and act in the interests of people on low incomes, that these abuses do not continue and that people are not guilty until proven innocent simply because they are on the welfare payrolls. In general, the Democrats are not happy with the thrust of this Budget. We do not believe that the Government's social justice claims are met by this Budget. We are appalled at the hypocrisy of the company tax rate going down and that people in the corporate sector are not yet paying their way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately a package of 10 Bills resulting from the microeconomic statement delivered last Wednesday by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Within my area of responsibility in this chamber are three very important Bills: the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill 1988, the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988. In view of the guillotine applied by the Government and supported by the Australian Democrats, I have to restrict my remarks to about 10 minutes. The Democrats have supported the Government in applying the guillotine to the discussion on the most important Constitution Alteration Bills, which were finalised before the Senate this morning as a result of that gag. They have gagged through the rest of the Government's program, a most important series of measures, including the May economic statement Bills, all of which will have to be completed by 10.30 tomorrow evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill enables the Commonwealth Government to recover from agricultural industries the cost of collecting and disbursing funds raised through industry levies and charges. It is estimated that the levy and charge collections and disbursement costs amount to 0.2 per cent of total collections, or $1.193m in a full year. It is part of the $100m in extra charges and taxes that this Government has imposed on the rural sector in the May economic statement. As my colleague Senator Stone pointed out earlier, this Government claims that this May economic statement is a great exercise in cutting expenditure, but the truth of the matter is that the Government has cut the States' expenditure to ensure that extra funds come from other areas of the community-in this case, from the rural sector.

While cost recovery generally is supported by the coalition parties, we point out that such recovery needs not only to be equitable but also to be seen to be equitable. This increasing cost-recovery burden being imposed on the rural sector does not appear to us to be equitable in that the same levels of cost recovery are not being imposed to anything like the same degree on other sectors of the community. Yet the rural sector is one of the major contributors to our balance of payments. It is essential that its recovery be achieved in the light of our present balance of payments problem.

The Fertiliser Subsidy Amendment Bill terminates the phosphatic and nitrogenous fertiliser bounty from 1 July 1988. The saving to the Government in this case will be $37m this year and $50m in the following full year. Since January 1988 the subsidy has been applied only to locally produced fertiliser, and special compensation payments have been made to certain importers to offset the additional cost of dumping duties. Because of these distortions, because of the declining value of the bounty, and because of the negative image of the rural community with the non-farm community, the National Farmers Federation suggested a trade-off to the Government. It suggested firstly a removal of tariffs on agricultural machinery parts made in Australia-an estimated saving of $80m to $100m-to which the Government responded that it was prepared to consider the matter after it received the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said:
The Government is disposed to grant duty-free entry on agricultural and mining equipment and parts not made in Australia.

I point out that he used the words `disposed to grant' and not the word `implement'. The second proposal by the National Farmers Federation was to allow the Australian farmer to buy fertiliser at world prices. That requires the removal of anti-dumping duties. Unless this happens there will not be genuine access at world prices. The Government has made no response to that proposal. The third part of the deal was income equalisation deposits. The Treasurer used a clever piece of verbiage. He announced that the Government would reintroduce income equalisation deposits but that it would defer doing that until July 1989. That enables the Government to have a massive rake-off from people like the wool growers, who this year are finally receiving adequate recompense for their years of hard labour in carrying on their industry through difficult times. When the times have come good and they are in desperate need of the reintroduction of income equalisation deposits to try to balance out their income, the Government has said, `Yes, you can have that, but you cannot have it until next year'. That enables the Government to make very substantial recoveries of tax from these people at this stage. I have spoken to a number of them who have indicated that they simply cannot meet their tax bills out of their revenue for this current year. In our view, the deferment is quite a shabby trick.

I now turn to the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988, which comes under my shadow portfolio. Our criticism of this Bill is that the Government's industry protection policy has not been timely: these tariff reductions could have and should have been made much earlier. Since the stock market crash of 19 October last year there has been speculation of tariff cuts and a clear acknowledgment of the necessity for change. But the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has delayed announcements in this area. He has delayed any changes until a very late stage. It was the beginning of this month before we had the passenger motor vehicle announcements and as late as the May economic statement before we received the rest of the announcements. The Government simply delayed these announcements so that the whole package could be included in the May economic statement. That is an absolute nonsense, because in the meantime industry has been damaged by the speculation and uncertainty fuelled by Government Ministers who have gone around talking about proposed tariff cuts and anticipating tariff cuts as they have endeavoured to persuade their colleagues in the union movement to accept the tariff cuts.

Before Christmas of last year I started criticising the Government for fuelling the speculation about the changes, for example, to the textile, clothing and footwear plan, not because the changes were not necessary in this area, or in the other areas of the passenger motor vehicle and other industries, but because of the damage that was being done as restructuring plans and investments were delayed while industry and the Opposition waited for the Government to come clean and announce its intentions. Many industries may now think that they worried unnecessarily. Others may think that they should have known six months ago so that they could get on with the job of restructuring. There has been very bad timing in relation to these tariff cuts. The Australian economy-certainly since 19 October last year and I believe for some time before that-has been ready for some very substantial and drastic tariff cuts.

There is some difficulty and pain in connection with tariff cuts but they are not difficult for governments. Mr Whitlam demonstrated this in 1974 when he introduced a 25 per cent across the board tariff cut. It is not the tariff cuts, but the maintaining of investment and employment in industries which are suffering the cuts which is difficult. The other difficulty is to gain some benefit from the cuts. To gain the benefit it is necessary to remove the rigidities which are currently inherent in our industrial structure and which have been built up over many years of protectionist policy for our industries. There is a desperate need to free up our system; there is a desperate need to deregulate the labour market; and there is a desperate need to overcome the rigidities and difficulties in matters such as the transport of goods, especially on our wharves. This Government has done nothing about that. There is nothing in this package of Bills and nothing in the May statement about freeing up the system. Unless the Government frees up the system, quite frankly the tariff cuts will simply wash out in unemployment and reduced investment. There is a need to have tariff cuts, but there is also a desperate need to remove the rigidities from the industrial structure.

At long last the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has suddenly realised, after all these years in office, that this is the right way to go. After the May statement he announced that labour market flexibility would be his next great challenge. Mr Keating, having taken over the IAC from Senator Button, is now about to take over industrial relations from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis. We welcome that they have at last realised the necessity to reform the labour market. We have been telling them that for five years. We point out that these tariff cuts which the Government has imposed by this Bill will not be of real value to people in Australia without the benefit of deregulation of our rigid industrial structures.

I also point out to the people of Australia that they can totally ignore the nonsense spoken last weekend by the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, who talked about massive falls in prices for various goods as a result of these changes. He spoke of the possibility of falls in prices in regard to these matters at the end of the four-year term of these tariff cuts-in other words, not during 1988 but sometime in 1992. If that happens in 1992, there will be no-one more surprised in this community than the wives and husbands of Australia who have borne the burden of having the Australian Labor Party as the Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the quite disgraceful behaviour of the Government and the abysmal incompetence of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, we are now participating in a four-hour debate on a package of no less than 10 important Bills arising from the Government's May economic statement of last week and on a wide range of micro- and macro-economic measures announced in that statement. This type of performance by the Government is a total prostitution of the democratic parliamentary system. Perhaps we should not be too surprised about that. Already today we have seen the Government, with the totally unprincipled connivance of the Australian Democrats, bludgeon through this Senate four referendum Bills, one of which if passed by the Australian people would permanently and fundamentally weaken the role of the Senate as the watchdog on behalf of the Australian people of those very democratic parliamentary processes that the Government is today prostituting.

SPEECH.PARA: In the pitifully short time available to me I will very briefly comment on some of the policy measures contained in the May economic statement, which is very rapidly becoming known as MES or mess. I will then touch, equally briefly, on the three Bills for which I have responsibility on behalf of the Opposition in the Senate; namely, the Migration Amendment Bill, the Departure Tax Amendment Bill and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill. The Opposition agrees with several of the announcements in the May economic statement. In particular we support the announcements in relation to reduction in industry assistance, including tariff reductions, but with the very important qualifications just mentioned by my colleague, Senator Austin Lewis. However, at the same time we reject the absurd claims by Government spokesmen such as the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, about the extent of the immediate benefits to consumers. Nevertheless, the changes are in the right direction.

We support the measures to put public sector business enterprises on a more commercial footing, though we stress that this is little more than a cop-out made necessary by the Government's abject failure to reach agreement within its ranks on a sensible program of privatisation. We support the reduction of the company tax rate to 39c in the dollar. We support the abolition of the 2 per cent revenue duty on imports. But there are other, and in many ways much more important, measures which we do not support. My colleague Senator Stone has already dealt with some of these in detail. We totally reject the assertion of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the economic statement contains:
. . . far-reaching economic reforms that will take our nation into the 21st century.
Once again, cutbacks in government spending are a key element of those changes . . .

These statements are quite simply false. The economic measures are not far-reaching. In many instances they exhibit a monumental lack of stomach by the Government to grasp the really difficult tasks it should have been tackling. Foremost among these is the need to reduce government spending by much more than the Treasurer has done. Ninety per cent of the planned reductions in spending of which the Treasurer boasts is a reduction in the Commonwealth's payments to the States, and both indirectly and directly through that to local government. Only about 10 per cent, or $112m, represents a cut in the Hawke Government's own spending. No wonder the State Premiers are so noisily angry about the unfairness of this treatment.

Even taking into account the reductions in payments to the States, the fact is still that the Government remains the highest spending and highest taxing government in Australia's history, as well as the Government which has put Australia into debt with the rest of the world by an amount which would have been frankly inconceivable only five years ago-a debt which has tripled in the five years of the Hawke Government to a figure of $110 billion, equivalent to $6,700 for every man, woman and child in Australia. That debt would be much higher if it had not been for the good fortune of the unexpectedly high prices over the past couple of years for many of our exported commodities. This good fortune, which has had nothing to do one way or the other with the policies of the Government, may well not last much longer. There are clouds on the international, economic and trade horizons which could well presage a collapse in export prices and in export volumes later this year or early in 1989. Yet the Government appears to have framed its economic policy as if this threat did not exist. If it had taken the external situation properly into account, it would have had no option but to adopt a much tougher fiscal policy than it has.

By being soft on its spending the Government has done several things. First, it has guaranteed a rise in interest rates because monetary policy is going to have to be the Government's key economic policy tool. By a soft fiscal policy and its inability to use its wages policy in an economic policy sense, it has thrown the whole weight of its policy adjustment measures on to monetary policy. This interest rate rise will have severe adverse implications for our external account. It will encourage greater capital inflow and therefore as well make more difficult the maintenance of an appropriate exchange rate. The soft fiscal policy has also prevented the Government from giving taxpayers a cut in income tax now. This would have been both achievable and desirable if only the Government had found the internal strength and discipline to take the hard decisions. Far from giving tax cuts in 1988-89, income tax will increase in the year ahead. The average rate of tax paid next year by wage and salary earners will be higher by something of the order of 1c in the dollar than in 1987-88, the current year. That arises because of the iniquitous effect of the tax bracket creep as incomes move into higher brackets due simply to the inflationary effect.

The Government now has a quite huge dilemma on its hands. It has promised income tax cuts in 1989-90 and last Friday in Melbourne the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) implied that these cuts would do more than simply return to taxpayers the revenue windfall that has been reaped from bracket creep. But even simply to give back to taxpayers the bracket creep rip off of this current year and next year would cost the Government about $3 billion. The Government has to reduce its top marginal tax rate from 49 per cent, the existing rate, down to the new corporate rate of 39 per cent if it is going to be able to maintain the integrity of this new company tax rate structure. To reduce the top marginal tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent and to adjust the other brackets accordingly is estimated to cost over $10 billion. So unless the Government can reduce spending in 1989-90 by a much greater amount than it has to date shown the capacity to deliver, it will be impossible for it to deliver on its tax promises without once again going into massive Budget deficit and blowing the Australian economy out of the water.

Time prevents me from going into greater detail on these matters. To summarise what I have already said, the facts underlying the May economic statement are that the Government has thrown away a golden opportunity to put the Australian economy on the path of sustainable long term growth and, worse still, has sown the seeds of major economic difficulties later in 1988 and in 1989. Those difficulties will include, very importantly and significantly, rises in interest rates, as I have already mentioned, and without much doubt at all great pressure on costs and prices and a corresponding lift in the inflation rate.

Let me also say without elaboration at this time that I believe the Treasurer has been less than honest with his statement that the proposed new superannuation tax arrangements will not harm one single superannuant or fund member. The Treasurer has said that not one person will be 1c worse off as a result of the superannuation changes that have been made. Quite frankly, that is simply wrong. Equally clearly, many will be disadvantaged. It is difficult at this stage to know where the burdens will fall and where the advantages will lie but, quite clearly, many superannuants and fund members will be disadvantaged. It is a very large and very complex issue which will require the most careful study between now and the Budget session.

In conclusion, let me just say a couple of words about the three Bills I mentioned earlier-the Migration Amendment Bill, the Departure Tax Amendment Bill and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill. The overall purport of that package of three Bills is to provide for the abolition of the arrival tax that the Government last year imposed on persons arriving in Australia from overseas, be they visitors from overseas or returning Australian citizens. At the time we said very strongly that that was a ridiculous tax. We did not vote against it because it was one of the Government's Budget measures, but we did consistently put to the Government and to the people the inequities of that tax. In that context I pay particular tribute to my colleague John Sharp in the House of Representatives.

The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. They should never have been necessary in the first place because the original proposal should not have been introduced. We welcome the fact that the Government has at last seen sense in the face of a great deal of pressure from a variety of sources, not least the travelling public. In the first few months of the tax to the end of January, 38 per cent of the travelling public refused to pay the tax and by April this year the Government had been forced to backtrack on its revenue measures as a measure of the loathing of the tax. It has cost the Australian community dearly in terms of the loss of goodwill of overseas visitors, it has cost us tourist dollars, and it is high time it was removed. We welcome that removal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a great rush at the end of the session we are now pushing through 10 Bills-the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill 1988, the Migration Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1988, the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-roll Tax) Amendment Bill 1988, the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill 1988, the National Health Amendment Bill 1988, the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988, the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill 1988, the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988-along with the debate on what was allegedly an important May economic statement.

SPEECH.PARA: If that economic statement is so important I wonder why the Government has given us so little time to discuss it. If the time available bears any relationship to the significance of the statement, obviously this is an insignificant and insubstantial statement which apparently does not deserve a great deal of attention in this chamber. However, unfortunately this Government has developed a sort of inverse ratio relationship with matters of significance. If it is of major significance it is rammed through the Senate, using guillotine motions, as the constitutional referendum matters were rammed through the Senate in the early hours of this morning and as the May economic statement is being rammed through now. I believe that this Government stands condemned for the offensive and disgraceful way it has approached this Senate chamber and the Parliament as a whole by seeking to limit the amount of serious question and debate on these matters of immense significance.

Senator Short was able, briefly, to deal with only a couple of Bills on the list. In the short time available to me I want to deal with the May economic statement as a whole and expose it for the sham that it is. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has come to the Parliament and pretended that he is cutting Government spending. That is simply false. He is not cutting Federal Government spending. Senator Short was particularly kind to him when he said that there was a very small amount of Federal Government cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not list them.

—Senator Short, in a very kindly and generous mood to the Treasurer, which I think is unjustified-I think he was too generous to the Treasurer-has omitted a very key element of that statement which involved massive changes in bookkeeping. The statement is a bookkeeper's dream; it is a set of fiddled accounts. When we adjust those fiddled accounts, when we write back the changes that are made and the manner in which things are being organised and when we get out of the accounts the fact that the States have carried such a substantial proportion of the burden-in fact, they have carried all the burden as the figures I will produce show-we see that the Commonwealth has not cut its own spending and this Treasurer is a sham for pretending that he has. It is an absolute disgrace that his word is taken at face value by people who, quite frankly, have the capacity to know better.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested to see that many of the media commentators, after mature reflection, are now criticising strongly the failure of this Treasurer to apply the appropriate cuts to Government spending that are absolutely vital if our economy is to emerge from its present crisis and if Australia's future is not to be jeopardised. As Senator Short has said, at the moment we have a temporary benefit from commodity prices which, for the time being, has assisted our balance of payments. But we are facing a real problem unless there is some serious cutting of Government spending. In a recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald Max Walsh mentioned that, if the Government gives up the option, as it appears to have done, of having genuine cuts in Government spending, it will have to rely on monetary policy. Mr Walsh said:

A government that has monetary policy as its preferred tool of domestic management is a sitting duck. As soon as it tightens monetary supply to dampen demand, it puts up interest rates thereby attracting foreign funds-
This inevitably increases the exchange rate-weakening export industries and funding increased imports.
He also said:
Recent interest rate movements have given the appreciation which we have had in recent times-
added impetus-

And the short-term reaction to last week's statement on changes in corporate tax and superannuation regulations must mean higher interest rates for the simple technical reason that the relative portfolio attraction of equities has been enhanced compared with fixed-interest investments. The reduced demand for fixed-interest instruments means that their yields have to be adjusted upwards to restore their relative position in the marketplace.

So we see monetary policy being overused because of the incompetence of this Government in not cutting its own spending and pretending that it has. Let us adjust the bookkeeping fiddles. I am glad that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is in the chamber because with his knowledge of finance he will be able to trace them and see exactly the way in which this Government has cooked the books. The manner in which it has done this is simple. Primary industry charges and levies and light dues and Navigation Act receipts, which were previously classified as offsets within outlays, have now been classified as revenue. Discounts and premiums on Treasury bonds have been reclassified from financing transactions to outlays.

According to the text of this statement, these changes will add an estimated $974m to recorded outlays in 1987-88 and $783m in 1988-89. In other words, by increasing the previous year's expenditure figures the Government makes the present year's figures look not as bad. That is what this is about. It is a device to exaggerate last year's spending so that this year's spending looks smaller. When we write back those adjustments and fiddles we get a genuine comparison-a comparison that this Treasurer seeks to avoid.

In addition, the Civil Aviation Authority will be shifted off-Budget from 1 July 1988 and this will reduce outlays in 1988-89 by about $270m. We have adjusted the estimated total outlays in the current year and next year to show exactly what the situation is. When we make those adjustments we find that total Government expenditure is claimed to fall by the ludicrously small amount of 0.8 per cent. That is a pathetic contribution.

However, we get a far more accurate and realistic view of the Government's failure to reduce spending when we exclude the burden of the States. Let us face it: the Federal Government cannot claim that it is cutting its spending when all it is doing is reducing its grants to the States. When we exclude the savings of $870m in total outlays to the States we see that Federal Government spending, on its own account, has increased this year, not fallen. It is that sort of realisation, a week after the event, that is prompting so many of the commentators to criticise this Government for its failure to cut government spending and its failure to take the action that was appropriate in the May statement. The Treasurer could not take that action for a variety of reasons, particularly his own pretensions to becoming leader of the Australian Labor Party and his need to appeal to the various factional groups within the Labor Party if that pretension to leadership was to be fulfilled. Of course, we can now see just how excessive this level of Government spending and, as a result, the level of Government taxing really are.

Let me deal with today's statement of Australia's national accounts. It reveals several things, if the figures are accurate, and I accept that in many instances the figures that the Government puts out are far from accurate. What do we find in today's seasonally adjusted accounts? We see that, over the last 12 months, private final consumption expenditure has gone up in real terms by only 2.8 per cent. But what has the Government done? Government consumption expenditure has gone up by 5.3 per cent. It has just doubled the rise of the private sector. The Government and governments around Australia are still spending up big, at double the rate of rise of the private sector. Even more serious, in the latest quarter we have a 2.3 per cent real fall in spending on equipment. This Government has been pretending that its policies are assisting the recovery in Australia by encouraging investment in new plant and equipment so that we can trade our way out of trouble. Not on your nelly!

The figures dramatise what is happening. As I said, in the latest quarter spending on new plant and equipment has fallen 2.3 per cent. Over the last 12 months it has risen by a paltry 3.1 per cent, far less, of course, than the 5.3 per cent increase in Government consumption expenditure. In these figures we have evidence of this Government's gross incompetence and the risk to which it is putting the Australian economy by failing to take appropriate fiscal measures.

When we look at the analysis of contributions to growth in gross domestic product (GDP), we see an extraordinarily revealing figure. We see that gross domestic product in the last quarter was up 1.8 per cent in real terms. What contributed to that? A growth in stocks and a growth in Government final consumption expenditure. It is the Government, not the private sector, that is leading the charge in growth. That is apart, of course, from the private sector increasing its stock levels. Where is the consumption led boom we have heard about?

Of course, this has led to enormous increases in the inflation rate. The implicit price deflator on GDP expenditure is something like 8.2 per cent for the last 12 months. In the only area of the private sector in which we are getting any real activity, real estate, we see that the inflator is up by something like 23 per cent. This Government really stands indicted. These figures demonstrate how ludicrous its policies are. On top of all these inflationary factors we have had something like a 3.3 per cent increase in the growth of wages, salaries and supplements in the latest quarter.

To pay for all this increased expenditure, what have we had? We have had continually rising taxes. I think that the latest Niemeyer statement put out by the Minister for Finance last week shows that net pay as you earn taxation collections have gone up 11.1 per cent so far this year. That is an increase of $2.7 billion; $2,700m more in taxes is being paid by the pay as you earn taxpayers of Australia. This is not being paid by the companies, the rich people, the people who live on investment income; but the workers of this nation have had to hit the can for that extra $2.7 billion to pay for this Government's massive expenditure rises. The total increase in taxes so far this year is $5.76 billion. We now know why this Government is capable of increasing its spending while budgeting for a surplus next year. We know why that surplus should have been $5 billion, not $3.5 billion.

So far this year we have had the sneaky rise of 17.4 per cent in sales tax collections-the consumption tax the Government pretended it did not have when it was attacking everyone else about the prospect of a consumption tax. So far this year consumption tax collections by this Government have risen by 17.4 per cent or something like $1,000m, in one of the greatest secret assaults on the hip pockets of Australians that has ever taken place. This Government stands condemned for its incompetence. The May economic statement reveals the extent of that incompetence. More importantly, I believe, it probably reveals the extent of the Treasurer's desperation to appeal more to the people and to the factions within the Australian Labor Party, in view of his hopes and aspirations for leadership, rather than providing the sort of leadership he should be providing by giving the Australian economy and the Australian people a proper May economic statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great regret that I can speak very briefly on only one Bill, the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill 1988, in the package before the Senate. There are many questions that I would like to ask of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) as to how the financing of the Department of Transport and Communications, at which the levy on aviation gasoline will be directed, is to take place. However, due to the collusion between the Australian Democrats and the far left of the Australian Labor Party, and the Australian Labor Party in general, we are denied the right to debate this legislation in the way we should. Perhaps later on in the afternoon when we debate the Civil Aviation Bill I will get a chance to ask a few more questions.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill is to appropriate a set fraction, all but 2.393c per litre, of the excise duty raised on aviation gasoline. It is important to recognise that this is avgas and not avtur duty that is being transferred to the Civil Aviation Authority to provide some funds for it when the Authority is formed on 1 July this year. It is recognised that it costs money to run the aviation service in Australia. Traditionally, the fund raising has been done in a number of ways-by air navigation charges, individual charges based on the weight of the aircraft involved and various rentals that the Department can raise. In Budget Paper No. 3 for 1987-88 there is listed on page 365 the receipts offset within outlays for air navigation charges. Included are airport facilities, terminal navigation, rescue and fire fighting services, international en-route, international charters and special arrangements, general aviation, airport business concessions and facilities such as that for which the Commonwealth makes charges. They come to a total of $318m.

What is a little obscure is how much the Commonwealth gets in excise payments for both avtur and avgas. Avtur would be a much greater aggregate figure than avgas, but one suspects that that is probably in the region of $250m to $400m a year. The Government has been rather coy in attributing that in the departmental estimates up to the present time.

Against these traditional backgrounds, in recent years-starting from the time of the Whitlam Government-we have had the user pays doctrine. This has been applied very much to the aviation industry, principally on emotional grounds. It is thought that people who fly, whether they be pensioners going to see their children on the other side of the country, people flying on business or to service a tractor or a bulldozer somewhere in the country or even people flying at the weekends for pleasure, are loaded with money, that they are fat cows favoured by society and thus ought to be taxed in every way possible.

The user pays doctrine has been applied by the Australian Labor Party more forcefully to the aviation industry than to any other section of the community. I have a personal objection to that. I happen to pay personal income tax. I pay company tax. I pay a lot of sales tax and excise duty on everything I buy. In other words, I am paying at least three different categories of tax to a central government to provide facilities such as airports to enable me to fly here to the Senate and do things such as that. I object very much to having a fourth level of taxation imposed on me.

More importantly, I object to that taxation being imposed on me in a way which means that I have no say as to how it is imposed. I cannot go into a Myer store, buy several thousand dollars worth of clothing and book it up to Senator Walsh; yet this is precisely what is being done to me, an aircraft owner, by the Department. Services are provided for me but I have no say either in whether I need them or in whether their delivery is efficient. If the Government were serious about a user pays doctrine, it would certainly set up boards of management for the various areas of expenditure and the actual user could have a majority position on the boards and hold the chairmanship of the relevant committees.

Over and above everything else, the user pays doctrine ignores the community benefit of something like aviation services. It is not only the person who flies between Sydney and Melbourne who gets a benefit from that airline service; the community at large benefits because it reduces the need for roads and rail services, it promotes trade, it brings in tourists. The whole level of commercial activity, profits earned and employment generated is related in a way to the provision of air services. In another sense there is a defence aspect as well because the aviation industry does provide the maintenance and support, reserve capability, including transport reserve capability, and a pool of skills that are nationally important-intangible though they may be. It is very wrong to see the provision of aviation services in this country as being restricted entirely to a user base.

Traditionally those set fundraising measures that I mentioned earlier in my speech-aviation navigation charges, rentals facilities and excise-were the sole sources of revenue for the Department. About 18 months ago the Department of Transport and Communications went over to a new scheme under which it proposed that movement charges, or landing charges, would be levied on general aviation aircraft as a means of supplementing its income. It found out very smartly it was too costly to implement a scheme like that. Furthermore it was unworkable because it simply could not trace the number of movements with any degree of accuracy. So the aviation industry in consultation with the Department agreed to an extra 3.9c per litre levy on aviation gasoline to compensate for the air navigation and movement charges that were projected to be introduced. This provided, of course, many advantages for the Department because it meant that an extra levy on aviation gasoline was paid in cash. The Department had no collection charge. It did not have to chase its clients because the oil companies paid the charge, and it was paid on the spot each month. There was no delay in pursuing clients for payment. It was a very attractive scheme for the Government from an efficiency point of view.

Recently the Government has tried to get out of any financial responsibility for the operation of the airway services. It has introduced a Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), which is tasked with looking after a number of airports in the country and being revenue self-supporting, and this afternoon it will introduce legislation for the Civil Aviation Authority, which will take over the functions of the old department with respect to navigation, air safety, legislation and the general administrative side of aviation. Again, that Authority will be largely self-funding. The relevance of that to this Bill is that a proportion of the excise raised from aviation gasoline, estimated to be about $22m a year, will go to the Civil Aviation Authority.

I applaud the Government because in the past, if one looks at the history of aviation fuels, the excise has been lost to Consolidated Revenue. It has not gone specifically to the industry. It is wise, if we are going to work out actually what the industry costs us, to have offsetting figures. I support the move to do this. Not all of the funds from aviation gasoline will go to the Civil Aviation Authority. Something like 2.3c will go to the Federal Airports Corporation, in the fullness of time, for the airfield side of it. It will simply not be enough. It will have to be supplemented from other sources by the Government to provide for the airfield services that the Federal Airports Corporation is so inefficiently and disastrously running at present. I have never seen a public authority in such a short time-about five months-get into such a totally discredited position with its clients, namely, the aviation industry, as has the Federal Airports Corporation. Unless the FAC picks up its game and improves out of sight, the Government will have to disband it and come up with another solution. The Opposition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available to me I want first to move the Opposition's amendment to the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Bill, and so move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) the funding shortcomings of the proposed Civil Aviation Authority; and
(b) its failure to include these revenue provisions in the Civil Aviation Bill 1988''.

The amendment draws attention to the shortcomings of the proposed Civil Aviation Authority, which is a matter the Opposition will be discussing later. Senator MacGibbon has just pointed out the shortcomings of that operation and the difficulties with it. The second point of the amendment is the failure of the Government to include in any statement about the Civil Aviation Authority any revenue provisions as to how much the operation will cost, where the money is coming from or going to and any attempt to try to explain what the advantages of the Authority are. They have been totally omitted from the Government's contribution to date.

I turn briefly to one part of the May economic statement which did not rate a mention amongst the Bills we are now discussing-the telecommunications area. There was a major contribution in the papers presented by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, to the Senate last Wednesday night. I note the Opposition's extreme disappointment at the Government's contribution in this area. It simply has not gone far enough in deregulating the telecommunications authorities, that is, Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd, and has rather settled for what obviously was the lowest common denominator-in other words, what the unions would allow the Government to do.

Consequently the Government has not gone into the exercise with the idea that the consumer is king paramount in its mind. That has been left aside. The consumer will gain very little from the deregulation proposed. Consequently the Opposition stresses its great disappointment that the Government squibbed the issue and certainly took only a very small step forward.

Without going into too much detail of the exact nature of the deregulatory moves, it is important to note that the Government failed very significantly in not removing Telecom's monopoly on the first phone. This is an area which is subsidised to the tune of something like $250m a year by the Australian taxpayer, and it is a monopoly which supports most inefficient work practices by the employees of Telecom. In one stroke the Government could have opened this area to competition and in that way generated more efficiency and incurred less cost to the consumer in the Australian community. It failed simply on that ground.

Another failure emerged only a day or two before the detailed statements came out last Wednesday, which was an indication of the pressure experienced by the Labor Caucus. No doubt it was under pressure from the trade union movement, which prevented the Government from allowing an open market for cellular mobile phones. We all know how rapidly this area of the market is developing, for the benefit of consumers, businesses and industry generally in this country. Instead of allowing the market to grow rapidly and deregulating it to allow competition into the industry so that there could be a rapid expansion, with consequent benefits to the economy, the Government sat on its hands again and chose to take the easy road under pressure from the trade union movement. That means that area of consumer benefit will not grow as rapidly as it might have. As a result job and business opportunities will not be created as fast as they might. As a result the economy suffers. That was a direct failure by the Government in the light of the specific pressures coming upon it obviously from the trade union movement.

We note with some pleasure that the Government has decided to deregulate small business systems and their installation, and the maintenance of some areas of the PABX telephone service. It is very welcome news that there will be a deregulated market for value added services for Telecom and OTC. These areas are exceptionally welcome even though they do represent relatively small steps forward. We note that, even with those relatively small steps, the Government is already being put under pressure by the trade union movement. We hear that the unions are meeting and discussing these questions, with the likelihood of taking industrial action to prevent Telecom and the Government proceeding down those lines. If the Government, in the way it has been wont to do lately, buckles under the pressure of the trade union movement, it will be a tragedy for this country. Whilst the steps are small and certainly disappointing in their magnitude and extent, the fact is that they are welcome in the sense that they are in the right direction. For the Government to give up the game now would be a tragedy for the nation, and I urge it not to buckle to the trade unions in this area.

Another area of failure is the Government's lack of backbone in not going all the way to turning Telecom into a public company with the shares held by the Government. That is the policy of the Liberal and National parties in this area, but the Government has chosen to keep Telecom as a separate name. It has been called the Telecommunications Corporation rather than the Commission, but there is little difference from what it presently is. That is merely a cosmetic change to the name of Telecom, without any effective changes that might have been wrought had the operations been switched to a public company and Telecom in that way opened to more effective competition as to capital raisings, as to its handling of industrial relations and as to other practices which affect its operations and efficiency.

The Opposition will be watching very closely and monitoring the operations of the new regulation agency called Austel which is to take over the role which Telecom had previously been managing itself. Telecom has been a major operator in the field of running a telecommunications business, not only regulating itself by law but also using the law to regulate everybody else, that is, its competitors in the marketplace, with the obvious inefficiencies that that brings. At least now the Government is going to remove that regulatory power of Telecom's by establishing the new agency, Austel. What we do not want to see happen is Austel merely becoming another branch of Telecom or of the Government in such a way that it seeks to protect Telecom from the marketplace, from competition and from efficiency, being used as just another means of achieving the same ends which Telecom achieved in former times. We put the Government on notice that we will be watching carefully to see that that does not happen.

While we are talking about Telecom, we note a recent statement by Senator Walsh about the obvious opportunity for and possibility of the Government introducing timed local telephone calls. We see quite clearly from a speech of his a week or so ago that this is clearly on the Government's agenda. Consequently, we would like to see that matter cleared up or cast aside, in the light of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a month or two ago when he said this would definitely not occur. We note Senator Walsh's adherence to economic rationalisation, as he calls it, and as a result we would very much like to hear from him whether he is going to be using Telecom as a taxing medium in order to reintroduce those charges on the community.

Regarding the superannuation changes that were brought down last Wednesday, we note again Senator Walsh's answer to my question today concerning what is clearly a bit of fast footwork on the Government's part. It said last Wednesday that some $900m was going to be taken out of the income of superannuation funds, but that somehow, by some magical stroke, this was not going to affect the final outcome of the beneficiaries receiving their benefit in due course. This is an amazing piece of work. In Senator Walsh's answer to my question on that point today, he admitted that the way in which the amount of tax to be saved by the Government, that is, $900m, is to be effected is by ensuring that investments in which those superannuation funds are currently involved and from which they remove themselves in order to take advantage of dividend imputation are picked up by some other parties outside the superannuation area which will consequently pay tax on that income. Apparently this is the way in which the Government has rationalised everything. If we narrow the argument down simply to the beneficiaries of superannuation funds and we look at the direct effects upon them of the reduced income of superannuation funds as a result of the tax, we see quite clearly that in individual cases there must be a detrimental effect upon the final benefits accruing to superannuation fund members.

I think it is simply exposed by Senator Walsh's remarks today that in fact the Government did play a sleight of hand on us last Wednesday when Mr Keating was quoted as saying that not one cent of final benefit would be lost by individual members. I think that shows the lack of good faith of the Government in this area. It certainly has been very misleading over the last week or so. At last today we have got the clear statement from Senator Walsh that in fact it is all being done with mirrors and that there is going to be a detrimental impact upon the final benefit for superannuation fund members.

I conclude by saying that the statement brought down last Wednesday night appears to me to be nothing more than a statement designed to build up the personal fortunes, if you like, of one Paul Keating, with the obvious objective of ensuring that he is the next leader of the Australian Labor Party. It is possible that this change of leadership will come sooner rather than later, and it may well be this year when we see the emergence of Prime Minister Keating. God forbid that that should happen! Nevertheless, it is something which is becoming clearer and clearer as a result of last Wednesday's exercise, which, when it boils down, amounts to little more than a public relations exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the release of the May mini-Budget, the headlines in the newspapers ranged from `Markets show confidence in Keating's blueprint' to `Cunning sleight of hand by Scrooge McKeating'. And we had everything in between. But as Robert Haupt so very aptly put it, `the press gallery was ecstatic'. Mr Haupt said:

SPEECH.PARA: as I heard the voters, they were worse than neutral-they hated it all.

This journalist went on to explain some of the talk-back sessions he had listened to. He said that people saw the postponement of the gold tax as a concession to Alan Bond; saw in the lowering of company tax a failure to lower income tax; and saw in the superannuation measures a change in the rules. Behind the whole exercise, one caller said, was the image of `Keating and his clocks'. As that slowly sank in, by week's end the people realised that the Government had once again ignored the ordinary Australian family and, as John Howard put it, `They get a big fat zero'. Even worse, people knew that because of the changes to the arrangements for superannuation benefits, which they had been planning for all their working life, they would end up much worse off than they are at present. Mr Hawke had tried, by the weekend, to rally the troops, and headlines appeared such as `Prime Minister pledges rise in living standards'. We all remember very clearly his promise: `There will be no child living in poverty by the year 1990'. One newspaper article stated:
Mr Hawke countered criticism of delays of personal tax cuts yesterday by saying living standards would rise immediately as a result of the mini-Budget.

However, the following day we saw the headline `Home interest rates on the way up'. There is no way in the wide world, as bank after bank puts up its home loan interest rates, that the living standards of the ordinary Australian family will go up. Senator Button cited figures showing by how much the price of clothes and shoes would come down. When we took him to task on that, we were told by Ministers that the Prices Surveillance Authority will monitor the price rises. What teeth does that body have, and what will it do? The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is at the table, certainly will not do anything.

We are told that this mini-Budget is just one building block. I can assure the Australian people that this building block is being placed so very carefully on the top of the pile that it will result in the complete toppling of this Labor Government. The building block is a sleight of hand trick by Scrooge McKeating. The Government has been too smart by half. The Prime Minister has said, `We are giving our mates a reduction in company tax, but the ordinary Australian family will have to wait'. He said that income tax cuts would have to wait for about 12 months. But they will not take place then. We know that Mr Keating has said that they will occur in mid-1990. That is not 12 months away. It is in the next financial year. It is not a case of being told what the tax cuts will be. Rather, it is: `We might cut tax. The Government is not coming across with how much people will get. That all depends on the level of wage rises; that has to be established before we will tell you the size of the cuts'.

Mr Keating has said, `If we cut your tax now, you will go out and spend the money irresponsibly on imported goods, and you will only send up our balance of payments deficit again'. The Government believes that it cannot let the Australian people have too much money and that it has to look after it for them. The Government says, `We will do the borrowing for you; we will increase our overseas debts; we will spend the money on how we see you want it spent, not on the way you decide to spend it'. The Government believes that, as a good socialist Government, it should tax the people to the hilt, because it fears that if it allows them to have money they will spend it irresponsibly.

The Weekend Australian reported Mr Hawke admitting, in a flash of honesty, that the Government's reforms will cause industry dislocation and job losses. He said that there will be industry dislocation and job losses, but that it is all for our own good-`No tax cuts; people will lose their jobs; but this mini-Budget is all for your own good'. Not everybody will accept that. I am quite sure that Mr Hawke will realise that very soon.

Let me come to the main differences in the philosophies of the Government and Opposition parties, because they are very great. I have already said that this Government wants to grab our money so that it can spend it in a better and wiser fashion than we can spend it. The editorial in the Weekend Australian pointed out that some of our social welfare policies, unfortunately, encourage long term dependency. If I had more time, I would be able to go into that matter in a much better way. There are large groups in our community-I do not want this to be misunderstood-that can never be independent, and it is the job of government to look after them. But there are other groups that should and can be helped and led to take responsibility for themselves.

During a debate the other day on the family package, I said-the figures were brought to notice originally by Senator Chaney-that there are poverty traps that encourage people to remain on welfare programs. I gave the example of a single income earner on $330 a week, with a dependent spouse and two children, paying $40.39 in tax. That person receives $35 from this Government through the family package. This Government still rips the tax off him, but it gives him back $35. If that single income earner earns an additional $90 for 7 1/2 hours extra work-overtime-he loses, out of that $90, the family income supplement-the lot. Out of the $90, he gets only $8.59.

Is there one bureaucrat sitting in this chamber at the moment who would work for another $90 and get only $8.59 out of it? Of course people will not do that; they will stay in the welfare system, putting out their hand and saying, `Give me the $35. I'm far better off than I am working overtime and getting only $8 1/2 for it'.

That is the type of poverty trap which this Government is setting up. Its philosophy is, `We know what is best for the community; they need not bear responsibility; we will bear it; we will not give the community tax cuts; we know how to spend people's money'. The Government is too frightened to give people the freedom to earn overtime. It would rather tax them heavily and not allow them to spend their money on their own priorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday evening the nation witnessed the Treasurer (Mr Keating) waxing rather lyrical about what he called the economic reforms that will take our nation into the twenty-first century. He might more truthfully have prefaced his remarks with the comment that the May 1988 statement was the package that would take him to the top of the Australian Labor Party. Mr Keating's cards are now clearly on the table and the news headlines reflect this. Australians have read of `Keating's grand design' and `Prime Minister Keating builds up credit to play Santa Claus'. The May economic statement has compounded and highlighted the dominance of the Treasurer over his ministerial colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: While Mr Keating addressed the nation for 30 minutes on national television, revealing the so-called gems of his mini-Budget, it was left to other Ministers-Dawkins, Kerin, Senator Evans and Senator Button-to fill in the harder, less newsworthy details off-screen. We heard nothing from the Treasurer about the end of the first home owners scheme, the reduction in the overall level of road funding in the next financial year, a freeze on funding to non-governmental schools that will effectively lock them into current levels of funding, and the termination of subsidies for agricultural fertilisers. Instead, Mr Keating served up headline-grabbing news, interspersed with sweeping metaphors. We heard about the proud economic history of this Labor Government. I certainly would not be proud of a number of features-for example, the responsibility for a blow-out in foreign debt to a record high level of over $100 billion and going down in the history books as the highest taxing government, with the highest taxing Treasurer, in Australia's peacetime history-but, on balance, we have to acknowledge that the May economic statement contained a few welcome and overdue initiatives. Not the least among these was the recognition of the need to pay off some of the burgeoning overseas debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Howard ran a $10 billion deficit; 5 per cent of GDP you had on the deficit.

—Perhaps Senator Walsh does not intend to honour those promises. I will take him up on those later. Cuts in the company tax rate have also been very much needed but it should not be forgotten that this Government put up the company tax rate to one of the highest rates in history.
