It put it up from 45c to 49c, and it wonders why there are problems with overseas money not flowing into companies in Australia. At last it has seen the light, but it took a long time. I ask Senator Walsh what this all means to the ordinary man in the street. He has lost touch with him.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me canvass a couple of other principal areas. I want to look at the impact of the May economic statement on my State of Tasmania, which has been hard hit by this ruthless Hawke Government. What does the May statement contain for the average family in Australia? Let us look at the impact on a smaller State such as Tasmania. The burden of cuts in Government spending that Treasurer Keating has so self-righteously announced has fallen predominantly on the States, not on the Commonwealth. While accepting the praise for the forward-looking economic program, this Hawke Government has sought to evade the repercussions of its scheme essentially by passing the cuts on to the States. This has been done in the same way as a commanding officer might pass on distasteful orders to a subordinate.

In net terms the May economic statement reduces the Forward Estimates by $982m. Of this saving the States have to contribute $870m. The States are not really getting a fair go. Tasmania's Budget was reduced by a total of $52.5m in real terms. This is on top of reductions to the tune of $330m in the two previous financial years. Following the May economic statement, Tasmania is set to lose a further $5m. It is pretty selective: $3.8m in road funding and $1.6m in funds to local government. So much for local government being recognised in the Constitution under the Government's referenda proposals, if they get through. That is how much charity this Federal Government has towards local government, in spite of all the claims made by the Prime Minister in his last, pre-election, visit to Tasmania in July last year. The Mercury of 8 July 1987 stated:
After three years of an average 4% cut in the general revenue grants, Mr Hawke said there was no need for the knife to be put into the State's funds again.

Either Mr Hawke was displaying a remarkable degree of economic naivety or he was blatantly lying to cadge votes for the upcoming Federal election. There is no end to the number of promises that this Government can make and then break without compunction.

What is in the May economic statement for the average family man? Amongst the rhetoric that the Treasurer has been spouting in recent weeks has been the claim that the economy is overheating and that there is a need to keep a lid on demand. In effect, what Mr Keating means by this is that there is a need to keep the pockets of taxpayers empty of disposable income. There is nothing in the statement that will improve living standards. In fact, living standards are going down for the ordinary man. They have already declined significantly under this Government as it absorbs more and more of the tax revenue. The average family does not seem to figure in Paul Keating's grand plan. It is a selfish plan for himself and his Labor Party. The ordinary family man is simply forgotten by the men in their ivory towers, except when a titbit dispensed here and there can achieve some electoral advantage.

Last week Senator Button went on record as describing the Government's expenditure review process as `terrible'. He is an honest man. It was his Department that fared the worst. The reality is that the average taxpayer must once again wait. He has to wait in a long queue-in fact, for 12 months-in order to get some promised tax relief, for no reason other than that it is electorally expedient for the Government to have tax cuts fresh in the minds of pay as you earn taxpayers when an election is on the horizon. That is what it is all about. What is going to happen in the interim? Bracket creep, as every wage earner knows, will continue to push the average family's income into higher and higher tax brackets. But there is no guarantee that by the end of next year these long promised tax cuts will eventuate for the ordinary person in the street. The Treasurer has said:

The size and timing of those cuts will depend upon the size and timing of future wage rises. That is, the Government is prepared to provide substantial tax cuts provided there is an acceptable wages outcome in 1988-89.

The ordinary man in the street will not have much control over that; he is going to be a pawn in the whole process. One might say that that is fair and reasonable, but there is a rub. The commitment is based on the assumption that commodity prices will also remain at current levels. Should international pressures force commodity prices down, Australia's external debt will once again begin to mount. So there will be problems. How will this Government stand on personal tax cuts in that event? Judging by its past record in honouring promises, I have some doubt that personal tax cuts of the magnitude foreshadowed and promised will be forthcoming. There are lots of ifs in this commitment, and all the while the average family man gets no relief, only a shadowy promise. While the Treasurer manipulates reform for political advantage the average Australian has to sit tight, cap in hand, for another 12 months.

The Government has perpetrated one of its greatest con tricks ever in the area of superannuation. Despite the claims by the Treasurer that no-one presently contributing to a superannuation fund will be disadvantaged by the tax changes incorporated in the May statement, many people have every reason to feel a little cheated. I have a page of calculations relating to a person who is about to retire. Aged 64 years, he is a member of a section 23f non-taxable superannuation fund. This man came into the fund late. He contributed for 12 years prior to 1983 and has contributed for six years post 1983. He is an ex-serviceman. Because of that he started his family late and had to gear up his superannuation towards the end of his working life. This fund is administered privately. The trustees have never invested in shares and consider it dangerous for legislation to be introduced to compromise them into doing so. The answer that Senator Walsh continually gives us-and we have asked numerous questions on this matter-is, `Let them put their money in fully franked dividends so that they can get dividend imputation'. He is telling these trustees suddenly to move into higher risk areas. They have deliberately kept out of these areas because they want to play it safe. They cannot afford to gamble with their savings. They have done things the right way. These sorts of people have no problems.

So much for Keating's unequivocal statement. The evidence is there daily that people in superannuation funds will be worse off. One has only to ask the superannuation fund managers. They know that they have problems. Unfortunately, because of the time constraints due to the gag that has been applied, this debate must be truncated. It is not surprising that the Government is embarrassed; it is a shemozzle and a disgrace on the part of a government that prides itself on being called a Labor government of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that each speaker who rises to put his view makes the point that this is a truncated debate. This Government is treating the Parliament like it treats the electorate-with contempt. The guillotining processes that are being applied to both the referendum proposals legislation and the May statement legislation are simply the result of mismanagement of our schedule by the Government. This has resulted in the quite improper and shortened debate that is taking place on these important issues. In this climate we are deliberating in a hasty, unseemly, hurried manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the statements that have been made recently by Government members. I begin with the famous one by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the time of his policy speech before the last election, when he said that no child would live in poverty by 1990. I saw a snippet of a television program the other night in which Graham Kennedy made the logical rejoinder that, of course, the Prime Minister did not say anything about parents living in poverty. That is a statement which probably reflects much of the pea-and-thimble tricks the Government indulges in.

The next statement was again made by the Prime Minister when he was doing his promotional television runs for the May statement we heard the other evening. He described it as the most important statement that had been made for a long time in this country, that Paul Keating in the Hawke-Keating Government would deliver the most extraordinary and far-reaching reforms-`reforms' was the word used; a nice euphemism for change-that would be hugely beneficial for this nation. Indeed, it sounded very much like the tablets coming down from the mount. The only problem was that this great statement fell far short of the promotional rhetoric that had gone before it.

The third statement we heard recently was by Senator Bolkus. It concerned the immediate price reductions from which people would benefit since tariffs had been slashed. He said that the cost of goods would come down immediately and dramatically. He raised false hopes and expectations. Subsequently, he distanced himself from that statement. Again, the statement was made with excessive haste and showed a lack of planning-the same way in which the business of this chamber is being conducted. The fourth statement that was of significance was again made by the Prime Minister-that real incomes will improve, when in truth they will decline and have declined. The fifth statement has already been dealt with, but it should be pointed out again and again because it is typical of what characterises these five statements. The fifth statement was that no one person in receipt of superannuation will be 1c worse off.

Those five statements quite clearly can be placed in the category, `They seemed a good idea at the time'. They are statements without foundation. Other speakers have clearly identified the problems with the so-called simple idea which, I read in an article by Laura Tingle, was dreamt up by a member of the Treasury staff, who woke up at 4 a.m. and said `Goodness me, we can bring all of that taxation that we collect from lump sum superannuation payments to the front end and therefore we will increase taxation collections'. As I said, it seemed like a good idea at the time.

As to the statements that surrounded that superannuation proposal and package, one said that managers of funds can very simply overcome the additional taxation burden by taking advantage of fully franked dividends. I heard Senator Messner interject during Senator Watson's speech, `Are there enough franked dividends around to satisfy the increased demand?'. The answer, quite clearly, is that there are not. Another very interesting concept which has not received much attention concerns the requirement for a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions. Probably the fund itself cannot pay that 15 per cent and that amount will have to be found from sources other than the employer, which in itself will constitute a fringe benefit and will no doubt attract the full fringe benefits tax rate of 49c in the dollar, not the reduced rate of 39c in the dollar.

Two good things did come out of this May statement, the first being that the corporate rate was reduced to 39c-a remarkable idea that came out of the Liberal Party's policies before the last election and which the Government said was impossible. The second good thing that came out of the statement was a reduction in tariffs. An important statement that was made was that personal income tax rates will be reduced at a future date. How interesting. Let us look at the timing and why that decision has been made. John Howard quite properly pointed out the simple explanation that, if one cuts personal tax rates closer to an election, it becomes part of an election inducement package. As well, in reality the Treasurer has a full 12-month period, to the year 1989-90, to bring down the personal tax rate to match the corporate rate without developing the gap which in turn leads to a distortion in the way in which people arrange their affairs-by utilising, perhaps, a private corporate structure and paying the lesser rate of 39c in the dollar rather than 49c in the dollar-before the 39c in the dollar corporate tax rate takes full effect. But there is only one year in which to avert that gap being created.

Not only do people like me realise that, so do the unions. Already the unions have started to flex their muscles, as we heard on the radio and read in the Press this morning. The Public Service unions are starting to say, `The Treasurer is budgeting for a $3 billion surplus, therefore he can afford to pay us for our contribution to the raising of that additional revenue'. It is not very hard to figure out that that sort of reasoning will catch on in the trade union movement. When one realises that the Treasurer has only one year in which to fix that disparity between the corporate and the personal tax rates, it is not too hard to realise that the pressures on the Government from the trade unions, the people who really call the shots, will be excessive.

I have said on many occasions in this chamber that this Government, which likes to be seen as hard, tough and sensible, is a government which tackles only soft options. When it looks at making Australia more competitive it cuts tariffs, it does not attack work practices. In the same way, in the taxation area this Government raises more taxes instead of cutting expenditure. It has been going on ever since this Government came to office in 1983. In this financial year, 1987-88, tax revenue collections will be $73.8 billion. The projection for 1988-89 is that $79.2 billion will be collected. For 1989-90 the projected figure is $84.5 billion and for 1990-91, $89.7 billion. Yet the bulk of the expenditure cuts are really being felt by the States. Tomorrow in New South Wales the new Greiner Government will bring down its first mini-Budget. We will then see whether it is the Labor Party or the Liberal Party that has the courage of its convictions. We will see a true comparison between Federal Labor and its soft options and Liberal New South Wales which will have to face the realities because again, the Labor Government took the soft options and cut State funding rather than put its own house in order.

There are many other things that this question raises. In the minutes that remain to me I will mention the proposed new tax file number. On several occasions in this place I have raised the question of the proposed common identifying number, or CIN number, which first came to light in the public hearings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in March 1988. It was during those hearings that Mr Boucher gave evidence. When asked whether he could introduce the CIN number straightaway without any legislation, he replied, `yes, but only for internal use'. In further evidence it was said on behalf of the Australian Taxation Office that its major activity for increasing the effectiveness of its taxation collections, its revenue collections, was the matching mechanisms between information supplied to it and taxpayers who it felt were understating income. At the moment the Office has a 60 per cent success rate. Evidence was given that unless it got an Australia Card or its equivalent it could not increase that success rate past 60 per cent.

In the May statement we have had the thin end of the wedge. The new tax file number was introduced. Today in the Press it was announced that as from 1 November all new recipients of unemployment benefits, sickness benefits and job search benefits will be required to quote the new tax file number in order that they do not have tax deducted from their payments at the rate of 49c in the dollar. If the tax file number is to have external usage involving the social security recipients this ought to require and will require legislation. Hence I presume the date of 1 November for the introduction because it will be dealt with in the Budget sittings.

It is fair to put the Government on notice, to put the Australian people on notice, that this coalition and the Democrats, provided they hang on to what they say this time, have said that we will not allow an Australia Card by another name to come into usage. As I have said before, a rose is a rose is a rose. A CIN number is an identity card is an Australia Card. It is up to the people to be vigilant to see that it is not slipped in in things such as the May statement which purports to be one thing and turns out to be another.

The truncated debate that is taking place means that the electorate is less informed. It means that it is unable to hear more reasoned debate. The same complaint was made this morning concerning the referendums. But I think this Government underestimates the people. It has lost touch desperately with the people. That was demonstrated in New South Wales when Labor lost office to the Liberal and National Party coalition. I suspect that the wise Australian population will see this May statement for the farrago that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that we have to deal with this package of 10 Bills relating to the May economic statement, we will be discussing a mini-Budget with mega consequences. I intend briefly to address a few of those Bills and how they affect the countryside and agriculture. Probably the best way to do this is to analyse the pros and cons of these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: We have lost the 5/3 depreciation rule which gives an immediate saving to the Government of some $196m across the board. I do not know how much of that amount will come from agriculture, but I am sure that it is a lot. We have returned to the old scheme. Instead of the 5/3 rule we have the old scheme which operates under a schedule. There are many items with specialist application that are used in modern agricultural production systems which do not appear to be specifically provided for in the existing schedule. For example, wool presses which have been around for 30 years, broadacre spray equipment and livestock scales. We are returning to a system which does not cover machinery that has been brought in for the last 30 years. That is all I will say about that except that this system of depreciation over the life of the machines does not take any account of the machines that will last and those that will not. It does not draw any distinction between an imported machine that will last 10 years or an Australian made machine that will last two years. The most salient point is that the longer write-off period leads operators to lose the incentive to keep up with the knife edge of technology. This leads to many other points but I will move on. I suppose one could say that this measure will have a similar effect to the effect that the fringe benefits tax had on the car industry.

I will move on to an important aspect, the loss of the superphosphate fertiliser bounty. A few speakers have already mentioned this matter and how the situation came about. The bounty has been around since 1931 and its significance has been diminishing since 1970. In 1970 the subsidy represented 42 per cent of the cost of superphosphate; in 1974 it was 38 per cent; in 1979 it was 17.4 per cent; and in 1982 it was 11 per cent. Now it is 8.4 per cent and diminishing because the subsidy has remained at $12 a tonne. The subsidy having lost its significance, I believe, as has been stated here, the farmers were happy to lose it provided they were given alternatives. Senator Powell presented a screwed up idea of exactly what the National Farmers Federation (NFF) arranged with the Government. I will tell the Senate what the NFF tried to negotiate with the Government. Specifically, the NFF required the removal of various Government taxes and charges which directly or indirectly act as import tax on agriculture. It also sought the removal of tariffs on agricultural equipment and parts for equipment as outlined in the NFF's recent submission to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), removal of tariffs on imported chemicals in agriculture, especially where there is no local production, and the removal of sales tax where it applies to oils and greases. It was also sought to extend the exemption already available to miners, farmers and other business users. Reform of the anti-dumping system was also sought so that farmers can obtain fertilisers and other farm inputs at world prices by making certain revisions to the anti-dumping Act and its administration and, as an interim measure, removing fertilisers from the possibility of anti-dumping action.
Those proposals were being negotiated with the NFF. However, something drastic happened on the way to the Senate, just as something happened to Caesar on the way to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the way to the forum.

—Yes, on the way to the forum. The NFF was prepared to go like a lamb to the slaughter. It was idiotic of Senator Powell to claim that this matter was worked out with the NFF. It is a total lie. It is a pity that the honourable senator is not here to see her rubbish thrown back at her.

SPEECH.PARA: The farmers are not happy with the alternatives they have been promised. There has been a monopoly of superphosphate manufacture in Australia with the help of tariffs. What the industry needs, and what the Government has not provided, is a slashing of tariffs and its anti-dumping measures. The Government has seen fit to cut down on wool promotion because the wool industry is showing some pretty good signs of recovery. It is well on the way to another boom. The $10.4m cut may not be insignificant because of the amount the industry puts in itself. The Government fails to recognise that. There has been a natural increase valuation. I suppose this is to be expected because the valuation has not changed since 1982. I would like the Government to index a few other things.

We now have meat inspection charges. Not too long ago we were put on to working on a 50:50 basis. The Government was paying half the cost of inspection as an export incentive. However, the Government chose to raise the industry's input to 60 per cent and to reduce its own input.

I now come to agricultural products underwriting, mainly as it affects the wheat industry. The statement merely told us that the industry would have to bear more of its own cost underwriting. I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin)-the non-farmer Minister for agriculture; the former agriculture spokesman for the Democrats, Senator Macklin, is also a non-farmer and he has a lot to say in these areas-has always had a mental block on this issue and has worked very hard to try to get rid of Government underwriting. I do not know what the final outcome will be. I hate to think, but it will be no joy for the farmer. The Government rammed through prescribed payments tax provisions but I will not mention these in detail because of time.

Gold tax is another issue which affects the country greatly. The Government has finally had the courage to do what it wanted to do-get into it. Government members who made that decision obviously have not seen the areas of Australia where the gold industry has kept the economics of the countryside going when everything else has failed. It has opened up communities in places where no-one in this chamber would ever dare to go. Yet miners and their families have gone out there. In return, this Government has decided to slug them a bit further.

I suppose the reinstatement of income equalisation deposits (IEDs) can be regarded-even though it is not for 12 months-as the great Walsh backdown. In 1984 Senator Walsh, as Minister for Finance, set out to wreck them because he said they were rorts. He has a fad that there is a rort under every bed. I welcome the return of the IEDs. The National Farmers Federation was sold a pup on this issue. This might compensate for the loss of other measures, but it will not be brought in until 1989-90, which is almost three financial years down the track. When Senator Walsh wrecked the IEDs he also brought down the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd. This has never been mentioned.

There are a few points in the mini-Budget which I applaud, such as the effect on the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation and those provisions concerning section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, provisional tax and pensioners. The Government did not extend the provisions to our young people to give them an encouragement. If they save more than $6,000 the Government takes provisional tax. The Government has promised things in return which it may or may not deliver in years to come-if it is still in government.

Before I finish I would like to mention the priorities of this chamber and of this Parliament in dealing with Bills which affect the great industries of Australia. On 18 December last year we belted through legislation on wheat, beef and horticulture within three hours in one night. About 11.5 per cent of the work force produces 84 per cent of Australia's export income. Mini-Budget legislation which affects the great industries that keep Australia going is to be belted through in about three hours this afternoon.

The night before last we had to listen to a three-quarters of an hour lecture on condoms. At the end of that lecture we did not even know whether condoms were useful or whether they had a place. We dealt only with advertising. Last night we spent four hours on freedom of religion in Australia. We have had freedom of religion in Australia since Australia's inception but we had to listen to that debate and we came out none the wiser. This afternoon we have to belt all this legislation through in a matter of four hours. It is disgraceful that the managers of Government business allow this.

The recognition of local government in the Constitution has been a big controversy in the last few days. It would be more relevant if local government representatives had discussions to decide whether they want to recognise us. Those who have been watching us in the last few days probably would not worry whether we recognised local government. If local government were run like this place it would soon be wound up by the ratepayers or by the State local government Ministers and it would be out the door. We can learn a lesson from local government-to manage the business of this chamber far better than it is now managed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it highly offensive that this debate is to last but four hours. We have a package of 10 Bills. About 20 speakers have indicated that they wish to make a contribution but because of the incompetence of this Government, the mismanagement of government business by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), and the conniving, contriving and conspiracy of the Australian Democrats we find ourselves subject to a guillotine, a gag. Such is the respect, such is the regard and such is the concern that the Government and the Australian Democrats have for the normal functioning and systems of this chamber! Last night and this morning we were gagged on four crucial pieces of legislations-four Bills designed to amend the Constitution; four Bills with quite separate and distinct characteristics. In fact, the fourth Bill in itself had three different proposals. Rather than debating these matters in an exhaustive full way, we were subjected to a guillotine.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened at 12.30 today? We found that the Australian Democrats had proposed a further amendment. They used a contingent notice of motion to allow them to introduce their amendment without debate. A significant amendment to a Bill to amend the Constitution was put and voted upon in this chamber without debate. With whose help? Who are the conspirators? The Democrats. What did the Democrats say some time ago? That they would never gag. Don Chipp said that he was here to keep us all honest. His promise was that he was going to `keep the bastards honest'. To underpin that promise, he said that he would never have a gag or a guillotine in this chamber; he would never again allow a government to ram legislation through without proper, deliberate consideration. Yet the Democrats joined with the Government to deny us a proper chance to debate the legislation, notwithstanding the fact that the Government found that its drafting was defective.

I notice this morning that when we had a motion to amend Standing Orders to provide for the ringing of the bells for four minutes for the calling of a quorum or a division the Democrats sat right where they are now, on our side of the chamber, while the bells rang. The Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate then went across and had words with them. Like wimps, they climbed out of their seats and cringed and crawled across to the other side of the chamber. So much for their independence; so much for their character! As somebody said yesterday, they are but running dogs of this miserable Government.

What does this package of Bills do? Three or four minutes will not allow me even to start. Yesterday we were debating the intrinsic virtue of having local government recognised in the Constitution. What a fine step that was. What a magnificent recognition of local government. What a magnificent contribution it was going to make to its future welfare, finances and functioning. Allegedly it was not an idle statement but at the end of the day we found out from the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), through questioning during the committee stage, that it is but a statement of principle. At the end of the day it delivers nothing.

Today we are dealing with legislation that affects local government. We find that while the Government is giving it principles in one hand it is taking money in the other. Let us look at general purpose grants. For the period 1988-89 there was a decline in real terms of 2.9 per cent. Local government assistance declined by 13.2 per cent from 1983-84 to 1986-87, the period of the life of this Government. From 1983-84 to 1988-89, the level of Commonwealth funding for roads has declined in real terms by 29.4 per cent. While the Government is telling local government that local government is important, that it has a contribution to make and that it is a significant third tier in the system of government in Australia, the Government has just nipped local government for a lazy 30 per cent of its outlays for roads. That is what I call recognition. There is a 7.8 per cent decrease in real terms in the May statement alone. In the boring hour it took Senator Walsh to weave his wandering way through that statement he at one point took 7.8 per cent of the road funding away from local government as quick as a flash. That is the Government's concern for local government. What has the Government done previously? It had automatic indexation on fuel excise, the 2c a litre that the Fraser Government put aside for the bicentennial road fund. This Government had automatic indexation except it did not put the money into roads; it put the money in its pocket and ran. A total of $426.6m was put into Consolidated Revenue and not back into roads. I ask: Does this Government care about local government, more particularly the isolated areas of Australia where the pipeline to survival is the roads?

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate the farmers.

—The Government promised the farmers that in four or five years it would reduce protection. In the meantime it has taken away the superphosphate bounty. What happened to the poor old gold miners? We hear now from Senator Walsh that the miners have always been crooks. They have always had a free ride and have always been on the gravy train because they did not pay tax on their gold. It has always been a rort and a racket. It has always been crook. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with his slippery silver tongue, said as recently as 7 July 1987, with his shiny face staring at us, `There will be no tax on gold in the life of this Parliament'.
—Will there be?
—Is he saying that it is a rort now but it was not a rort on 7 July 1987, or was he part of this rort?
—Will there be a tax on gold in the life of this Parliament?

—The honourable senator is quite right. I am not denying that, but at the end of the day Senator Walsh is now saying that there always should have been a tax on gold and that it has always been a rort. Senator Walsh is saying that he was conspiring before to cheat the rest of the taxpayers. I am using his logic. Why did the Prime Minister not have the guts before the last election to say, `You people should be paying a tax on gold, but because there is an election coming up I am not going to put one on now; I will wait until the end of this Parliament and then I will put one on'? That is his regard for integrity and honesty. It is political expediency at its worst. It smells. That is the contribution this Prime Minister has made towards the welfare of farmers and miners.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably time has overtaken me. In the modest period that we have to discuss 10 vital Bills we find this Government saying that it has care and compassion for the poor. This Government is presiding over 800,000 children who are living below the poverty line. What has it done to help them? Has it cut costs? Of course it has not. It is the biggest taxing, biggest spending government since Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only creating more poor.

—Quite right. The $3 billion surplus it has now forecast comes not from fiscal restraint; it comes from extra taxes. This year alone three-quarters of a million taxpayers will move into a higher tax bracket. In the next three years two million taxpayers will be paying more than they were before the last election. That is their reward for voting this Government into office. However, I have no doubt that come the next election they will realise what a fraud the Government is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said by previous speakers, the guillotine imposed upon us by the Government and the Australian Democrats hardly gives time even to list the number of Bills that we are supposed to be debating tonight in this chamber, this House of review. Rather than spend the 10 minutes that I have doing that, I simply want to touch upon two matters that have come out of the May economic statement. They are two matters which I think we are going to hear a great deal more of in the months ahead and which will require very detailed consideration by us as legislators. The first relates to changes to be imposed upon the Australian people in relation to superannuation and the second is the Government's intention to introduce a new tax file number system which has so many similarities to the aborted ID card that the Government sought to impose on Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern with this Government's superannuation proposals is that it seems to me that they amount to a disincentive to Australians to invest for their future security in the form of superannuation. Let us reflect briefly on the changes that have occurred since this Government came into office. The taxation regime that had been in place as a result of the previous Government was a 5 per cent lump sum tax. That figure was increased by this Government to 30 per cent. Now we find from this May statement that the intention is to make a further substantial change, on the one hand, taxing at the rate of 15 per cent income that is derived by funds and, on the other hand, taxing at the rate of 15 per cent contributions that are made by employers to the fund.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us that this change will be tax neutral but, as economic commentators are noting in the Press now, that simply assumes a number of things that should not be assumed. It assumes that trust managers will invest a very large percentage of their funds-perhaps around 50 per cent-in Australian equities that will produce fully franked dividends. This is not a normal practice. Fund managers wish to have a wider discretion than that and wish to vary their investments so that if we have share crashes, as we had last year, then the beneficiaries of such funds will have their benefits in a number of different areas of investment and consequently not suffer as they would in more narrowly based investments. Fund managers are not going to change their investment practices significantly when this tax settles down. Unfortunately the result for the beneficiaries will be greater taxation to be paid on their investment in superannuation which, in turn, will reflect in a smaller dividend at the time of their retirement. To this Government that is perhaps a matter of little consequence, but to those of us on this side of the chamber it is a matter of very significant consequence not only for the individuals concerned but in the interests of the national economy.

We see in Australia significant demographic changes that will place an ever-growing burden upon the state to assist in supporting these people in their retirement. We on this side of the chamber would have thought that any support that could have been given to them to invest in their own futures would have been worthwhile. So why reduce the support-a short-sighted decision, one would have thought, in the least? Let us reflect very briefly that, in 1981, 5.6 people in Australia were supporting every person over the age of 65. By the year 2040, 3.1 persons will be supporting each person over the age of 65. There we find a change of almost 50 per cent. The number of people entitled to pensions will increase substantially over that period and the number of taxpayers supporting them proportionately will reduce.

Why, in those circumstances, is this Government being so short-sighted as to impose a further disincentive on people saving for their retirement? Would this Government not have been better off concentrating on the real problems that exist in superannuation-problems of portability, problems of preservation investing and problems of coverage-thus bringing more people within the superannuation net? Still only a small percentage of Australians are in superannuation funds. We notice that people in the public sector are advantaged over people in the private sector. In 1968 some 67 per cent of the public sector was covered as opposed to only 38 per cent in the private sector. Of course, in the public sector there was more indexed superannuation-a great benefit. We find only minute numbers in part time employment covered by superannuation-some 7 per cent in 1986. We find that women and the poor have been traditionally disadvantaged in superannuation. Would this Government not have been doing better concentrating on some of these shortcomings rather than restructuring its tax on superannuation in such a way that it will be a disincentive for investment?

The other subject that I said I wanted to touch upon in the very few minutes that I have been given is the Government's intentions in relation to its tax file number system. We are told in the statements that this will not amount to an ID card, but when we look at the skeleton that is being put to us as to what the Government intends we must have very great doubts. It will of course be compulsory. A person will have to get his tax number card and, if he is a taxpayer for the first time, he will have to prove his identity, at a post office it seems, in much the same way as if he were seeking a passport. I presume that that means he will have to produce his birth certificate to be given his tax file number and that that number will stay with him for life.

When he opens a bank account he will quote his number. When he buys shares or securities he will be obliged to quote his number. If he invests in government bonds he must quote his number. In turn, his transactions, through that number, will be reported to the Commissioner of Taxation. It does not end there; it then links with other dealings that he has with government. If he has dealings with government in the area of social security-perhaps because he is getting some form of pension-or in the area of education because he is getting some government support as a student, again he must quote his number and that number will be reported to the Taxation Commissioner. There will not only be a report back to the Taxation Commissioner but also, we understand from the papers, the Taxation Commissioner will be reporting on that person's affairs to those government bodies, by virtue again of that person's number.

It seems to me that at first blush that is certainly not greatly distinguishable from what the Government intended all along with regard to its ID system. Certainly, there is no suggestion that there will be an ID card that people carry away. Nevertheless, it means that in future people's total financial being will be recorded by means of a number that stays with them for life and that that number will be available to various government departments for them to act, hopefully within their responsibilities.

Many questions are being left unanswered. For example, we understand that this will be the procedure in the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. What about the Department of Community Services and Health? Will it be advised of people's affairs and information of a private nature that people put to it in order to gain some benefit? Is that to be reported to the Taxation Commissioner by virtue of people's numbers? Similarly, will this apply in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, a department through which some members of the community gain benefits? The Government, in its statement, is silent in that regard. Will information that is provided by these government departments or by private sector institutions, pursuant to their obligations under the system, to the Australian Taxation Office then be given, under the special relationship with the Taxation Commissioner, to the Director of Public Prosecutions or the National Crime Authority? In other words, will information that we provide to the Department of Social Security go to the Australian Taxation Office, via our numbers, and then, in certain circumstances, be available to the National Crime Authority? That question is unanswered. What has happened to the Government's proposal for a comprehensive privacy Bill to give us some security? Has that lapsed under this new proposal? The Government is silent.

Many problems immediately come to mind. Let me mention one other problem. If all our financial transactions are now to be recorded by one number, will that not provide greater ease for fraudulent activity? Does that mean that, if someone is able to obtain a person's number, he can break into the total of that person's financial being, including his financial transactions with government, his financial records that are provided to the Taxation Office and his financial transactions with the private sector, which under the legislation is obliged to record his number?

Certainly, on the face of it, there are areas in this proposed change of great concern and those interested in preserving some personal privacy in this country would not be prepared to allow this Government system to go through without the most detailed and careful analysis. I am pleased that this morning the Senate agreed to refer the Government's planned new system to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which will advertise for public submissions, hold public inquiries on the matter, report to the Senate in due course and assure the Australian people that this will not be an ID card in disguise.

The two matters I wanted to mention and to raise concerns about in this very preliminary way tonight are the Government's changes in relation to superannuation and what it proposes in relation to the new tax file number system. Both matters will be pursued in much greater detail in the time ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would also like to register my protest on behalf of the constituents of Queensland, who have sent me here to represent them. I have been given 10 minutes out of the whole day in which to debate 10 pieces of legislation.
—Order! Senator Boswell, you have 30 minutes available to you.

—Because of the guillotine that has been brought down and so that all honourable senators on this side of politics can speak in this debate, we have made an agreement that each be restricted to 10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to say is that when we come to power we will effectively correct the economy, but today we saw a blatant misuse of the Senate when the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party coalesced and forced through legislation to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. No doubt it is meant to affect the elections in Queensland. Effectively, that legislation will deny State representation to the rural producers and the primary industry of Australia. If democracy is to be allowed to exist, it is essential that all sections of the community be given an adequate voice and vote to protect their interests and that a parliamentarian be given the ability to effectively service the people, the industries and the institutions in his or her electorate, taking into consideration ease of transport and distribution of population. Today we effectively lost that.

If the referendum question were to be carried in my home state of Queensland-it will not be carried in Queensland-seven or eight State representatives would be removed from the outback areas of western Queensland. Their seats would be given to the south-east corner of Queensland, leaving about 22 representatives out of 89 to represent the major industries, the magnitude of Queensland industries, stretching from the Torres Strait Islands to Cairns and Bundaberg. Power would be centralised in the area between Noosa Heads, the Gold Coast and a little west of Toowoomba. There would be no representatives in the western areas further out from there. That would result in a loss of services in rural Queensland. It would result in a loss of industries and the loss of decentralisation of power. Areas would gradually be depopulated because the services provided would not support a decent way of living.

I add that it is all to no avail because those eight or nine seats that would be lost from those areas would be placed in the north coast-south coast areas of Queensland. In normal circumstances, the National Party or the Liberal Party would win those seats.

As a result of this Constitution Bill being passed today, all that we may have done is deprive the great rural industries-the great primary industries, the wealth creators of this nation-of representation. We did not get even 10 minutes to discuss that legislation when it was before the House. The Australian Democrats had got that covered. We came in here to represent the people who sent us to this place, but they did not get a run for their money at all on that legislation. They did not even get a voice to protest against this legislation, which is intended to deprive them of their parliamentary representation. Their parliamentary representation is to founder on a rock-a rock put there by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. These people will have to protest like crazy against this referendum proposal. I say to every person in rural Australia that when the referendum questions are put to them they must say no; otherwise they will have no parliamentary representation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I think this has probably gone on long enough. At the moment we are supposed to be debating the May economic statement Bills. There are quite a few of those on which Senator Boswell could choose to speak. However, he is debating a matter that finished around lunchtime today. I suppose that we could even say that he is reflecting on a vote of the Senate in the way in which he is going. I suggest that he be brought back to the subject under discussion at the moment.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Given the difficult circumstances today and the arrangements which have been made for these Bills to be dealt with, I can only suggest that the Chair exercise leniency in terms of the wide-ranging discussion that Senator Boswell wants to engage in. What has been happening here in regard to this legislative package over the last week or so is that the Bills are all very much integrated, albeit that as legislation we can separate it out. I seek that you rule accordingly.
—It seems to me that leniency has already been shown by Government senators and by me.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With all due respect, if you are going to participate in this debate, I suggest that you leave the chair and sit in your seat over on the Government side.
—Order! I am ruling on a point of order. Leniency has been shown.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to take a point of order. My point of order is to ask whether you are entitled to enter into the debate when you are making a ruling?

—Order! I am making a ruling on a point of order. I have said that leniency has already been shown in this chamber by Government senators and by me as Acting Deputy President. Decisions have been made in the past from this chair which indicate that Senator Boswell should deal with the Bills which are before the House and not talk about decisions already made in this chamber today.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a further point of order. You will recall that when the Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, asked for a cognate debate on these Bills he mentioned that they related to the May economic statement. I argue that the issues being canvassed by Senator Boswell certainly come within the parameters of the May economic statement, as was envisaged by Senator Evans. It was not intended that the debate would be restricted only to these particular pieces of legislation.
—There is no point of order. I ask Senator Boswell to stick to the matters before the Chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I can understand Senator Colston's embarrassment at Queenslanders possibly being deprived of their parliamentary representation. I know that Senator Colston sometimes braves the primary industry areas of western Queensland. I know that he will not be received very warmly when the people there know that they have no members to represent them in the State Parliament. The ethos of these people and their voice may well be lost in the State Parliament because of the combined weight of the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party today. Not only is this Government taxing them as a result of the May economic statement but it is also trying to deprive them of their parliamentary representation-something that is absolutely essential for people in rural areas. School bus routes will close. There is nothing in the May economic statement to support the continued provision of school bus routes. An amount of $50m is to be taken from local councils in rural areas. Government departments will close. There will be no departmental presence to support a decent standard of welfare, good living standards and health care for the rural people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now address the Bills, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I see that you are reaching for your copy of the Standing Orders. I do not want to transgress your good graces. In regard to this legislation before us tonight, I would like to pick up on some of the pluses of this Government. There are not too many, but let us take a few of them. The income equalisation deposit has always been National Party, Liberal Party and coalition policy. Not only was it coalition policy but it was a fact of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —When does it start again?
—It restarts in 1989-another year hence.
—It is not effective till 1 July 1990.

—I am informed by Senator Panizza, an authority on these matters, that it is not effective until 1 July 1990. We have had small reductions on the agricultural machinery tariffs, improvements on the rural adjustment scheme, and an increase in soil conservation expenditure. Of course, we must welcome all those things. However, only time will tell whether the Government's commitment in these areas will be fulfilled. On the one hand, this Government has given a few things. However, on the other hand it has increased export inspection charges-livestock tax-and has reduced the depreciation rates on plant machinery while further reducing desperately needed road funding and local government funding. That is what I alluded to in the earlier part of my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make some quick references to the wheat industry. The Government is proposing to review the current system whereby 95 per cent of estimated net returns for the current season and the lowest 2 per cent of the preceeding season is underwritten. This is to be changed so that producers will assume more of the responsibility of meeting the cost of price uncertainty.

I see that my time has almost expired. As I finish this very small contribution I warn the Government not to walk away from its underwriting scheme. This underwriting scheme was pressed into effect for the 1986-87 crop. Prior to that the industry protection figure was around 2 to 4 per cent. If the Government walks away from that underwriting protection no-one on this side of the House will let it forget the commitment that Mr Kerin has made to the industry. The industry is happy with Mr Kerin's commitment to it. I hope that, unlike when he came to power on an underwriting scheme promise for the sugar industry, which he failed to fulfil for about four or five years, he will not walk away from the wheat industry underwriting scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable senator claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

—During Senator Bos-well's speech I rose on a point of order and suggested that he was not speaking to the Bills before us. After Senator Boswell resumed he made some comment that I was embarrassed because of some Bills that had gone through this chamber earlier in the day. I wish to point out I am in no way embarrassed. I am pleased the Bills went through. The only embarrassment I have as a Queensland senator is that some people in Queensland were sufficiently misguided to send Senator Boswell into this place as well.
—Order! Senator Colston, a personal explanation must not be used to attack another senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, my National Party of Australia colleague, brought to the attention of the Senate the guillotining of the referenda debate today. Fancy a government, any self-respecting politician, guillotining any discussion on our Constitution in our bicentennial year. I commend Senator Boswell for his comments because they were factual; they were honest and true. Obviously the other side of the House had absolutely no interest in hearing them. That was evident this afternoon when it guillotined the whole debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell clearly pointed out-he put his point very well-that the so-called one vote one value referendum question reduces the representation of country people. Country people should reject it outright, as they should reject all four proposed referendum questions because there is a plot behind every single one of them. I will not comment too much in the short time I have on the four referendum questions except to say that if one thing is clear about question No. 3, on one vote one value, it is that there is a difference between gerrymandering and malapportionment. The Government has failed to spell out this difference. It failed to spell it out to the public of Australia. I assure the Government that I will be campaigning very strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —And very effectively, too, I might add.

—All the Opposition will be campaigning very effectively. The master of gerrymandering is the Government's own party. In New South Wales we see the gerrymander brought down by nifty Neville Wran, and in my own State of Victoria gerrymandering occurs in the seats of McEwen and Burke. It is a disgrace that the Australian Labor Party members for the seats of McEwen and Burke have even been elected, because at least 90 per cent of the land mass of those two seats is in the country. What sort of representatives are they? Australian Labor Party socialists representing country people is unheard of.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen today a government that just wants to get to its own Australian Labor Party Conference next week to slug it out over uranium and privatisation. Labor Party members want to get to Hobart and at all this expense sit in their luxury hotels and no doubt make a few phone calls to a few of their rich Western Australian business mates and ask them what policies should be brought forward and how they should handle this and that. But all that is further at the expense of this Parliament because this Government will shut it down, without having had any effective debate on our 1901 Constitution and without having had any effective debate on this May mini-Budget statement, the first Budget statement to be brought down since the 1987 October crash. If it thought it necessary to bring down a May mini-Budget following that crash, if it panicked enough to bring down that mini-Budget, and yet now expects this Parliament, the representatives of the people, to debate it in less than four hours, there is absolutely no doubt that the Government and the mini-Budget are shams. I have the firmest conviction that the people of Australia have reached a stage where they have utter contempt for this Government. They are contemptuous because of the lack of integrity and leadership it shows.

Only last year four leading Ministers made major economic statements declaring that Australia was facing economic peril. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) declared that we faced the peacetime equivalent of war. Prior to that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made a statement that if we did not make major changes we would become a banana republic. We had the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) declaring we were heading down the Argentinean road. We also had the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) declaring that the International Monetary Fund came perilously close to knocking on Australia's door. It was all due to the mounting foreign debt, the $112 billion debt.

What has changed since then? Certainly not the $112 billion debt. Yet each one of those senior Ministers, Ministers who hold leading positions in this country, has attempted to sell this May mini-Budget to the people as if nothing is wrong, it is all over, there will be no more expenditure cuts and we will have tax cuts in the future. They declare that Australia is back on the tracks. We know it is not. We know the debt is still $112 billion by anyone's measurement. Obviously the ordinary family Australian is still suffering from low living standards. So what has changed since those four senior Ministers made those statements some 12 months ago? We know it is not the debt burden. What has changed is the nerve of the Prime Minister, the nerve of the Treasurer and the nerve of the Finance Minister. We saw how the Finance Minister lost his nerve last night. Probably the only person who has not lost his nerve is Senator Button, because he never had any. He is spineless. We really know when leadership in this country is lacking; it is when the ordinary Australian treats those who hold such senior positions as the ones I have mentioned with utter suspicion, when they consider that they have no integrity at all.

This mini-Budget is simply tinkering with the economy. It is a non-event. Who believes there will be tax cuts in 12 months? Why should we believe that set of Ministers? Anyone who believes there will be substantial cuts in the next 12 months is gullible and I feel sorry for them because the Government already has its let-out clause. That let-out clause says that the tax cuts are conditional on an acceptable wages outcome in 1988-89. The Government's let-out clause simply means a decision will be based on whatever the political climate is at the time. That properly sums up this Government's economic management. It is devoid of vision and it is made up of political opportunists.

As the other speakers have pointed out, our time in this debate is limited and each speaker must allow his colleagues to come on. But I simply wish to finish by making one guiding point about this mini-Budget. It is a point I will take up in the future, when given the opportunity, and that will undoubtedly be in the new Parliament House as tomorrow is our last sitting day in this House. This May mini-Budget discourages ordinary Australians from saving, and nothing exemplifies that more than the changes to superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I wish to speak on that part of the May mini-Budget that deals with local government and financial assistance, I am pleased that the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) is in the chamber. I am also pleased to see that Senator Powell is here. Although I did not have the opportunity of hearing her speech, I know she has a lot of feeling for local government, and I hope she said something about the level of financial assistance to local government.
—I have amendments about that.

—I am pleased about that. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, has been described as all sorts of things-as a magician with economics, as Scrooge McKeating. If I had to describe Senator Reynolds, the Minister for Local Government, I think I would have to call her the great illusionist. I am speaking about the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, and this is a time when local governments throughout Australia are being subjected to the biggest con job of all time. Members of the Government are crusading around the country speaking about the so-called manna from heaven which will flow from the token recognition of local government, but in the very next breath they turn their backs on local government, supporting unprecedented funding cuts which will not only cripple local government but also millions of ordinary Australian ratepayers.

SPEECH.PARA: I said yesterday that there had been a lot of feeling at the local government conference in Canberra about recognition of local government. I am sure that when those council clerks, town clerks, wardens, mayors and shire presidents return to their respective municipalities and have to frame budgets for 1989-90 and discover the real effects of this Government's funding cutbacks they will forget about local government recognition and get down to the real work of trying to balance their budgets. I will be very surprised if they do not find themselves looking at rate increases of 15 to 20 per cent.

I was very interested to hear mentioned tonight the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that there would be no child living in poverty by 1990. There may not be, and I hope there are not, but there will be a lot of local governments in poverty by 1990. If this Government's record on local government funding and road funding continues, local governments certainly will be in poverty. In fact, I have been told that some councils in northern Victoria have been talking about going to the wall because of their funding cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania?
—And in Tasmania.
—I thought you would be supporting my amendments.

—I hope so; I have not had a chance to read them yet. I read with interest the recent news report that the Prime Minister received a resounding reception when he attended the local government conference in Canberra. I too took the opportunity of spending half a day there, and whilst I did not receive a rousing reception-in fact I got a rather cool reception from some of my colleagues-many of those representatives of local government who are here in Canberra at the moment know only too well what is going on, and their numbers are growing all the time. They know that on the one hand they are receiving what appears to be something, while on the other hand things are being taken away. As I said earlier, when they strike their rates and do their budgets, they will find out how sincere this so-called friend of local government is.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us today is just another patch-up job. It is designed to amend the formula under which general purpose financial assistance for local government is determined. Previously this was to be calculated by changing the amount by the percentage change to Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States. In my time in local government there have been many different formulas. In fact, there have been so many different formulas that it has been a little like a new mother with a new baby. She does not know which formula to use to stop the baby getting sick. It seems to me that in this case the formula the Minister for Local Government and this Government are putting forward is an attempt to make local government feel better. As I said, at the end of the day when they have to strike their rates they will find out what has really happened.

We know what has happened to the States. Senator Crichton-Browne said earlier today that the Commonwealth Government played a big part in cutting their budgets. There is some $982m in spending cuts in the mini-Budget and $870m, or nearly 90 per cent, is to come from the States and local government. That is disgraceful. Why can this Government not put its money where its mouth is and cut its own Budget rather than decimating the States? No doubt all honourable senators will see the effects of these cuts on our States. I was very disturbed to see what our Premier in Tasmania has had to do to try to balance his Budget after the tremendous cuts that have been made to the State.

Almost $80m has been cut from road funding-$50m this year and a predicted $29m next year. I noticed with interest that the Minister for Local Government said, `But we are going to provide the same amount of money for local roads as we did last year'. That is terrific. That does not account for inflation, but even if it did, as I and many of the other people here who have been in local government know, the State governments will pass on the cuts. If they are not receiving any money for roads, the Minister cannot tell me that they are not going to say to local government, `You are getting a fair deal from the Minister for Local Government and the Commonwealth Government, so we are going to cut back our percentage to you'. We all know that although local government is the third tier of government and a very important tier, being closest to the people, it is the end of the road. It is always the end of the road. If funding cuts start at the top, it is always local governments that end up receiving the raw end of the deal. That is exactly what this is here today-the raw end of the deal.

We have seen another con job that the great illusionist here, Senator Reynolds, has perpetrated on local government. I have been very disappointed that the local government bodies seem to have missed it. In the good old days of the Liberal Government, when we gave them a guaranteed 2 per cent of personal income tax collections, which has now been reduced to 1.66 per cent, we gave them the money for a full 12-months period. A lot of local government members have said to me, both today and yesterday, and I am sure to other members of the Senate, that they appreciated that. They got the money and they could invest it. It was another source of income to them and they knew exactly where they were. But the great illusionist over here has introduced quarterly payments. Local government let it happen and did not say much about it. I was very disappointed that it did that because that represents a great reduction of funds.
We have only to look at some of the statements made prior to the mini-Budget to see that they back up what has been said in this chamber today. One article states:
Forty government backbenchers have warned of grave political consequences if the Federal Government makes further cuts to road funding . . .

Well, the Government has made those funding cuts. I wonder what the consequences will be. Are we going to see roads self-destruct? We have already seen sealed roads being ripped up, graded and put back to gravel. It is a retrograde step. Our road system is one of our national assets and all this Government has done is run it down. The Australian of Tuesday, 24 May, states, `Road funds cut ``puts 2500 jobs, 90 lives at risk'' '. That is what this Government thinks about the people of Australia. It is not particularly worried about the roads or the accident rate. I think it was Mr Larry King who pointed out the effect that lack of road funding will have on accident rates in this country.

In conclusion, I believe that the formula this Government has come up with at short notice for a 2.5 per cent increase over local government's entitlement in 1978, which in real terms is a reduction of $20m, is just another example of the measures which this Government seems hell bent on initiating and will send local authorities bankrupt throughout Australia. Not only can we look forward to reduced road construction and maintenance, but also retrenchments and massive rate hikes. With those few comments I pass over to my colleague Senator Chapman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The May economic statement to which these Bills relate was not so much a mini-Budget; it was more a meanie-Budget. It was a May statement all right-we may get a tax cut, we may not. The unions may do a deal on wages, they may not. Interest rates may be contained. Pigs may fly! No wonder the Government is jackbooting these Bills through the Senate with less than four hours debate, allowing us, by agreement, only 10 minutes per speaker. It is so ashamed of the reality and the consequences of this statement that it does not want it subjected to adequate parliamentary scrutiny. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) calls the concoction of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a magic pudding. In its self-delusion and flights of fancy, it is more a magic mushroom. We know how mushrooms are grown.

SPEECH.PARA: If time permits tonight, I will highlight three of a number of areas in which this document is dishonest. Those three areas are its accounting fiddles; the taxation of superannuation; and the imposts on the rural sector. Contrary to claims of expenditure restraint by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, under this statement real expenditure by the Hawke Labor Government on its own Federal Government programs will rise. The facade of restraint is achieved by accounting fiddles, by strangling the State governments and by an unusually optimistic economic forecast. The Treasurer claimed that real outlays are expected to fall by 1.5 per cent but, when adjustment is made for a number of accounting fiddles, it is clear that real Commonwealth expenditure on its own programs actually increases.

There are several fiddles that achieve this: primary industry charges and levies and light dues and Navigation Act receipts which were previously classified as offsets within outlays have now been classified as revenue; discounts and premiums on Treasury bonds have been reclassified from financing transactions to outlays. According to page 26 of the document, these changes will add an estimated $974m to recorded outlays in 1987-88 and $783m in 1988-89. Further, the Civil Aviation Authority will be shifted off-Budget from 1 July 1988, reducing outlays in 1988-89 by about $270m. On this basis the Treasurer claims that outlays will fall in real terms in 1988-89 against 1987-88 as follows: estimated total outlays for 1987-88 of $78,577m and for 1988-89 an amount of $81,651m, giving a nominal increase of 3.9 per cent and a real decrease of 1.5 per cent.

It may well be appropriate to reclassify these Budget transactions to align them more closely with international accounting procedures, but it is grossly dishonest to claim that mere accounting changes are expenditure restraint. If allowance is made for these accounting changes, the true situation is that in 1987-88 estimated total outlays will be $77,603m and, for 1988-89, $81,138m-a nominal increase of 4.6 per cent, being a real decrease of 0.8 per cent.

As we know, State governments have been forced to bear the brunt of cuts to Forward Estimates-to the tune of some $870m, or 89 per cent of the total cuts of $982m in the Forward Estimates, and to the tune of some $1,740m less in State funding for 1988-89 compared with 1987-88.

To get the real picture about the Commonwealth's own spending, we should exclude those grants to the States. On that basis, the Commonwealth's own spending rises from some $62,773m in 1987-88 to $68,048m in 1988-89-a nominal increase of 8.4 per cent, representing a real increase, after inflation, of 3 per cent. So much for the Treasurer's claims of expenditure restraint. What he claims to be a cut of 1.5 per cent is in fact a real increase of 3 per cent on the Commonwealth's own spending.

Do we need any more demonstration of this Government's dishonesty? The Government is not only dishonest; it is also hypocritical. On Monday, in a speech to a national seminar organised by the Institute of Municipal Management, the Prime Minister said:
I know some of you have been concerned about cuts to funding for local government in the May statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another barber's cap performance.
—It was not a very brilliant performance. The Prime Minister continued:

SPEECH.PARA: If the same cut had been applied to local government's recurrent funding as to the State's the forward estimates would have been cut back by some $28 million.

Of course, as we know, the cut to local government was $20m. What cant and hypocrisy! What is good for the goose ought to be good for the gander. If the Commonwealth had the guts to embrace the same restraint on its own spending as it has forced on the States, we would have seen a cut of 6.23 per cent, or $4,247m, on its Forward Estimates, allowing total outlays, including grants to the States, of $77,002m for 1988-89, or $63,912m on its own programs. That represents over $4,000m less than the actual spending will be in each case next year.

More than that, if the Commonwealth embraced the restraint that it is imposing on the States, not just in relation to the Forward Estimates but in relation to 1988-89 compared with 1987-88, we would see a cut of 11.73 per cent. That is the cut which the Government has imposed on the States next year compared with the current year. That will represent a cut of some $7,365m in Commonwealth outlays, reducing total outlays to $68,498m next year, or $55,408m, on its own Commonwealth programs.

How dare the Prime Minister and the Treasurer strut around claiming to be restraining expenditure. The fact is that if they took the same medicine that they are imposing on the States, spending on their own programs next year would be $55,408m instead of $68,048m-a real fall of 17.1 per cent instead of a real increase of 3 per cent. It is good enough for the States, which have exercised more restraint over the last half decade than this Hawke Labor Government, but apparently it is not good enough for this Government. Such savings would readily fund the tax cuts which have been advocated by the Opposition.

The Government's dishonesty is also evident in relation to its treatment of superannuation. The Treasurer says that no-one will lose 1c under the new superannuation tax, but David Connolly has already proved how someone on a mere $15,000 a year will wind up $1,762 worse off. That is not much; $1,762 is less than 10 per cent of a Treasurer's travelling allowance. Further analysis proves that retirees will lose much more than that. Certainly, a tax of 15 per cent on employer contributions merely offsets the reduction of 15 per cent of the tax on lump sum payments. However, the 15 per cent tax on income of superannuation funds is a new and additional tax. In practice, it is simply not possible to offset that tax by using the imputed tax credits from fully franked dividends received by the funds from those Australian companies providing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a lie.

—It is a lie. Of course, it is to be expected that some scheme thought up in the middle of the night by a Treasury boffin would be all theory and no practice. According to the Government's own document, superannuation funds currently have about 15 per cent of their total investment in equities offering franked dividends. But to have sufficient tax credits to offset the tax, they would have to lift that to about 60 per cent, given the much lower yield from dividends than from interest, rent or other incomes. A number of funds are precluded from such a high percentage of investments being in equities such as capital stable approved deposit funds and capital guaranteed funds. Of course, it would be most imprudent for the rest to invest such a high proportion of their total funds in equities. Quite simply, it is not possible for them to achieve those adequate tax offsets. Apart from being imprudent, it is also not possible, because there are simply not enough shares to go around. The total value of the current share market in industrial and commercial stocks is about $110,000m. To achieve the requisite percentage of franked equities, the superannuation funds would need to lift their current investment in equities from about $7,000m to between $25,000m and $30,000m. There are simply not enough shares to go around to achieve that. We see the Government committing the fallacy of composition, something that basic economics students know to avoid.
