PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 April, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Bill 1988 has been brought before the Parliament in order to establish the new Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The idea of this Authority was first floated by the Government when it announced its in-principle decision almost two years ago, on 22 October 1986. There was a further statement about a year later when the then Minister for aviation, Senator Evans, said in the Parliament that the Government would be proceeding with the establishment of the Authority and that we would see the appropriate legislation in the Autumn session. That has now happened but, of course, it is 18 months since the announcement was first made. The Authority will have operational authority and responsibility to cover air traffic control. It will handle and regulate flight advisory services. It will provide communications, navigation and surveillance systems at airports for the operation of airlines and will maintain and operate rescue and firefighting machinery and equipment at airports. In addition, it will provide aeronautical information services and organise where necessary-hopefully not very often-aviation search and rescue services.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is an amazing piece of legislation. Nowhere in the second reading speech, in any other statement or in any utterance by any Minister can I find any justification for the Government's action. There is no reason set down for the establishment of the separate Authority, which will only take over the role of the department which is currently undertaking the work. There is no mention, no skerrick anywhere, of any evidence of the need for the establishment of the Authority and, as I said, there is no attempt by the Government to justify its action.

There must be some motive that has not emerged in the public arena. Certainly, there has been no statement by the Government as to what its real intentions are, but I think we can conclude that the establishment of this Authority-we have just heard from Senator Chapman that the May economic statement announced reduced expenditures of some $250m as a result of its establishment-will somehow provide another means by which imposts can be made on the people. Quite clearly, it will provide another nefarious means of raising taxes. Clearly, it is another way of gaining for the Government the $250m which was previously met by direct subventions off the Budget. This means just further taxes. It is just another piece of the Government's chicanery in its mini-Budget, as it described it, brought down one week ago.

The amount of $250m has been taken off the Budget by the simple means of establishing a new Authority to operate the services for the airline industry. This will allow the Authority to raise its charges to gather in the $250m that it would otherwise be getting from the Government. It is just another form of taxation. This is not mentioned in the second reading speech. There is no attempt to set out the cost benefits of setting up the Aviation Authority. There is no attempt to provide us with any kind of cost impact study as to who is going to bear the cost, what the costs will be and the real nature of the operation. However, one thing is for sure. From the words in the second reading speech we can garner a little information about what is intended. We read that the Aviation Authority will be required to revalue all its assets. We know what this means because we have seen that happen in respect of Telecom Australia and other Government authorities. Revaluing the assets-presumably that means upwards-and the Government requiring the Authority to get a certain return for it on the basis of the investment of those assets at a higher value is to justify the imposition of higher charges upon the public, in this case upon the airlines and the airline users.

As a result of this measure we will see increased values being applied to the assets which were previously owned by the former Department of Aviation. That will lead to the Government requiring the Authority to return to it a dividend based upon that higher value of assets. In turn, the Authority-because it will have to pay that dividend to the Government-will be required to raise its charges on the people. This is just blackmail and another form of taxation. It is another example of the chicanery of the Hawke Labor Government.

There has been much talk about the consultation that was to occur with the industry as to the establishment of this Authority. As far as I can understand it, there has been practically no consultation at all with the industry. As I have just mentioned, operators have no idea of what will happen as regards costs. What is going to happen with regard to staffing? I am sure that Senator MacGibbon, who is very well informed about the detailed operation of flight services, will be expanding on these matters in his remarks a little later.

We note that the operations of the Authority will not have in-built biases in favour of efficiency. The staff of the CAA will remain covered by the Public Service Act. It will obviously be another branch of the Public Service. Certainly, one must be very sceptical about the commercial activity which might be generated as a result of the establishment of this Authority. Again, inefficient charges and costs are to be imposed on industry.

Had the Government consulted more widely, it might have found industry in general very keen about seeing the promised review of airline regulations, air safety regulations, and so on, undertaken and completed before the new Authority was created. We have heard nothing of the results of an inquiry or review of such regulations. As we all know, there is a myriad of air navigation regulations that suffocate the aviation industry and build extra costs into the air fares that are charged to the travelling public. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon will expand on these matters in the course of his remarks.

The Government ought to have taken the opportunity to deregulate the industry as much as possible. As we are noting in other areas of Government activity, the Government has backed off, because of union pressure, from deregulating industry and relieving the burden of costs from the back of unhappy consumers. As I mentioned earlier, revaluation of the assets will have very extensive implications for the industry in the future. We have no knowledge of what the costs will be. Obviously, they will rise. The Government is not telling us by how much the charges will increase as a result of the changes which it has in mind. Clearly, there will be confusion in the industry while these matters are being discussed.

One matter of great concern is whether a staff ceiling will be imposed on the new Authority. We note that the limit imposed on the number of employees of the Federal Airports Corporation is now 1,600, compared with the limit of 1,200 that was first established. So the limit has gone up by about one-third since that Corporation was established only six or eight months ago. We hope that that will not happen in this new Authority, which presently has 7,000 employees across Australia. Quite clearly, there is room for the Government to give undertakings in this regard.

I refer finally to the craven capitulation of this Government on the question of deregulation and privatisation generally. A little over a year ago, on 27 April 1987, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated:
Some assets-
presumably public assets-

may be used more efficiently outside the public sector. Sales of some assets would certainly relieve the Budget of ongoing subventions and, of course, all asset (sales) produce a capital appropriation to the Budget which either retires debt or slows down the buildup of debt and hence relieves the Budget of its very high public debt interest commitment.

The Treasurer, a little over a year ago, told the Australian people that privatisation was good for them and that the Hawke Government was heading in that direction because it believed that it would relieve the huge debt load on the public sector by paying off debt and thereby reducing interest payments, which, in turn, would lead to lower taxes on the Australian people. That was said a year ago, before the 1987 election. The Treasurer probably had that in mind at the time. Some similar remarks were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in August, a month or so after the July 1987 election. He said:
The question should be not: `Why should we sell a given enterprise?', but: `Why should we continue to tie up our resources in it?'.

That was a fairly gung ho, Rambo approach to privatisation from the Prime Minister. One would have expected that we would be charging down the road, about to sell public enterprises as fast as possible, to the advantage of the Australian people. But no; we have observed over the last 12 months discussion-debate, as Senator Evans refers to it-within the Australian Labor Party (ALP) what has amounted to a big fat zero. There have been no moves of any great significance in the area of deregulation in the aviation industry. There has been some movement at the edges in the telecommunications industry. The Commonwealth Bank remains in public hands. There has been no attempt to move into the more peripheral areas of Commonwealth business undertakings.

These matters represent a failure on the part of the Labor Government to face up to its responsibilities and meet the very criteria that were laid down by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, its two most senior Ministers a little over a year ago. This obvious capitulation to the trade union movement by the Government deserves condemnation. It means that in the long run the Australian people will have to pay higher prices for inefficient services being provided by public enterprises which, in the Prime Minister's own words, should be undertaken by private industry. We read only a week or so ago of further comments on this matter by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in his speech to the seminar on privatisation convened by the economics policy committee of the Australian Capital Territory branch of the ALP on 8 May. He said:
In short, I find it a little hard to understand why some people see intrinsic merit in using scarce resources to do something in the public sector which would otherwise be done in the private sector.

That was what Senator Walsh said about a fortnight or three weeks ago. Yet this Government has not been able to get itself mobile on this matter. It has fallen into a morass over its privatisation and deregulation policy. It has been unable to assist or lift from the backs of the Australian people the burden which has been imposed by inefficient enterprises over a long period. It is the interests of the consumer which are at stake. Surely, it is the role of government to get out of inefficient enterprises and to encourage more efficient operations wherever possible in order to improve the standard of service to the community. The Government has failed miserably in that area in recent times. Obviously, its commitment to improve the standard of service to the community has not been raised by its latest move-the new Civil Aviation Authority which this legislation will create.

As I mentioned in my opening remarks, there is nothing in the second reading speech or in any other paper that is available that demonstrates why it is necessary to have such an authority. It has been created simply as a taxing device-another branch, if you like, of the Australian Taxation Office-to raise another $250m-plus from the Australian community in order to meet Mr Keating's demands for a reduction in Government expenditure. In other words, it is about replacing saved expenditures with higher taxes on the Australian people. It is not an efficient enterprise in the sense that was obviously intended by Senator Walsh's remarks at an earlier time. Clearly, the Government needs to address issues. It needs to explain in the Parliament tonight why it is necessary to establish a new authority of this kind. We in the Liberal and National parties simply do not believe that it is necessary and, for that reason, we will oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Civil Aviation Bill 1988, but with reservations. We share the concern of the Opposition over this new organisation, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). I rang a number of people about this Bill, people who are involved in the general aviation industry. I rang Dick Smith, who has long been a critic of the Department responsible for aviation, now the Department of Transport and Communications, and the way it operates in this country to stifle the development of aviation. I rang Peter Petroni of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia. I rang a number of other people. They all said, `We suppose the Bill might as well be passed. It could not be any worse than the Department. Maybe-just maybe-it will be better'.
—They are optimists.

—Yes, they are optimists. Something came to my mind as I talked to people about this matter, and that was the fact that these phone calls always develop into a swapping of horror stories about the Department. This happens in Australia any time two pilots, or two people in the industry, get together. I have flown in the United States of America. I was a fixed base operator there. I owned my own flying service. I am a flight instructor, commercial pilot, and all that stuff. In the United States when pilots get together they talk about aircraft and about the weather. They do not talk about the Federal Aeronautics Administration of the United States (FAA), because it operates in conjunction with the industry to help the industry. The FAA and the industry work together for the common good, for the common safety, for the common development of aviation. It does not happen in this country. That is the tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people were sceptical about a private corporation staffed by public servants with security of tenure and all the lurks and perks of the Yes, Minister bureaucrat. I too am sceptical. I sincerely hope it works, but I am sceptical. There was some scepticism about another area of this Bill. That scepticism came from the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. It was afraid that some clauses of this Bill would trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. It specifically referred to clause 29 (3) and clause 30. We have looked at this concern and we foreshadow some amendments which we will move at the committee stage to make sure that civil liberties are not unduly trespassed upon and that people have the rights which they will be denied if this Bill goes to law unamended. There has been quite a bit of scepticism about this Bill.

The Department and its failures are the reason that this Bill has been drafted ostensibly to try to revamp, revise and revitalise the Department so that it will operate in a more supportive manner to the industry. After all, who would want to fly on an airline run by the Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't joke. Sometimes when they put a VIP on, we have to go on it.

—Yes, we may have to. Who would want to run an airline flown by the Department? One would have to fill in forms in quadruplicate for tickets. One would have to wait months for confirmation of the tickets. One could probably board the aircraft and be told that the pilots would take off three hours after completing reams of paperwork. They would fly by the rules-we can be sure of that: there would be no flexibility in the Department's airline. Once in the air, one could be told in mid-flight that the plane was not going to Melbourne after all and that the passengers would be landing at Albury-Wodonga. No explanations would be given-none whatsoever. If one wanted to find out why, one would have to take the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That is what the Department's airline would be like. And it would be unsafe.
—And it would cost you $200.

—It would cost $200 and it would be unsafe-unless one was like the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, who is a lawyer and who could afford to take the matter to the AAT to ensure that his ticket was properly discharged. Unfortunately, this is what happens. I would actually be frightened to fly on a Department airline because, unfortunately, the Department adds to the hazards of flying. It does not make flying safer.

SPEECH.PARA: Flying is inherently safe as a means of transportation. We do not fight with traffic on a road; we are not worried about people coming out from intersections; and we do not worry about a lot of the hazards of ground transport. It can be made unsafe if the flexibility of the operators and the pilots is interfered with in a dangerous manner and if they are forced to fly in a dangerous manner. There are a number of ways in which the Department does this. For instance, the control zones take all of the available air space in a basin, leaving the area around the basins. Cities such as Melbourne, Sydney and Hobart are all in basins. The control zones take up the nice air space in the middle. The visual flight rules-VFR-corridors are around the outside, in the mountainous areas. People are afraid to fly into the control zones because of the penalties the Department can impose on them. If they do not say the right things on the radio or if they make a minor infraction, they are gone; they are history; their licence has gone. So they fly into mountain tops. The Aviation Safety Digest comes out every month with stories of people who have flown into mountain tops because they have been afraid to contact departmental personnel. We do not know why they died, but everybody has a fear of declaring an emergency to the Department because they know of the forms they will have to fill out. That is not safe. The fact is that pilots do not wish to kill themselves. Airline operators do not wish to crash. It is the safety consciousness of the operators and the pilots which gives aviation in Australia its great safety record. The Department is not adding to that.

A number of very strange things have happened in the Department in terms of check pilots. I rang a number of people about this Bill. I rang a person who operates hot air balloons. It turns out that 80 per cent of hot air balloonists are actually commercial pilots, but that the Department has no-one with a commercial balloon pilot's licence. It has two private-rated balloon pilots and no-one to check out the commercial pilots in the ballooning industry. It goes on and on. Any pilot could give us several hours, I am sure, of such horror stories.

The bottom line is that pilots themselves want to be safe. The old adage that there are old pilots and bold pilots but there are no old bold pilots still holds today, as it always did. The Department gets into some very petty arguments which cost the taxpayers and the litigants much money. One argument is about night flying and night colour blindness. I have here a letter from a Marcus Ryder in Templestowe, Victoria. He is 19 years old and is currently studying for his private pilot's licence. This man has passed tests which would allow him to fly jet aircraft in the Royal Australian Air Force. His night flying vision is that good-but the Department will not let him fly at night because he has not passed one antiquated test.

A physician in Geelong, named Arthur Pape, has the same problem of night colour blindness. He has taken the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and he has beaten the Department, but he spent thousands of dollars on it. The Department has spent thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money in fighting this case. One would think that, since he has won, the Department would give up. But no, there are 10 more cases coming up and the Department will fight each one at the taxpayers' expense. Why? Is it unsafe for these people to fly at night? No, it is not unsafe. It merely does not fit in with the regulations of the Department.

I hope the CAA will change the situation. The Department needs flexibility. It needs to change the system. It needs flexibility to operate with commonsense rather than with the rigid bureaucratic structure which may guarantee jobs but which does not guarantee safety. One of the problems is that many of the Department's personnel are ex-military personnel. They fly by the book; they do not have to worry about the cost of anything. Who in the military worries about the cost of anything? Yet these people are now running a civilian outfit where cost should be an object but is not.

What do we do? We hope that the CAA will not just be an old dog in the manger, with a new name. We need a flexible, responsive partnership between government, the industry and general aviation. This partnership could herald a new golden era in Australian aviation. A CAA which is merely a renamed Department of Aviation, DOA, would be the dead hand which would stifle Australian aviation forever. I intend to move a number of amendments in the committee stage. I will foreshadow them now to save some time. They have been agreed to by the Government and the Opposition. I hope that they will go some way towards relieving the apprehension of people towards the CAA.

Amendment No. 1 corrects the omission of a rating from the list of items, a refusal to issue of which or the imposition of a condition upon which may give rise to an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In other words, if one is not allowed a rating, not just a licence, by the DOA one may take it to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. No. 2 addresses the concerns raised by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills in its seventh report, on the invasion of personal liberties. No. 3 relates to the same topic, as do Nos 4 and 5. No. 6 restores the second element of the protection against surreptitious revenue raising found in paragraph 26 (2) (ca) of the Air Navigation Act 1920, upon which this clause is modelled. The DOA has long been known for sneaking around and figuring out ways of penalising the industry and pilots. Hopefully, this will close one door. The explanatory memorandum of No. 7 reads:

This amendment makes reviewable the decision to take a statutory lien in respect of an aircraft. Without this decision being appellable the primary issue of whether there is a liability to pay cannot be tested until after an aircraft is deregistered.

At present, after one's aircraft is taken off the roll one can then appeal. That amounts to confiscation; certainly lack of use of the machine. Once the aircraft has been taken and stricken from the rolls one can appeal. That is not a fair go. No. 8 reads:
This amendment brings the regulation of air navigation safety under the same level of Parliamentary scrutiny as the regulation of marine navigation is under the Navigation Act 1912.

This means that any order can be brought before the Senate and disallowed. If it turns out that it is discriminatory, if it is too expensive for the industry or somewhat frivolous in its nature, it can be disallowed. This brings Parliament into control over some aspects of the DOA, which I think is a very healthy thing. Parliament and the people should have far more say in what is happening in aviation in this country. I again say that the Australian Democrats will support the Bill with reservations and amendments. We hope that the DOA personnel who move into the CAA will take this as an opportunity to turn over a new leaf and operate with the aircraft industry, the general aviation industry, so that we can produce a viable industry in Australia which is cost-effective and which will answer the needs of the Australian flying public well into the twenty-first century.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the Civil Aviation Bill 1988. There simply has not been one valid reason advanced by the Government as to why the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) should be set up. The proposal is badly thought out. There has been minimal consultation with the aviation industry. The Opposition sees very clearly the urgent need to restore competence and efficiency to the aviation industry and aviation services in this country, but we do not see that this is the way to go about it. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister who once represented him in the other place, Mr Duncan, are the latest in a long line of Ministers who simply have no personal experience of the aviation industry. I say that in no unkind way at all, and certainly imply no personal criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said on previous occasions here, aviation requires special aptitudes. It is different from most other forms of human activity. The lessons we have learnt in aviation over the last 80 or so years have been bought at a very high price. They have been bought at the highest price possible to pay-human lives. As Senator Sanders said, we can operate safely and predictably in the air but it takes a certain set of aptitudes to do it. I am not sure that the Civil Aviation Authority will necessarily enshrine those attitudes. When I say that one needs special aptitudes to operate in the aviation world I am not neglecting the commercial side, because it is a very difficult world to operate in commercially. Unless one is commercially successful one does not survive. In essence, the Bill provides that the functions that were discharged by the old Department of Aviation or of Civil Aviation be discharged by the new Authority with the exception of the maintenance of a number of airfields which have been transferred to the Federal Airports Corporation.

Most of what Senator Sanders said is perfectly true. It might have been said in a more colourful way than I would have said it, but there are some real problems in the relationship between the Department and the aviation community. I am pleased that the amendments the Australian Democrats will move deal with the very real points raised in the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills criticisms of this Bill. I have always been concerned about the way in which the Department has operated in such a heavy-handed way of finding people guilty before they went to court insofar as it has summary powers to take someone's licence away before the evidence has been collected, let alone assessed. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on page 2 it states:
It is the Government's view in the light of experience, that these functions-
namely, the functions of the old Depart- ment-
would now be better performed through a statutory authority . . .

There is simply nothing advanced in the way of evidence to support that point of view. The Government proposes to set up a board to manage the Civil Aviation Authority. Without being harsh, all it is doing is increasing the administrative costs of aviation in the country by at least $2m in the first instance. It is taking over 7,000 staff from the old Department to operate under Public Service conditions. Presumably it will not have the right to hire and fire the way the Federal Airports Corporation claims it does not have the right to hire and fire the employees it took over from the Department. Presumably it will have to pick up the superannuation entitlements for those 7,000 people. That is in contrast with the statement on page 5 of the second reading speech that the commercial nature of the authority needs to be clearly understood. The second reading speech very clearly puts the point that the Government hopes the body will be a commercially effective unit.

With the greatest of respect, public servants are not successful in the commercial world. That is no criticism of them, because their whole background is one of administration, not of the cut and thrust of the commercial world. There are no rewards and there are no censures for commercial operations built into the Public Service. It is really expecting too much for people with a lifetime in administration to go into the dog-eat-dog world of the commercial world and be successful. It just cannot happen.

I will deal with a few of the Opposition's criticisms of the Bill. We believe that there has been very little consultation with the industry. Very few details have been made public as to how the new Authority will work. We have grave reservations about the picking up of 7,000 employees from the Public Service and placing them into a commercial operation. I observe that with 7,000 employees there will be more than one employee for every aircraft on the Australian register, which is really a Rolls-Royce service. I certainly do not want more than one person looking after my aeroplane; I can look after it very well by myself and just talk to someone occasionally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they can polish them and take care of them.

—Yes. We are concerned that the Government has failed to implement its promised regulatory review before the creation of the Civil Aviation Authority because we think that the whole of the aviation scene is over-regulated. This is more or less in line with what Senator Sanders said.

SPEECH.PARA: But over and above everything else, the administration of the Department now is very inefficient. It is very run down, very expensive and over-regulated. I do know the Department very well. I have been flying for over 25 years and I have owned and operated aircraft in this country for over 20 years. I have had harmonious and close relationships with the Department for more than 20 years. I have seen a department that was arguably one of the best in the world 25 years ago-and it knew it was among the best in the world-go to what now is a stumbling bureaucracy. Morale in the Department is very low. Part of that has come from the change in the administration of the Department. In the last 15 years we have seen a Department of Civil Aviation which had its own ethos, its own esprit de corps, its own separate identity, changed in the Whitlam years to a Department of Transport, then back to a Department of Aviation in the Fraser years, and then to a Department of Transport again-mixing with the land, the sea and other forms of transport under the Hawke Administration-and now, since July last year, to the Department of Transport and Communications. This has had a great effect on the morale of the people involved, because to a certain degree they just do not know where they are going, they do not know who they are answerable to, and it has been reflected very much in their attitude to their work.

The most telling criticism of the Department that has been made in public in recent years has been that great book by Dick Smith, Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom-something that led to a House of Representatives inquiry and something which has led to absolutely no response from the Government and no change in the way the Department does its business.

Coupled with all these matters is the fact that the Government puts very low priority on aviation. The very first thing it did when it came into office in 1983 was to cut $20m out of the $70m budget that year for the Brisbane Airport that was being built. We have seen a great run-down in the expenditure on airways services-on communications, on navigation aids and, particularly, radar. Expenditure has not been met when it should have been met and we have got a long way behind the eight ball there.

One of the other things that are annoying the Department of Aviation and contributing to bad morale is the way it has been split up and the way the Federal Airports Commission, which is intensely disliked by the old Department, has come into existence.

The Government knows it has a mess on its hands and it wants to isolate itself from the mess. That is why it has set up this Civil Aviation Authority. It wants to create a statutory authority that can stand apart from ministerial and governmental responsibility. But the facts of life are that that will not work, and the Minister and the Government cannot evade their responsibility for the regulation of the airways services in Australia.

I said before that it is not easy to survive in the aviation world. It is a very difficult world. We have got enormously high costs in this country, and it does not matter whether one is trying to operate a charter airline, flying passengers or freight, for hire and reward, or to operate in a maintenance facility as an engineering workshop-it is very difficult to survive. The costs that are borne by the industry-admittedly, a lot of them are generated overseas-have gone up astronomically. In the last five years the price of simple thrust bearings for propeller governors that probably cost $4.70 has risen to over $200. Five years ago magneto condensers cost $20; they are now over $100. Five years ago fuel pumps for modern twins cost about $800; today they are over $2,000. It is difficult to survive without being harassed and hamstrung by an over-regulated and intrusive system.

I want to come back to the business of the Government's lack of concern for aviation and the way it has not been funding the airways services the way it should. I was very interested in recent times-I think it has been on three occasions-that the Minister has made a reply to Senator Sheil with respect to radar at Coolangatta. The Minister's explanation has been that even if radar had been provided at Coolangatta, the recent tragic accident would still have occurred. His reason for that is that the accident took place in the circuit area and that control of the circuit area is mediated visually by the controller in the tower and that radar would not have helped him. That happens to be true-but it is only less than half the truth.

The truth of the matter is that there is a very busy zone at Coolangatta. Had there been an airfield radar there, there would have been a number of controllers on duty. There would have been one controller doing the approach control, looking at the traffic seeking an airways clearance into the zone and flying in the zone, which is probably 20 miles in diameter. There would have been another controller whose sole task, visually, would have been to watch the traffic and control it in the airfield circuit.

Another very important point of the provision of radar in that circumstance would have been that the approach controller would have known the precise position of all the aircraft in the zone. As it happens at present, the controller asks the pilot to report where he is and he does that visually with reference to landmarks on the ground. People do not always fly in their own backyards. People genuinely make mistakes in unfamiliar areas identifying where they are. It puts an added strain on a controller if there is one controller looking after a busy zone such as Coolangatta and trying to control every aircraft in the 20-odd mile diameter of that zone. So I reject very much the Minister's argument that radar would not have helped at Coolangatta.

More importantly than that, I have a great concern, as a Queenslander and as an airman, about Cairns Airport. Cairns Airport is one of the most dangerous airports in Australia. It has a number of high mountains very close to it. There is a mountain range to the west of the airfield and to the south-east there are hills. There is high ground right in the circuit area. Cairns has a typical wet tropical climate. When it rains in Cairns, people literally cannot see more than 20 yards ahead. It is quite different from the rain shadow area of Townsville. It is also a very busy airport. It is the third busiest airport in Australia.

I flew into Cairns at the end of last year. I was a passenger in the front seat of an aircraft. I had a headset on. I was just staggered at the amount of radio traffic at 4 o'clock in the afternoon getting into Cairns. I am advised that within the recent past a regular public transport jet aircraft departed Cairns and the traffic was so intense that until the captain switched to the Townsville frequency he simply could not get his departure call in once he was airborne. This is a very busy airport. It also attracts a lot of charter operators-for the Gulf, the west, the inland, and up the Reef. They are often very low time pilots who are on their first commercial job.

I can remember from when I was a student that the Queen wanted to fly into Cairns. She was not allowed to fly into Cairns because it was judged that Cairns Airport was too high a risk in 1953 for the Queen to go into. The conditions today are precisely the same. There is simply no radar there. Yet Cairns has been an international airport since March 1984.

I am telling the Minister that he faces the certainty of an accident in that area. It may be an accident that involves a 747 or the like. Possibly 200 or 400 lives will be lost because the fundamentals are wrong. We know with certainty that we are going to have an accident there. What we do not know is when it will happen. The other thing we know is that it is a preventable accident. But the Department is doing nothing. There is a proposal to put a radar set on the field in 1990. I believe that tenders have already been called. But there is no reason why that cannot be installed more or less straight away. It is only a small cost of about $6m. It is a fraction of the cost of the whole value of the aircraft that will be involved in the accident, to say nothing of the human lives. The Opposition does not believe that the inaction of the Minister and the Department in the present situation will be alleviated one little bit by the creation of the Civil Aviation Authority.

Before I close I want to refer to one final technical point. I regret that we do not have a committee stage on this Bill. Aircraft are very vulnerable to malicious damage and things such as that. I suppose that they are different from cars, where terrorists can put bombs in them, but that does not happen very frequently. If anyone interferes with a car people probably will walk away from it with a few scratches but if anyone interferes with an aircraft people lose their lives. In relation to interference with a crew or aircraft clause 24 of the Bill states:
(2) A person shall not tamper with an aircraft or an aircraft component or item of equipment.
Penalty: $5000 or imprisonment for 2 years, or both.
Section 15 of the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963 provides:
A person who does an act or thing capable of prejudicing the safe operation of an aircraft to which this Part applies-
(a) with intent to prejudice the safe operation of that aircraft; and
(b) with intent to cause the death of a person or with reckless indifference to the safety of the life of a person, is guilty of an indictable offence punishable by death.

There is a vast difference between an indictable offence punishable by death, and a $5,000 fine or imprisonment for two years. I do not know which piece of legislation takes precedence in this circumstance.

The Opposition does not believe that the creation of this body will do anything other than generate more paper work and higher costs for the industry. We argue that aviation is a specialised field, a field that can operate alone, stand alone, and be controlled and administered by government. Until we hear further arguments from this Government as to why it is necessary to go down this path we will not support the move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the decision to establish the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) as a separate statutory authority should be seen against the background of a general desire by the Government to reshape the Department of Transport and Communications essentially as a policy department and to spin off from it those very substantial operational areas of the Department which primarily hitherto have been concentrated in the aviation component of it. Thus we have established the Federal Airports Corporation and now the Civil Aviation Authority. Part of the reason for that spin-off of the respective operational arms is to create that very sense of esprit de corps and morale that Senator MacGibbon was so lyrical about identifying as a need in the aviation administration area. I think it has been acknowledged-I acknowledge it now-that there has probably been a loss of some of that spirit that was traditionally associated with the old Department of Civil Aviation as a result of the successive administrative changes it has been subjected to, for one good reason or another, by successive governments. It is important to recreate that sense of professionalism, pride and commitment to a particular complex interrelated set of tasks that we hope will be associated with the creation of these two strongly identified aviation bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: The management of each of these bodies will be very important. The shape, structure, composition and dynamism of the boards that are responsible for their respective administration will be very important indeed. I am certainly conscious of the need to have not merely a representative membership but also a dynamic membership which reflects the sorts of wide-ranging concerns that have been expressed in the course of this debate, plus that hard-headed commercialism which I think is important if we are to be able to develop rational investment strategies of the kind that are so obviously necessary, both on the airport side and in the development of the airways infrastructure.

Probably the central theme underlying the creation of the CAA is to create a body that is sensitive and responsible-using words that I think featured prominently in Senator Sanders's speech-to the industry's requirements and that is sensitive and responsible to industry's capacity and willingness to meet the costs that are associated with developing a decent aviation infrastructure. It is important to establish that nexus between the creation and development of an infrastructure and the role of the industry in paying for what it gets. The relationship is simply too indirect, to diffuse and too subject to too many other competing constraints when those investment decisions are being made essentially by government departments or by the combinations of government departments that are involved in doing that. The idea of creating a direct nexus between the cost recovery strategies and the actual infrastructure investment strategies is central to the underlying rationale, and I would have thought that that was a fairly attractive rationale so far as all the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats are concerned. There is much more that could be said about the underlying philosophy of this, but I simply make that point in general terms.

It is important that the body be subject to the discipline of cost containment and does not feel merely an open-ended kind of capacity to impose charges, increases of one kind or another, to pursue various investment whims and fancies. To that extent the Minister will have some ongoing role in terms of a power to disapprove charges which the Authority might wish to levy. Basically, the discipline will need to be imposed internally and, as I have said, it is important to develop the kind of broad structure which will ensure that there is that kind of close working relationship between the industry and the Authority that we are trying to establish.

I do not think the continued application of the Public Service Act should be seen as a constraint in developing a more flexible and responsive approach-if you like, a less bureaucratic approach-to the staffing needs of the industry. An enormous amount has happened over the last 12 or 18 months in opening up Public Service administration to some of the disciplines, at least at the higher executive and managerial levels, that apply in the commercial sector. Certainly it is the case that under present Public Service legislation senior management appointments can be made on a contract basis. In fact, they can be made right through the executive structure, and it is certainly within the contemplation of the Government that a number of the senior executive posts should be put together on that basis rather than reflecting simply a holus-bolus translation of existing Public Service structures into a new notionally arms-length statutory authority which in practice might not be very different. We want it to be different, but we believe that under the Public Service Act as it now applies there is that degree of flexibility.

There is a lot that I could say about other points that have been raised. Consultation is one that I think needs to be nailed quickly in the last minute or two that I have left. There has been a really quite extensive process of consultation with the industry on the establishment of the CAA. It was initiated by my predecessor, Mr Morris, in November 1986 at a meeting with the Aviation Industry Advisory Council (AVIAC). There has been a constant flow of consultation with staff associations and various industry parties and bodies in the subsequent period. Discussion papers were prepared on the basis of a quite detailed program of consultation run by the Department and that was the subject of the full scale consideration by AVIAC in April 1987. I then announced the decision to go ahead, not just in principle but also in practice, with the CAA in my major aviation statement on 7 October. Since then there has been a whole series of ongoing meetings with different segments of the industry to put flesh on the bones that were outlined on that occasion.

Finally, there are investment strategies that need to be pursued as a matter of priority in the airways infrastructure area. I certainly acknowledge the force of the points that have been made about Coolangatta Airport by Senator MacGibbon and, indeed, another senator in recent days, and, in particular, the force of the points that have been made about Cairns. They are high priority areas for the installation of radar, but plans are well and truly in place and they will get priority under the new administration. The Bitmead review of aviation regulations is well and truly under way and there is a lot more I could say about that. I just make the point that it is not sensible to delay the establishment of this Authority in order to wait for that review to be completed. I indicate, on behalf of the Government, that the Democrat amendments are acceptable and one other formal Government amendment of an administrative kind I believe also ought to be acceptable. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare entitled Kangaroos.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The report on kangaroos is the third report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. Earlier reports were on the export of live sheep from Australia and dolphins and whales in captivity.

The Committee had been inquiring into kangaroos for some time. The taking of evidence and field inspections were completed in the last Parliament. Although the Committee has been expanded in size from four to six members in this Parliament, three of the previous four members were reappointed to the Committee. The former Chairman, George Georges, was not returned to the Senate at the last election.

At this point, I want to give due recognition to the work of the Committee in the previous parliaments in this and other areas of inquiry, and particularly to the leadership of George Georges as Chairman of the Committee. It is obvious that the Committee has had a significant impact on animal welfare in many areas of animal use in Australia. In the course of its inquiry into matters which have been or will be reported on to the Senate, the Committee has stimulated a more informed public debate on many contentious and emotional animal welfare issues. Improvements to animal welfare have often flowed from the this debate even before the Committee has had a chance to report on those matters.
I turn now to the report and the Committee's conclusions and recommendations.

The size and continuing viability of kangaroo populations, particularly of red and grey kangaroos, was a contentious issue during the inquiry. After careful consideration of the evidence, the Committee concludes that none of the species subject to killing is presently threatened with extinction and there is no evidence to indicate that any will become extinct. However, the Committee sounds a note of caution: if there is a significant change in the habitat or the pattern or extent of killing of these species, further consideration will have to be given to their long term viability.

Despite the fact that most killing of kangaroos is done to protect property, little work had been done to assess the extent of the damage caused by kangaroos. Damage to property includes the consumption of pasture, crops and water and damage to fences. Competition with livestock for pasture and water is mainly a problem in dry periods when food is scarce. It was only during the course of the inquiry that any broad-scale estimates of kangaroo damage were published. There is now enough information available to come to the conclusion that the level of damage is not inconsiderable, even though the published estimates of damage must be treated with some caution.

Having come to the conclusion that species of kangaroos which are subjected to legal killing are not in danger of extinction and do cause damage to properties, the Committee then considered the status of kangaroos and their management.

The kangaroo is thought of in affectionate terms by most Australians. It is also a national symbol, as part of Australia's crest and in many other ways. It is also a native animal unique to this part of the world. The Committee therefore recommends that, as a fundamental principle, the kangaroo remain a protected animal.
However, the kangaroo does cause at times intolerable levels of damage to properties and other human land use. It is therefore necessary for the kangaroo to be managed to contain this damage.

As a protected animal, the kangaroo has the right to be left alone except in the case of the protection of property, within the requirements of the law. Leaving aside the use of kangaroos in research, which is being considered in the Committee's examination of animal experimentation, the Committee believes that the kangaroo should not be killed for any other purpose.

The management of kangaroos, with its welfare implications, is a national issue. As such, it should be treated in a national way. Although responsibility for kangaroo management resides with the States, that should not preclude cooperation among the Commonwealth and the States to pursue a national approach to kangaroo management.

There is a national plan of management for kangaroos approved by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. However, a more comprehensive plan is needed to cover all species and all aspects of kangaroo management. It should cover kangaroo population size and dynamics, ecology, protection of habitat, programs to curb kangaroo damage to properties and commercial and non-commercial kill quotas. The plan would reflect the different environments and circumstances occurring in the different regions of Australia and take into account local as well as national needs. There would be, however, one set of objectives and a uniform approach to kangaroo management even if there are different practices to reflect the diversity of species and environments.

Ideally, a comprehensive national kangaroo management plan should be administered federally rather than by the States and Territories individually. There are, of course, enormous constitutional and political problems associated with the transfer of State responsibilities to the Commonwealth. Although it has been suggested to the Committee that the Commonwealth should take over responsibility for wildlife, the Committee does not believe that such an approach is available. The Committee recommends a cooperative approach being taken over time whereby arrangements for national management of kangaroos would be worked out between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

The Committee believes that the killing of kangaroos should not be resorted to as a reflex action. More investigation should be undertaken by the fauna authorities to determine the most effective way of containing kangaroo damage. In some areas, especially new crop areas, the shooting of kangaroos has not been the answer to the farmers' kangaroo problem. The killing of kangaroos should be a last resort, not the first option, in containing kangaroo damage. This will inevitably need greater resources being placed at the disposal of the State fauna authorities.

The killing of kangaroos to contain damage was not really in question during the inquiry. Most of the debate on killing centred on the level of killing and the use of the commercial kangaroo industry to carry out the killing.

Throughout the inquiry, the animal welfare organisations maintained an implacable opposition to the commercial shooting of kangaroos. They argued that the level of killing by the industry was determined by commercial factors and not by the need to protect property. This is largely true, although shooting is generally done within upper limits imposed by government.

From the results of the two studies done by RSPCA Australia into cruelty to kangaroos, and from other information, it is unquestionable that professional shooters kill kangaroos more humanely than other shooters. Where kangaroos have to be killed, there is a strong argument for the use of professional shooters.

Animal welfare organisations argued that where professional shooters are used to kill kangaroos, these shooters should be engaged by the government rather than by the industry. In this way, shooters would only shoot kangaroos which were causing a problem to landholders, and not simply for commercial reasons.

The former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment told the Parliament that the cost of replacing the kangaroo industry with a government shooters' scheme would be about $50 million. Although the Committee believes that such a scheme would not cost that amount of money, it would still require significant government funding.

Under the Constitution, management of fauna is a State responsibility and each State can manage kangaroos in its own way. However, because the industry depends on markets overseas, the Federal Government can impose conditions on the export of kangaroo products. Under the Kangaroo Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, export permits will only be given for kangaroo products derived from kangaroos killed under a kangaroo management program which has been approved by the relevant Federal Minister.

If the industry were disbanded, there would be no exports, and the moderating influence of the Federal Government would be gone. The slaughter of kangaroos in Queensland following the temporary export ban in 1986 is an example of the reaction of a State to the absence of the influence of the Federal Government, even for a short period.
The Committee therefore recommends the continuation of the commercial killing of kangaroos for damage mitigation purposes.

There is provision for non-commercial shooting of kangaroos by landholders or their agents in State legislation. It is clear from the evidence that these shooters have neither the marksmanship nor, in many cases, the firearms to kill kangaroos humanely.
The Committee modified a proposal put forward by RSPCA Australia for the engagement of professional shooters by the government in non-commercial shooting areas.

Adhering to the principle of keeping cruelty to a minimum, the Committee recommends a system whereby those landholders, who can demonstrate ownership of an appropriate firearm and who can satisfy fauna authorities of their marksmanship, may be issued with permits to kill kangaroos on their properties. However, for landholders who cannot meet these criteria, the government would pay travelling expenses to professional shooters to kill kangaroos on the landholders' properties. The landholders would pay a nominal fee to the shooters and the shooters would take the skins for sale to a fauna dealer or skin dealer. In this way, cruelty to kangaroos would be reduced and government would be faced with increased but still quite reasonable expenditure.

This scheme does not involve `government shooters'. It is extending the commercial operation to areas where there is presently no commercial shooting. However, the arrangements for the professional shooter would be made by the fauna authority after the authority has satisfied itself that a bona fide kangaroo problem existed. This arrangement would only apply where a landholder was not equipped to do the job himself.

Government must recognise that management of fauna cannot be relegated to the bottom of the list of priorities for funding. Native fauna are under the control of government and it is the responsibility of government to manage them properly and, where some need to be killed, for the killing to be done as humanely as possible.

The Committee is aware of the need for financial restraint. However, for too long, funding restraint has perpetrated a system in which the level of cruelty is unacceptably high. It is incumbent on this Committee to strive to reduce the level of suffering to kangaroos and other animals in Australia. Despite the calls for more radical changes to the kangaroo management program from some quarters of the community, the Committee believes it has put forward responsible proposals, balancing both animal welfare concerns and the need to keep the funding of kangaroo management within reasonable proportions. A reduction in suffering in kangaroo management leads inescapably to a greater level of funding, which government must embrace.

Finally, I want to thank the staff of the Committee for their work in relation to this report, particularly the Committee Secretary, Paul Barsdell; research officers, Bronwyn Winter, Jim Warner, Doug Hynd and Barbara Allan, and steno-secretaries, Lucinda Hunter, Doris Vidovic and Glenice Castles. I also want to thank all the witnesses and other people who contributed to this inquiry into kangaroos.
I commend the report to the Senate.
